easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Fort Pitt is a name that refers to several places and things. Here are some of them:

* In Canada, there's a place called Saskatchewan, and also a community called Fort Pitt Farms Christian Community.
* In the past, there was a big battle called the Battle of Fort Pitt during a rebellion in Canada.
* There's also a park in Canada called Fort Pitt Provincial Park, which was named after a trading post that was once there.

* In England, there's a school called Fort Pitt Grammar School, and a fort that was built a long time ago during a time of war.

* In the United States, there's a city called Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and several things named after Fort Pitt. These include:
	+ A place where the city was founded, called Fort Pitt.
	+ A train that used to run between Pittsburgh and another city called Altoona.
	+ A building called the Fort Pitt Blockhouse that was built to support the fort.
	+ A street called Fort Pitt Boulevard.
	+ A brewery that used to make beer called Fort Pitt Brewing Company.
	+ A bridge called the Fort Pitt Bridge.
	+ A school called Fort Pitt Elementary School.
	+ An old armory called the Fort Pitt Foundry.
	+ A former ice hockey team called the Fort Pitt Hornets.
	+ A funicular railroad called the Fort Pitt Incline.
	+ A museum called the Fort Pitt Museum.
	+ A soccer club called the Fort Pitt Regiment.
* There was also a time when the city of Pittsburgh was under attack, known as the Siege of Fort Pitt, and a treaty was signed between the United States and a Native American tribe called the Lenape people, known as the Treaty of Fort Pitt.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

In England, there's a school called Fort Pitt Grammar School, and a historic fort that was built during the time of Napoleon.

In the United States, there's a city called Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, which has a rich history. There was once a fort built on the site of the city, and it's now commemorated by a museum. The city also has a bridge, a tunnel, and a few other landmarks that are named after Fort Pitt.

In Pittsburgh, you can also find a former train that used to run between the city and another town called Altoona. There's also a historic armory, a former brewery, and a few other buildings and structures that are connected to Fort Pitt.

Fort Pitt has also been the site of some important events in history. For example, there was a battle during the North-West Rebellion in 1885, and a treaty was signed between the United States and the Lenape people in 1778.

Overall, Fort Pitt is a name that's associated with a range of places and events that are significant in history and culture.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Fort Pitt is a term that encompasses various entities and landmarks across North America and the United Kingdom. The name is derived from the historical significance of the Fort Pitt trading post, established by the Hudson's Bay Company.

In Canada, Fort Pitt refers to the Saskatchewan region, as well as the Fort Pitt Farms Christian Community, a Hutterite group. The Battle of Fort Pitt, which took place during the 1885 North-West Rebellion, is also notable. Additionally, Fort Pitt Provincial Park, a National Historic Site, is situated near the site of the original trading post.

In Kent, England, Fort Pitt is associated with a Napoleonic-era fort and Fort Pitt Grammar School. The fort was constructed during the late 18th century as a defensive measure against French invasion.

In the United States, Fort Pitt has multiple connections to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The original Fort Pitt, built in the 18th century, was situated on the site of present-day Pittsburgh. The city is also home to the Fort Pitt (Amtrak) train, which operated between Pittsburgh and Altoona. Other notable landmarks include the Fort Pitt Blockhouse, a structure built to support the original fort, as well as the Fort Pitt Boulevard, Fort Pitt Brewing Company (active from 1906 to 1957), Fort Pitt Bridge, Fort Pitt Elementary School, Fort Pitt Foundry (a historic armory), Fort Pitt Hornets (a former ice hockey team), Fort Pitt Incline (a former funicular railroad), Fort Pitt Museum, and Fort Pitt Regiment (a soccer club).

Historically, Fort Pitt was also the site of the Siege of Fort Pitt in 1763, during Pontiac's War, and the Treaty of Fort Pitt in 1778, between the United States and the Lenape people. Furthermore, the Fort Pitt Tunnel, a major transportation artery, connects Pittsburgh to the surrounding areas.

samples.title: East Williston, Florida
samples.original_text:
East Williston is a census-designated place (CDP) in Levy County, Florida, United States. The population was 694 at the 2010 census.

Geography
East Williston is located at  (29.389034, -82.419488).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 966 people, 344 households, and 245 families residing in the CDP.  The population density was 310.6 people per square mile (119.9/km2).  There were 381 housing units at an average density of 122.5/sq mi (47.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 12.42% White, 83.75% African American, 0.21% Native American, 1.14% from other races, and 2.48% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.38% of the population.

There were 344 households, out of which 35.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 29.1% were married couples living together, 36.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 28.5% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.81 and the average family size was 3.32.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 31.2% under the age of 18, 12.1% from 18 to 24, 27.6% from 25 to 44, 17.6% from 45 to 64, and 11.5% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 31 years. For every 100 females, there were 75.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 75.5 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $23,882, and the median income for a family was $28,152. Males had a median income of $26,589 versus $17,981 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $14,085.  About 29.4% of families and 28.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 41.7% of those under age 18 and 35.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Levy County, Florida
Census-designated places in Florida

In Inuit mythology, Amaguq is a mischievous god who is also a wolf. You might also know him as Amarok, the spirit of the wolf.

In Inuit culture, there are many animal gods and goddesses that play important roles. One of these is Amaguq, who is known for being a trickster. This means he loves to play pranks and cause trouble, but he's also a powerful and respected figure in Inuit mythology.

In many cultures, wolves are seen as special animals with spiritual significance. In Inuit mythology, wolves are often associated with the god Amaguq, who is said to have the power to control the animals of the forest and the sea.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Mysterious Amaguq: A Trickster God from Inuit Mythology**

In the rich cultural heritage of the Inuit people, there's a fascinating figure known as Amaguq, a mischievous god with a special connection to wolves. But Amaguq isn't the only canine deity in Inuit mythology. There's another important figure, Amarok, who embodies the spirit of the wolf.

In Inuit mythology, Amaguq is often depicted as a trickster, known for playing pranks and causing trouble. This type of god is common in many mythologies, where they use their cunning and wit to test humans and challenge their values. As a wolf god, Amaguq is closely tied to the natural world and the Inuit people's deep respect for the land and its creatures.

Amarok, on the other hand, is a more serious figure, representing the power and majesty of the wolf. In Inuit culture, wolves are revered for their strength, loyalty, and ability to thrive in the harsh Arctic environment. Amarok embodies these qualities, serving as a symbol of protection and guidance.

These two figures, Amaguq and Amarok, offer a fascinating glimpse into the rich cultural heritage of the Inuit people. Their stories and symbolism continue to captivate us, reminding us of the importance of respecting and honoring the natural world.

adult_technical.text:
In Inuit mythology, Amaguq is a complex figure, embodying both the characteristics of a trickster and a wolf deity. This multifaceted nature is reminiscent of Amarok, the spirit of the wolf, which is also deeply rooted in Inuit folklore.

The Inuit pantheon is replete with animal deities, and the canine species is particularly well-represented. The mythology of the Inuit features a rich array of mythological dogs and wolves, which often serve as symbols of power, cunning, and adaptability. The trickster archetype, exemplified by Amaguq, is a common motif in Inuit mythology, reflecting the importance of cleverness and resourcefulness in the harsh Arctic environment.

This theme is echoed in the broader context of folklore, religion, and mythology, where wolves and dogs have long been imbued with symbolic significance. The study of these mythological canines offers valuable insights into the cultural and ecological contexts in which they emerged, as well as the enduring power of these archetypes to captivate human imagination.

samples.title: Humboldt, Illinois

Humboldt is a village in Coles County, Illinois, United States. At the 2020 census, its population was 361. It is part of the Charleston-Mattoon Micropolitan Statistical Area.

History
The village was incorporated on April 16, 1878. The village was named after Alexander von Humboldt, a German natural scientist.

Geography
Humboldt is located at  (39.604140, -88.319676).

According to the 2010 census, Humboldt has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census, there were 481 people, 183 households and 133 families residing in the town. The population density was . There were 199 housing units at an average density of . The racial make-up was 98.75% White, 0.21% Native American and 1.04% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 3.95% of the population.

There were 183 households, of which 35.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 62.8% were married couples living together, 8.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.8% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.63 and the average family size was 3.12.

27.4% of the population were under the age of 18, 8.5% from 18 to 24, 31.0% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64 and 12.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 33 years. For every 100 females, there were 90.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.6 males.

The median household income was $39,375 and the median family income was $45,625. Males had a median income of $29,688 and females $20,417. The per capita income was $16,244. About 1.6% of families and 6.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 5.3% of those under age 18 and 7.5% of those age 65 or over.

Boxtel () is a municipality and a town in the southern Netherlands. The name derives from Buchestelle and is presumably a combination of 'stelle' (Dutch for stable, safe place) and (deer) buck.

This is the origin of the Van Boxtel family, which has numerous descendants in North Brabant.

The town was the site of the Battle of Boxtel fought in September 1794 during the Flanders campaign. It is often principally remembered as the first battle of the future Duke of Wellington.

The Parry Peninsula on the north coast of Canada's Northwest Territories is bounded on the west by Franklin Bay, on the north by Amundsen Gulf, and on the east by Darnley Bay.The nearest settlement is Paulatuk. It is also home to the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary on the northern extremity of the Parry Peninsula.

History
It is named for the Arctic explorer William Edward Parry. On the northern tip of the peninsula is Cape Parry. A headland, and a Distant Early Warning Line site on Parry Peninsula northern tip.

The Parry Peninsula is also home to a very important place for birds, called the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary. This sanctuary is located at the very tip of the peninsula.

The peninsula was named after a famous explorer named William Edward Parry. At the northern tip of the peninsula, you'll find a point of land called Cape Parry, which is also home to a special radar station that helps keep an eye out for any potential threats from far away.

**The Parry Peninsula: A Remote Corner of Canada's Northwest Territories**

Located on the northern coast of Canada's Northwest Territories, the Parry Peninsula is a vast and remote region bounded by three bodies of water: Franklin Bay to the west, Amundsen Gulf to the north, and Darnley Bay to the east. The nearest settlement is the small community of Paulatuk.

This rugged and beautiful area is also home to the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary, which is situated on the northernmost tip of the peninsula. The sanctuary provides a vital habitat for migratory birds and is a haven for nature lovers and bird enthusiasts.

**A Piece of History**

The Parry Peninsula is named after William Edward Parry, a renowned Arctic explorer who ventured into these icy waters in the early 19th century. The northern tip of the peninsula is marked by Cape Parry, a dramatic headland that also hosts a Distant Early Warning Line site. This site was part of a network of radar stations established during the Cold War to detect potential threats from the Soviet Union.

The 1460s BC, spanning from January 1, 1469 BC to December 31, 1460 BC, was a pivotal decade in ancient Near Eastern history. This period witnessed significant military campaigns, the rise of a powerful female pharaoh, and the continuation of established dynasties.

One of the most notable events of this decade was the Battle of Megiddo, circa 1469 BC, in which Egypt emerged victorious over Canaan. This military triumph marked a significant expansion of Egyptian influence in the region and solidified its position as a dominant power in the ancient Near East.

During this decade, Hatshepsut, a female pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty, ruled Egypt from circa 1473 BC to 1458 BC. adult_non_technical.text:
**What Does "Occupation" Mean?**

The word "occupation" can have different meanings depending on the context. Let's break it down.

**Job or Role**: In everyday life, an occupation refers to the work or role you have in society, often a regular activity you do for pay. It's what you do to earn a living and contribute to the world.

**Protest or Demonstration**: In a different sense, occupation can mean a peaceful protest or demonstration where people gather in public spaces to express their opinions or make a statement.

**Military Control**: In a more serious context, occupation refers to when a military force takes control of a territory or area.

**Using a Building**: Finally, occupation can also refer to the act of using a building or space for a specific purpose.

**In Arts and Entertainment**: The word "occupation" has also been used in various forms of media, such as films, TV shows, and video games.

**Other Related Terms**: If you're interested in learning more, you might want to explore related concepts like career, employment, job, profession, and vocation.

In simple terms, occupation is a versatile word that can have different meanings depending on the context. Whether it's a job, a protest, military control, or using a building, occupation is an important part of our daily lives.

samples.title: Abatement of debts and legacies
samples.original_text:
Abatement of debts and legacies is a common law doctrine of wills that holds that when the equitable assets of a deceased person are not sufficient to satisfy fully all the creditors, their debts must abate proportionately, and they must accept a dividend.

In the case of legacies when the funds or assets out of which they are payable are not sufficient to pay them in full, the legacies abate in proportion, unless there is a priority given specially to any particular legacy. Annuities are also subject to the same rule as general legacies.

The order of abatement is usually:
 Intestate property
 The residuary of the estate
 General Devises—i.e., cash gifts
 Demonstrative Devises—i.e., cash gifts from a specific account, stocks, bonds, securities, etc.
 Specific Devises—i.e., specified items of personal property, real property, etc.
Non-probate property—i.e., life insurance policies—do not abate.

Definitions
A specific devise, is a specific gift in a will to a specific person other than an amount of money. For example, if James's will states that he is leaving his $500,000 yacht to his brother Mike, the yacht would be a specific devise.

A general devise, is a monetary gift to a specific person to be satisfied out of the overall estate. For example, if James's will states that he is leaving $500,000 to his son Sam then the money would be a general devise.

A demonstrative devise, is money given from a particular account.  For example, "$10,000 to be paid from the sale of my GM stock."

A residual devise is one left to a devisee after all specific and general devices have been made.  For example, James's will might say: "I give all the rest, residue and remainder of my estate to my daughter Lilly." Lilly would be the residual devisee and entitled to James's residuary estate.

References

Common law
Wills and trusts

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

When someone dies, their debts and legacies (gifts) need to be paid. If the person doesn't have enough money or assets to pay everything, the debts and legacies are reduced proportionally. This means that each debt or legacy is paid a smaller amount.

For example, let's say someone leaves a will that says they want to give $10,000 to their friend, but they only have $5,000 available. In this case, the friend would only receive $5,000.

The same rule applies to legacies, which are gifts of specific items or amounts of money. If the person doesn't have enough money or assets to pay the full amount, the legacy is reduced proportionally.

The order in which debts and legacies are paid is usually as follows:

1. Debts that aren't mentioned in the will (intestate property)
2. The remaining assets of the estate (residuary of the estate)
3. Cash gifts (general devises)
4. Cash gifts from specific accounts, stocks, bonds, or securities (demonstrative devises)
5. Specific gifts of personal or real property (specific devises)

However, some assets, like life insurance policies, don't follow this rule and are paid out in full.

Here are some definitions to help clarify things:

* A specific devise is a gift of a specific item, like a yacht or a piece of jewelry, to a specific person.
* A general devise is a monetary gift to a specific person, like $500,000 to a son or daughter.
* A demonstrative devise is a gift of money from a specific account, like "$10,000 to be paid from the sale of my GM stock."
* A residual devise is a gift of the remaining assets of the estate after all other gifts have been made.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**When a Person Dies, Who Gets What?**

When someone passes away, their assets are divided among their loved ones according to their will. But what happens if there's not enough money or property to go around? That's where the concept of "abatement" comes in.

Abatement is a rule that helps determine how to divide up the remaining assets among the people or organizations named in the will. It's like a recipe for dividing a limited pie among multiple people. When there's not enough pie to go around, each slice gets smaller to make sure everyone gets a fair share.

The same rule applies to legacies, which are promises to leave specific gifts or amounts of money to certain people. If the funds to pay these legacies are limited, they are reduced proportionally, unless a specific legacy is given priority.

The order in which assets are divided is usually as follows:

1. First, any assets that aren't part of the will (like life insurance policies) are distributed.
2. Next, the remaining assets in the will are divided among the beneficiaries.
3. Cash gifts (general devises) are distributed first, followed by gifts from specific accounts (demonstrative devises).
4. Finally, specific gifts (like a yacht or a piece of real estate) are distributed.

To understand these terms, let's break them down:

* A specific devise is a gift of a specific item, like a yacht or a piece of jewelry, to a specific person.
* A general devise is a monetary gift to a specific person, taken from the overall estate.
* A demonstrative devise is a gift of money from a specific account, like a stock or bond.
* A residual devise is a gift of the remaining assets after all other gifts have been made.

In summary, abatement is a way to divide up the remaining assets of a deceased person fairly among their loved ones, ensuring that everyone gets a share. By understanding the different types of gifts and the order in which they are distributed, we can ensure that the wishes of the deceased are carried out.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The doctrine of abatement of debts and legacies in wills, rooted in common law, dictates that when the equitable assets of a deceased individual are insufficient to satisfy all creditors in full, the debts must proportionally abate, and creditors must accept a dividend.

In the case of legacies, when the funds or assets from which they are payable are insufficient to pay them in full, the legacies abate proportionally, unless a specific priority is assigned to a particular legacy. This principle applies equally to annuities.

The order of abatement typically follows a specific hierarchy:

1. Intestate property
2. The residuary of the estate
3. General devises (cash gifts)
4. Demonstrative devises (cash gifts from specific accounts, such as stocks, bonds, or securities)
5. Specific devises (specified items of personal or real property)

Notably, non-probate property, such as life insurance policies, is exempt from abatement.

For the purposes of this doctrine, the following definitions are crucial:

* A specific devise refers to a gift in a will to a specific person, excluding monetary amounts. For instance, a will that leaves a $500,000 yacht to a brother would constitute a specific devise.
* A general devise, on the other hand, is a monetary gift to a specific person, to be satisfied from the overall estate. An example would be a will that leaves $500,000 to a son.
* A demonstrative devise is a monetary gift from a particular account. For instance, a will that states "$10,000 to be paid from the sale of my GM stock" would be a demonstrative devise.
* A residual devise is a gift left to a devisee after all specific and general devises have been made. For example, a will that states "I give all the rest, residue, and remainder of my estate to my daughter Lilly" would make Lilly the residual devisee and entitled to the residuary estate.

References:

* Common law
* Wills and trusts

samples.title: Gilding metal
samples.original_text:
Gilding metal is a form of brass (an alloy of copper and zinc) with a much higher copper content than zinc content. Exact figures range from 95% copper and 5% zinc to “8 parts copper to 1 of zinc” (11% zinc) in British Army Dress Regulations.

Gilding metal is used for various purposes, including the jackets of bullets, driving bands on some artillery shells, as well as enameled badges and other jewellery. The sheet is widely used for craft metalworking by hammer working. It is also used particularly as a lower-cost training material for silversmiths.  Starting in 1944, shell casings made of gilding metal were melted down by the United States Mint to be made into pennies.  These pennies replaced the less popular steel cent of 1943, and the pennies of this composition were produced until 1946.

Gilding metal was also used for the "bronze" Olympic medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics held in Tokyo, Japan in 2021.

Gilding metal may be annealed by heating to between . It should be cooled slowly afterwards, to reduce risk of cracking.

References 

Copper alloys
Brass
Ammunition

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

Gilding metal is a special kind of metal made from a mix of copper and zinc. It's different from regular brass because it has a lot more copper than zinc. The exact mix can vary, but it's usually around 95% copper and 5% zinc.

Gilding metal is used for many things, like making bullet casings, artillery shell bands, and even jewelry. It's also popular among crafty people who like to work with metal by hammering it. Some silversmiths use it as a cheaper way to practice their skills.

In the past, the United States Mint melted down gilding metal to make pennies. This started in 1944 and lasted until 1946. These pennies replaced the steel pennies that were made in 1943.

Gilding metal was also used to make the Olympic medals for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan.

When working with gilding metal, it's important to heat it up and then cool it down slowly to prevent it from cracking.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Magic of Gilding Metal: A Copper-Zinc Alloy with Many Uses**

You may have heard of brass, a popular alloy made from copper and zinc. But did you know that there's a special type of brass called gilding metal, which has a higher copper content than zinc? This unique blend of metals has been used for a variety of purposes, from making bullets and artillery shells to crafting jewelry and even coins.

Gilding metal is prized for its durability and malleability, making it a favorite among metalworkers who shape and hammer it into intricate designs. It's also a more affordable option for silversmiths to practice their craft. In fact, during World War II, the United States Mint melted down gilding metal shell casings to create pennies, replacing the less popular steel cents.

In recent years, gilding metal has made a comeback, with the 2020 Tokyo Olympics featuring medals made from this very alloy. The medals were designed to be both beautiful and durable, reflecting the metal's versatility.

When working with gilding metal, it's essential to heat it carefully and let it cool slowly to prevent cracking. This process, called annealing, helps to relax the metal's internal stresses, making it easier to shape and mold.

From bullets to badges, coins to Olympic medals, gilding metal is a remarkable alloy with a rich history and many uses. Its unique properties make it a popular choice for metalworkers and craftspeople around the world.

adult_technical.text:
Gilding metal is a copper-zinc alloy characterized by a significantly higher copper content than zinc. The exact composition ranges from 95% copper and 5% zinc to an 8:1 ratio of copper to zinc (11% zinc), as specified in British Army Dress Regulations.

This alloy is utilized in various applications, including the production of bullet jackets, driving bands on artillery shells, and enameled badges and jewelry. Its sheet form is widely employed in craft metalworking through hammer working, and it is also used as a cost-effective training material for silversmiths.

Notably, gilding metal was used as a raw material for the production of pennies by the United States Mint, starting in 1944. These pennies replaced the steel cent of 1943 and were produced until 1946. Additionally, gilding metal was used to manufacture the "bronze" Olympic medals awarded at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, held in 2021.

To optimize its properties, gilding metal can be annealed by heating it to a specific temperature range. Following annealing, slow cooling is essential to minimize the risk of cracking.

References:

* Copper alloys
* Brass
* Ammunition

samples.title: AD 145
samples.original_text:
Year 145 (CXLV) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar (or, less frequently, year 898 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 145 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events

By place

Roman Empire 
 Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar become Roman Consuls.
 Marcus Aurelius marries Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius.
 Arrian becomes archon in Athens.

Asia 
 Change of emperor from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

Births 
 April 11 – Septimius Severus, Roman emperor (d. 211)

Deaths 
 Han Chongdi, Chinese emperor of the Han Dynasty (b. 143)

References

easy_general.text:

Important Events

In Rome:

* Two new leaders, Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar, took over as Roman Consuls.
* Marcus Aurelius married Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius.
* A man named Arrian became the leader of Athens.

In Asia:

* The emperor of the Chinese Han Dynasty, Han Chongdi, died and was replaced by Han Zhidi.

Births:

* Septimius Severus, who would later become a Roman emperor, was born on April 11.

Deaths:

* Han Chongdi, the emperor of the Han Dynasty, died.

Note: I've kept the important information from the original text, but used simpler language and shorter sentences to make it easier to understand. I've also avoided using technical words like "archon" and "Ab urbe condita" and explained them in simple terms.

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text in plain language:

In the year 145, the Roman Empire was ruled by two powerful leaders, Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar. This was a significant year, marked by important events that shaped the course of history.

In Rome, Marcus Aurelius married Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius, in a ceremony that solidified their family ties. Meanwhile, a new leader, Arrian, took charge in Athens, a city in ancient Greece.

Across the seas, in China, the Han Dynasty was experiencing a change in leadership. Emperor Han Chongdi passed away, and his successor, Han Zhidi, took the throne.

This year also saw the birth of a future Roman emperor, Septimius Severus, who would go on to rule the empire for many years. Unfortunately, Han Chongdi's death marked the end of his life, leaving behind a legacy that would be remembered for centuries to come.

In the years that followed, the way people counted time changed. The Anno Domini calendar, which is still used today, became the standard method for naming years in Europe. This meant that the year 145 would be known as 145 AD, a system that has been used ever since.

These events may seem like small steps in the grand tapestry of history, but they laid the foundation for the world we live in today.

adult_technical.text:
Year 145 CE was a common year that commenced on a Thursday, according to the Julian calendar. At the time, it was denoted as the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar, or alternatively, as the 898th year since the founding of Rome (Ab urbe condita). The convention of numbering years as 145 has been employed since the early Middle Ages, when the Anno Domini era became the dominant method of dating in Europe.

Events

Regional Developments

Roman Empire

Asia
The Han Dynasty in China witnessed a change in imperial leadership, with Han Chongdi being succeeded by Han Zhidi.

Births
On April 11, Septimius Severus, a future Roman Emperor, was born. He would later reign from 193 to 211 CE.

Deaths
Han Chongdi, the Chinese Emperor of the Han Dynasty, passed away on an unknown date, but likely in 145 CE, given his birth year of 143 CE.

samples.title: Termination type
samples.original_text:
In lithic reduction, termination type is a characteristic indicating the manner in which the distal end of a lithic flake detaches from a core (Andrefsky 1998:18).  Common types include:

 Step/snap termination – these occur when a flake snaps or breaks during removal, resulting in an abrupt right-angle break.
 Hinge termination – results when the applied force rolls away from the core or objective piece, creating a rounded or blunted distal end.
 Overshot/outrepasse/plunging termination - occurs when the applied force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core.  Also referred to as a reverse hinge termination.
 Perverse termination - "twisting" breaks resulting from when the applied force is redirected through the material in a helical fashion;
 Feather/monotomic termination – a smooth termination that results in a feathered distal end.  The distal ends of these flakes are only a few molecules thick, are extremely sharp, and indicate a flawless detachment.  These are the intended results of some lithic reduction techniques, and are very desirable for opportunistic tool use that does not require retouching or sharpening.

References
 Andrefsky, William, Jr. (1998) Lithics: Macroscopic approaches to analysis.  Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

Lithics

easy_general.text:
When archaeologists study old stone tools, they look at how the stone flakes off from the core. This is called lithic reduction. One important thing they examine is the way the flake breaks off at the end. This is called the termination type.

There are several different types of terminations. One type is called a step or snap termination. This happens when the flake breaks off suddenly, like a piece of glass breaking. Another type is called a hinge termination. This happens when the force used to remove the flake rolls away from the core, making the end of the flake rounded.

Sometimes, the force used to remove the flake dips and takes a piece of the opposite side of the artifact or the core. This is called an overshot or plunging termination. Another type is called a perverse termination, which is like a twisting break. This happens when the force is applied in a special way, kind of like twisting a rope.

The last type is called a feather or monotomic termination. This is when the flake breaks off smoothly, leaving a very sharp and thin edge. This is what happens when a tool is made to be used without needing to be sharpened or retouched. Archaeologists like to find these types of terminations because they can learn a lot about how the tool was made and used.

Note: I've kept the main points and technical terms, but explained them in simpler language and added examples to help make it easier to understand. I've also avoided copying sentences from the original text and used my own wording.

adult_non_technical.text:
**How Lithic Flakes Break Off: Understanding Termination Types**

When archaeologists study ancient stone tools, they look for clues about how the tools were made. One important clue is the way the stone flakes break off during the manufacturing process. This is called the "termination type" of the flake.

There are several ways a flake can break off, and each type tells us something about how the tool was made. Here are some common types:

* **Step or Snap Termination**: This happens when the flake breaks off suddenly, like a piece of glass shattering. The edge is sharp and clean, with a right-angle bend.
* **Hinge Termination**: In this case, the flake breaks off when the force applied to it rolls away from the core or the tool being made. The edge is rounded or blunted, and the break is smooth.
* **Overshot or Reverse Hinge Termination**: This type of break occurs when the force applied to the flake dips and removes a section of the opposite edge of the tool or the core. It's like a reverse hinge, where the flake breaks off in the opposite direction.
* **Perverse Termination**: This type of break is like a twisting motion, where the force applied to the flake is redirected through the material in a spiral shape. The edge is rough and irregular.
* **Feather or Monotomic Termination**: This is the most desirable type of break, where the flake breaks off smoothly and leaves a very sharp, thin edge. The edge is so thin that it's almost like a feather, and it doesn't need to be sharpened or retouched.

Understanding these termination types helps archaeologists learn more about how ancient people made their tools and what techniques they used. It's like solving a puzzle, and each piece of information helps us build a better picture of the past.

adult_technical.text:
In lithic reduction, the termination type refers to the manner in which the distal end of a flake detaches from a core (Andrefsky 1998). This characteristic is crucial in understanding the mechanics of flintknapping and the intentional design of lithic tools. The following types of terminations are commonly observed:

Step/snap terminations occur when the flake breaks or snaps during removal, resulting in a sharp, right-angle break. This type of termination is often indicative of a sudden, forceful detachment.

Hinge terminations, on the other hand, result from the applied force rolling away from the core or objective piece, creating a rounded or blunted distal end. This type of termination suggests a more controlled detachment process.

Overshot, outrepasse, or plunging terminations occur when the applied force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core. This type of termination is also referred to as a reverse hinge termination, highlighting the complex dynamics involved in the detachment process.

Perverse terminations are characterized by twisting breaks resulting from the redirected force being applied to the material in a helical fashion. This type of termination is often indicative of a more complex, multi-step reduction process.

Feather or monotomic terminations, in contrast, result in a smooth, feathered distal end. These flakes are extremely sharp, with a thickness of only a few molecules, and are often the intended outcome of specific lithic reduction techniques. Feather terminations are highly desirable for opportunistic tool use that does not require retouching or sharpening.

References:
Andrefsky, William, Jr. (1998) Lithics: Macroscopic approaches to analysis. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Cordova: A Name with Many Meanings**

Cordova is a name that has been used in many different contexts throughout history and around the world. In this article, we'll explore the various meanings and uses of the name Cordova.

**Places**

samples.title: Mass media in Laos
samples.original_text:
Mass media in Laos are based on a network of telephone lines and radiotelephone communications in remote areas, as well as mobile phone infrastructure. The system is not well-developed.

Infrastructure and statistics
In 1997 there were 25,000 telephone lines in use, and in 2007 there were 850,000 mobile cellular subscribers. Laos is served by a Russian Intersputnik satellite that covers the Indian Ocean region.

In 1998 there were 12 AM stations and one FM station. In 1997 there were an estimated 730,000 radios in the country. In 2011 Laos had three television channels. In 2000 there was one Internet service provider, by 2002 serving about 10,000 users. The top-level domain for Laos is .la.

See also
 Telephone numbers in Laos
 Internet in Laos

References 

 
Laos
Laos

samples.title: Center Creek Township, Martin County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Center Creek Township is a township in Martin County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 269 at the 2000 census.

This township took its name from Center Creek.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which   is land and   (0.08%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 269 people, 106 households, and 78 families residing in the township.  The population density was 7.6 people per square mile (2.9/km2).  There were 111 housing units at an average density of 3.1/sq mi (1.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.51% White, and 1.49% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.86% of the population.

There were 106 households, out of which 26.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 64.2% were married couples living together, 3.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.4% were non-families. 20.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 2.88.

In the township the population was spread out, with 23.0% under the age of 18, 8.6% from 18 to 24, 25.3% from 25 to 44, 27.1% from 45 to 64, and 16.0% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 100.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $40,859, and the median income for a family was $41,477. Males had a median income of $26,389 versus $18,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,689.  About 2.6% of families and 3.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including none of those under the age of eighteen and 5.6% of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Martin County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

Capricorn is a term that can refer to a variety of things, from geographical locations to fictional characters, and even technology. Let's take a journey to explore the different meanings of this versatile term.

**Places**

Capricorn can refer to a group of islands in the southern Great Barrier Reef in Australia, or a district in the Limpopo province of South Africa.

**Animals**

In the animal kingdom, Capricorn is the name of a type of goat-like or antelope-like creature, and also a genus of animals that includes the Alpine ibex.

**Astronomy and Astrology**

In the night sky, Capricorn is one of the 12 constellations of the zodiac, and in astrology, it's associated with the sign of the same name.

**Arts and Entertainment**

In the world of fiction, Capricorn has been the name of several characters in comics, books, and movies. In music, there have been albums and singles with this title, and even a record label called Capricorn Records.

**Other Uses**

Capricorn has also been used as the name of a microprocessor, a ship, and even a pressure group in British African colonies. In science fiction, it's a term that has been used in various contexts, including the popular TV series Battlestar Galactica.

**In Conclusion**

As you can see, Capricorn is a term with many meanings and uses. Whether it's a place, an animal, a celestial body, or a fictional character, Capricorn is a versatile term that has captured the imagination of people around the world.

samples.title: Helsingborg Municipality
samples.original_text:
Helsingborg Municipality (Helsingborgs kommun) is a municipality in Scania County in Sweden. Its seat is located in the city of Helsingborg, which is Sweden's eighth largest city. The municipality had a population of 
147,734 on January 1, 2019, and the metro has about 320,000 inhabitants.

Between 1912 and 1971 the name of the town was officially spelled Hälsingborg (rather like the region of Hälsingland but unlike neighbouring Danish Helsingør and the Finnish capital Helsingfors (Helsinki)). The spelling was changed back to the older version when the present municipality was created in 1971 through the amalgamation of the Town of Hälsingborg with four surrounding rural municipalities. Since the 1990s the municipality again styles itself Helsingborgs stad (Town of Helsingborg). This usage is only nominal and has no effect on the status of the municipality.

Localities

As of 2018, there were 16 urban areas the municipality.

International relations

Twin towns — sister cities
Helsingborg is twinned with:
 Alexandria, United States
 Dubrovnik, Croatia

 Liepāja, Latvia
 Pärnu, Estonia

See also
 Municipalities of Sweden
 European route E4

References
Statistics Sweden

External links

Helsingborg Municipality - Official site
The local daily newspaper

 
Municipalities of Skåne County
Scania

samples.title: ICD (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
ICD is the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems, an international standard diagnostic tool.

ICD may also refer to:

Organizations
 Information Control Division of the US Army in Germany after WWII
 United States Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense (USAMRICD or ICD) 
 Iranian Club, Dubai
 Islamic Corporation for the Development of the Private Sector, of the Islamic Development Bank
 International Clothing Designs, UK clothing importer

Science and technology
 In-circuit debugger, in electronic hardware development
 Interface control document, in systems and software engineering
 MPLAB devices ICD (n-circuit debugger)
 Interatomic Coulombic decay, a relaxation process

Medicine
 Immunogenic cell death
 Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator
 Impulse control disorder
 Isobaric counterdiffusion

Other uses
 Doctor of Canon Law (Latin: Iuris Canonici Doctor)
 Incentive-centered design
 Inland container depot of Container Corporation of India

See also
 Intelligence Community Directive 301 (ICD-301)

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

ICD stands for International Classification of Diseases. It's a special tool that doctors and healthcare professionals use to diagnose and track different illnesses and health problems. This tool helps them to understand and compare health data from all around the world.

But ICD can also stand for other things. For example:

* In the US Army, ICD was the name of a division that controlled information during World War II.
* In the UK, ICD is a company that imports clothing.
* In Dubai, ICD is the name of a club.
* In the Islamic Development Bank, ICD is a group that helps develop private businesses.

In science and technology, ICD can also mean:

* A special tool that helps engineers test and fix electronic devices.
* A document that explains how different systems and software work together.
* A type of device that helps scientists study the behavior of atoms.

In medicine, ICD can stand for:

* A type of cell death that happens when the immune system is fighting an infection.
* A device that helps regulate a person's heartbeat.
* A condition where a person has trouble controlling their impulses.
* A process that happens when different substances mix together in a special way.

Finally, ICD can also stand for:

* A special degree in Canon Law, which is a type of law that deals with the rules of the Catholic Church.
* A design approach that focuses on encouraging people to make good choices.
* A storage facility for shipping containers in India.

If you're still confused, you can look up Intelligence Community Directive 301 (ICD-301) for more information.

adult_non_technical.text:
**What is ICD?**

ICD stands for International Classification of Diseases, a system used by doctors and healthcare professionals around the world to diagnose and track illnesses. It's like a universal language that helps them communicate and compare health information.

But ICD can also refer to other things. Let's break it down:

**Organizations**

* In the past, ICD was the name of a division within the US Army in Germany after World War II.
* Today, it's also the name of a medical research institute in the US, a club in Dubai, and a company that promotes private sector development in the Islamic world.

**Science and Technology**

* In electronics, ICD can refer to a tool that helps developers test and fix problems with electronic circuits.
* In software engineering, it's a document that outlines how different systems communicate with each other.
* In chemistry, ICD is a process that helps atoms relax and stabilize.

**Medicine**

* In medicine, ICD can refer to a type of cell death that triggers an immune response.
* It's also the name of a device that helps regulate irregular heartbeats.
* Additionally, ICD can describe a condition where people have trouble controlling their impulses.
* Finally, it's a term used to describe a process where two substances mix together without changing their pressure.

**Other uses**

* In the world of law, ICD stands for Doctor of Canon Law, a degree earned by experts in church law.
* In design, ICD is a approach that focuses on creating products that motivate people to behave in certain ways.
* In logistics, ICD is a type of storage facility for shipping containers.

**What's the connection?**

While ICD has many meanings, they all share a common thread - they're all about classification, diagnosis, and understanding. Whether it's a medical condition, a technical process, or a business concept, ICD is a term that helps us make sense of the world around us.

adult_technical.text:
The International Classification of Diseases (ICD) is a globally recognized diagnostic tool used to standardize the classification of diseases and health problems. This terminology is employed by healthcare professionals and researchers to facilitate the recording, analysis, and comparison of health data.

Beyond its application in medicine, the term ICD has been adopted by various organizations and industries. For instance, the Information Control Division of the US Army in Germany, established after World War II, shares the same acronym. Additionally, the United States Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense (USAMRICD) and the Iranian Club in Dubai also utilize the ICD designation.

In the realm of science and technology, ICD has distinct meanings. In electronic hardware development, an in-circuit debugger (ICD) is a tool used to diagnose and troubleshoot issues within a circuit. In systems and software engineering, an interface control document (ICD) outlines the specifications for communication between different components. Furthermore, MPLAB devices employ an ICD as an n-circuit debugger.

In the field of physics, interatomic Coulombic decay (ICD) refers to a relaxation process that occurs between atoms. In medicine, ICD has several distinct meanings, including immunogenic cell death, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, impulse control disorder, and isobaric counterdiffusion.

Outside of medicine and science, ICD is used in various contexts. The Latin term "Iuris Canonici Doctor" translates to Doctor of Canon Law, while incentive-centered design and inland container depot of Container Corporation of India also utilize the ICD designation.

Finally, Intelligence Community Directive 301 (ICD-301) is a document outlining guidelines for intelligence agencies.

samples.title: Pope Pelagius II
samples.original_text:
Pope Pelagius II (died 7 February 590) was the bishop of Rome from 26 November 579 to his death.

Life
Pelagius was a native of Rome, but probably of Ostrogothic descent, as his father's name was Winigild. Pelagius became Pope Benedict I's successor on November 26, 579, without imperial confirmation.

Pelagius appealed for help from Emperor Maurice against the Lombards, but to no avail, forcing Pelagius to "buy" a truce and turn to the Franks, who invaded Italy, but left after being bribed by the Lombards.

Pelagius labored to promote clerical celibacy, and he issued stringent regulations on this matter. During his pontificate, the bishop of Milan, who had broken communion with Rome in the Schism of the Three Chapters, returned to full communion around 581, while other bishops in Northern Italy remained in schism.

Pelagius ordered the construction of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, a church shrine over the place where Saint Lawrence was martyred. During his reign, the Visigoths of Spain converted, but he also faced conflict with the See of Constantinople over the adoption of the title of "Ecumenical Patriarch," which Pelagius believed to undermine the authority of the papacy.

Pelagius fell victim to the plague that devastated Rome at the end of 590. His successor, Gregory I, thought his regulations of clerical celibacy too strict, and modified them to some extent.

References

590 deaths
Popes
Italian popes
6th-century deaths from plague (disease)
Popes of the Byzantine Papacy
6th-century archbishops
Year of birth unknown
520 births
6th-century popes
Infectious disease deaths in Lazio

Pelagius became pope after Pope Benedict I died, but he didn't get official approval from the emperor at the time, Maurice. This caused some problems for Pelagius, as he had to deal with a group called the Lombards who were causing trouble in Italy. He even had to pay them to stop fighting.

Pelagius wanted to make sure that priests didn't get married, so he made some strict rules about it. During his time as pope, some other bishops in Italy who had broken away from the Catholic Church returned to being part of it. He also built a new church in Rome to honor a saint named Lawrence.

Pelagius had some disagreements with the Church in Constantinople, which is now modern-day Istanbul, over who should be in charge. He also faced challenges when the plague, a deadly disease, spread through Rome and killed many people, including him.

After Pelagius died, his successor, Pope Gregory I, changed some of the rules about priests getting married.

adult_non_technical.text:
Meet Pope Pelagius II: The Pope Who Faced Many Challenges

Pope Pelagius II was the leader of the Catholic Church in Rome from 579 until his death in 590. He was born in Rome, but his family had roots in the Ostrogothic kingdom, which was a powerful force in Italy at the time.

Pelagius became pope after the death of Pope Benedict I, but he didn't have the formal approval of the Emperor Maurice, who was the ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire. This didn't stop Pelagius from trying to protect his city from the Lombards, a rival tribe that was invading Italy. Unfortunately, his appeals to the Emperor for help were unsuccessful, and he had to pay the Lombards to leave Rome alone.

Pelagius was also a strong advocate for priests to remain celibate, and he introduced strict rules to enforce this. During his time as pope, the bishop of Milan, who had previously broken away from Rome, returned to the fold, and other bishops in Northern Italy also ended their schism.

Pelagius also oversaw the construction of a new church in Rome, the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, which was built on the site where Saint Lawrence was martyred. He also faced challenges from the Visigoths in Spain, who converted to Christianity during his reign, and from the See of Constantinople, which was trying to assert its authority over the papacy.

Sadly, Pelagius died in 590, likely due to the plague that was sweeping through Rome at the time. His successor, Pope Gregory I, relaxed some of the strict rules Pelagius had introduced regarding priestly celibacy.

Overall, Pope Pelagius II faced many challenges during his time as pope, from wars and invasions to internal conflicts and disease. Despite these challenges, he remained committed to his duties and worked to strengthen the Catholic Church in Rome.

adult_technical.text:
Pope Pelagius II (died February 7, 590) occupied the papacy from November 26, 579, until his demise.

Biography
Pelagius, a native Roman, likely of Ostrogothic descent, succeeded Pope Benedict I without imperial confirmation on November 26, 579. His pontificate was marked by a series of diplomatic and military challenges. In an effort to counter the Lombard threat, Pelagius appealed to Emperor Maurice for assistance, but ultimately was forced to negotiate a truce and seek the aid of the Franks. The Franks, however, were bribed by the Lombards and withdrew from Italy.

Pelagius devoted significant attention to promoting clerical celibacy, issuing stringent regulations to enforce this policy. During his tenure, the bishop of Milan, who had previously broken communion with Rome during the Schism of the Three Chapters, returned to full communion around 581. Meanwhile, other bishops in Northern Italy remained in schism.

Pelagius oversaw the construction of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, a shrine built over the site of Saint Lawrence's martyrdom. His papacy also witnessed the conversion of the Visigoths in Spain, as well as a dispute with the See of Constantinople regarding the adoption of the title "Ecumenical Patriarch," which Pelagius believed would undermine the authority of the papacy.

Pelagius succumbed to the plague that ravaged Rome at the end of 590. His successor, Gregory I, subsequently modified the regulations on clerical celibacy, which Pelagius had deemed too strict.

samples.title: Burdell Township, Michigan
samples.original_text:
Burdell Township is a civil township of Osceola County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  As of the 2000 census, the township population was 1,241.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  is land and  (0.56%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 1,241 people, 478 households, and 351 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.2 per square mile (12.8/km2).  There were 713 housing units at an average density of 19.1 per square mile (7.4/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.55% White, 0.08% African American, 0.32% Native American, 0.24% Asian, and 0.81% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.48% of the population.

There were 478 households, out of which 31.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 61.3% were married couples living together, 8.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.4% were non-families. 20.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 3.00.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.0% under the age of 18, 6.9% from 18 to 24, 28.0% from 25 to 44, 26.0% from 45 to 64, and 13.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 101.1 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.8 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $35,481, and the median income for a family was $40,815. Males had a median income of $30,521 versus $20,294 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,375.  About 8.8% of families and 13.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 15.5% of those under age 18 and 9.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Osceola County, Michigan
Townships in Michigan

samples.title: Salhouse Broad
samples.original_text:
Salhouse Broad, one of the Norfolk Broads, is situated on the River Bure in The Broads in Norfolk, England.

The broad is situated just off the river and attracts little through traffic. It lies south of Hoveton Great Broad and approximately half a mile north of the village of Salhouse. Salhouse Broad is accessible from the landward side and moorings are also permitted to fee-paying boat visitors. It is privately owned and managed in conjunction with the community of Salhouse. The broad covers an area of  and is home to many forms of wildlife including the Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the swallowtail butterfly. Black swans have been recorded on this broad. Salhouse Broad is unusual in being the result of the flooding of tenth century sand and gravel diggings, not of peat diggings like most of the broads.

References

Norfolk Broads

Salhouse Broad is a special place because it's home to many different types of wildlife, like the Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the swallowtail butterfly. You might even spot some black swans swimming around! What's unique about Salhouse Broad is that it was created when the river flooded an old sand and gravel pit, which is different from how most of the other broads were formed.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

Accessible from the land and with mooring facilities available for visitors, Salhouse Broad is a popular spot for boaters and those looking to connect with nature. The broad is privately owned and managed by the local community, ensuring its preservation for future generations.

This unique broad is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including the majestic Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the stunning swallowtail butterfly. You might even catch a glimpse of a black swan gliding across the water. What sets Salhouse Broad apart from other broads in the area is its unusual history - it was formed when the River Bure flooded a series of sand and gravel diggings dating back to the 10th century, rather than the more common peat diggings.

Whether you're a nature enthusiast, a boater, or simply looking for a peaceful escape, Salhouse Broad is a must-visit destination in the Norfolk Broads.

samples.title: Amoz
samples.original_text:
Amoz  (), also known as Amotz, was the father of the prophet Isaiah, mentioned in Isaiah 1:1; 2:1 and 13:1, and in II Kings 19:2, 20; 20:1. Nothing else is known for certain about him.

There is a Talmudic tradition that when the name of a prophet's father is given, the father was also a prophet, so that Amoz would have been a prophet like his son. Though it is mentioned frequently as the patronymic title of Isaiah, the name Amoz appears nowhere else in the Bible. The rabbis of the Talmud declared, based upon a rabbinic tradition, that Amoz was the brother of Amaziah (אמציה), the king of Judah at that time (and, as a result, that Isaiah himself was a member of the royal family). According to some traditions, Amoz is the "man of God" in 2 Chronicles 25:7–9 (Seder Olam Rabbah 20), who cautioned Amaziah to release the Israelite mercenaries that he had hired.

References

Prophets in Judaism
Hebrew Bible people
Isaiah

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Isaiah's Father: Amoz

Isaiah, a famous prophet in the Bible, had a father named Amoz. We know about Amoz because he is mentioned in several places in the Bible, including Isaiah 1:1, 2:1, and 13:1, as well as 2 Kings 19:2, 20; 20:1.

Some people think that when the Bible mentions a prophet's father, it means the father was also a prophet. If that's true, then Amoz would have been a prophet just like his son Isaiah. However, we don't know much about Amoz beyond his connection to Isaiah.

The rabbis, who are Jewish scholars, have a different idea about Amoz. They think that Amoz was actually the brother of King Amaziah, who ruled Judah at the time. This would mean that Isaiah was part of the royal family.

There's another story about Amoz in the Bible. In 2 Chronicles 25:7-9, there's a "man of God" who tells King Amaziah to release some soldiers he had hired. Some people think this "man of God" might have been Amoz.

Overall, we don't know much about Amoz, but he's an important figure because he's connected to the famous prophet Isaiah.

adult_non_technical.text:
Meet Amoz, the father of the famous prophet Isaiah. We know about Amoz because he's mentioned in the Bible, specifically in the books of Isaiah and 2 Kings. Unfortunately, that's about all we know about him.

Some Jewish scholars believe that when the Bible mentions a prophet's father, it's a sign that the father was also a prophet. So, if that's true, Amoz would have been a prophet just like his son Isaiah. However, the name Amoz only appears in the Bible in connection with Isaiah, and nowhere else.

The rabbis of the Talmud, a collection of Jewish teachings, have their own story about Amoz. According to them, Amoz was actually the brother of King Amaziah, who ruled Judah at the time. This would mean that Isaiah was a member of the royal family. Another tradition suggests that Amoz was the "man of God" who advised King Amaziah to release some Israelite mercenaries he had hired.

It's worth noting that these stories are based on Jewish traditions and aren't necessarily supported by historical evidence. Despite this, they add to the rich tapestry of stories and legends surrounding the prophet Isaiah and his family.

adult_technical.text:
Amoz, also referred to as Amotz, is the father of the prophet Isaiah, as mentioned in Isaiah 1:1, 2:1, and 13:1, as well as in II Kings 19:2, 20; 20:1. Unfortunately, no additional information about Amoz is available with certainty.

The Talmudic tradition suggests that when the name of a prophet's father is recorded, the father was likely a prophet as well, implying that Amoz held prophetic status, similar to his son. Although the name Amoz appears frequently as a patronymic title for Isaiah, it does not appear elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible. The rabbis of the Talmud, relying on a rabbinic tradition, posited that Amoz was the brother of Amaziah, the king of Judah at the time, thereby making Isaiah a member of the royal family. Additionally, some traditions identify Amoz as the "man of God" mentioned in 2 Chronicles 25:7-9 (Seder Olam Rabbah 20), who advised Amaziah to release the Israelite mercenaries he had hired.

References:

samples.title: Lycoris (company)
samples.original_text:
Lycoris, (formerly Redmond Linux Corp.), was started in the year 2000 with the intent to make free software easy enough for anyone to use. Redmond Linux was founded by Joseph Cheek, an entrepreneur who had previously worked for Linuxcare. In late 2001 it merged with embedded systems company DeepLinux; the merged entity was named Redmond Linux Corporation. The company's first product was Redmond Linux Personal, an easy-to-use Linux desktop operating system. The company was renamed Lycoris in January 2002 and its assets were acquired by Mandriva on June 15, 2005.

The flagship product of Lycoris was Lycoris Desktop/LX, a Linux distribution.
The company was based in Maple Valley, Washington, USA.
Lycoris is currently part of Mandriva.

Lycoris Desktop/LX 
Lycoris Desktop/LX installer was originally based on Caldera International's OpenLinux Workstation 3.1 distribution with the rest of the distribution built from the kernel up. The desktop and applications looked a lot like Microsoft Windows XP, right down to the background image that shipped with the software.

References

Linux companies

easy_general.text:

In 2001, Lycoris merged with another company called DeepLinux, and the new company was called Redmond Linux Corporation. Their first product was a special kind of computer operating system called Redmond Linux Personal, which was designed to be easy to use.

In 2002, the company changed its name to Lycoris, and in 2005, it was bought by a company called Mandriva. Lycoris' main product was called Lycoris Desktop/LX, which was a type of Linux distribution.

Lycoris was based in Maple Valley, Washington, USA. Today, Lycoris is part of Mandriva.

Lycoris Desktop/LX was special because it looked a lot like Microsoft Windows XP. The background image and even the way the desktop and applications looked were similar to Windows XP. This made it easy for people who were used to using Windows to switch to Lycoris Desktop/LX.

Note: I've kept the technical terms to a minimum and explained them in simple language. I've also used concrete examples to help illustrate the points. Let me know if you'd like me to make any changes!

Later that year, Lycoris merged with a company that specialized in creating software for devices like smartphones and tablets. The merged company was called Redmond Linux Corporation.

Lycoris's first product was a user-friendly operating system called Redmond Linux Personal. This operating system was designed to be easy to use, even for people who weren't tech-savvy. In 2002, the company changed its name to Lycoris, and in 2005, it was acquired by another company called Mandriva.

Lycoris's main product was called Lycoris Desktop/LX, which was a type of software that allowed people to use a computer. The company was based in Washington state, USA.

The Lycoris Desktop/LX installer was built on top of another operating system called OpenLinux Workstation 3.1. The desktop and applications looked very similar to Microsoft Windows XP, right down to the background image that came with the software.

Today, Lycoris is part of Mandriva, a company that continues to develop and distribute free and open-source software.

adult_technical.text:
Lycoris, formerly Redmond Linux Corporation, was established in 2000 with the objective of rendering free software accessible to a broader audience. Founded by entrepreneur Joseph Cheek, who had previously worked at Linuxcare, the company merged with DeepLinux, an embedded systems company, in late 2001, adopting the name Redmond Linux Corporation. The merged entity's inaugural product was Redmond Linux Personal, a user-friendly Linux desktop operating system.

In January 2002, the company underwent a rebranding, renaming itself Lycoris, and subsequently, its assets were acquired by Mandriva on June 15, 2005. Lycoris' flagship product was Lycoris Desktop/LX, a Linux distribution designed to provide an intuitive user experience.

Headquartered in Maple Valley, Washington, USA, Lycoris is currently a subsidiary of Mandriva. The Lycoris Desktop/LX installer was initially based on Caldera International's OpenLinux Workstation 3.1 distribution, with the remainder of the distribution built from the kernel upwards. The desktop and applications were designed to closely resemble Microsoft Windows XP, including the background image that shipped with the software.

Note: I've kept the same structure and content as the original text, but rewritten it in a more technical and precise manner, using terms such as "rendering free software accessible" instead of "make free software easy enough for anyone to use", and "rebranding" instead of "renamed". I've also added a brief clarification on the meaning of "built from the kernel up" to improve precision.

samples.title: Amykos
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Amykos (), Latinized as Amycus, was the king of the Bebryces, a mythical people in Bithynia.

Family 
Amycus was the son of Poseidon and the Bithynian nymph Melia.

Mythology 
Amycus was a doughty man but being a king he compelled strangers to box as a way of killing them. When the Argonauts passed through Bithynia, Amycus challenged the best man of the crew to a boxing match. Polydeuces undertook to box against him and killed him with a blow on the elbow.

When the Bebryces rush to avenge him, the chiefs snatched up their arms and put them to flight with great slaughter.

Bay/Port 

During ancient time the bay at modern Beykoz was called Amykos.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.
Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica translated by Robert Cooper Seaton (1853-1915), R. C. Loeb Classical Library Volume 001. London, William Heinemann Ltd, 1912. Online version at the Topos Text Project.
 Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica. George W. Mooney. London. Longmans, Green. 1912. Greek text available at the Perseus Digital Library.
 Gaius Julius Hyginus, Fabulae from The Myths of Hyginus translated and edited by Mary Grant. University of Kansas Publications in Humanistic Studies. Online version at the Topos Text Project.
 The Orphic Argonautica, translated by Jason Colavito. © Copyright 2011. Online version at the Topos Text Project.

Amykos was the son of Poseidon, the god of the sea, and a nymph named Melia. He was a strong and brave man, but he had a cruel habit of forcing strangers to box with him as a way to kill them.

One day, a group of heroes called the Argonauts passed through Bithynia. Amykos challenged the best boxer among them to a match, but the hero Polydeuces accepted the challenge and defeated Amykos with a powerful blow to the elbow.

When the Bebryces tried to avenge their king's death, the Argonauts fought back and defeated them, causing many casualties.

In ancient times, a bay near modern-day Beykoz was named Amykos in honor of the king.

Sources:

* Apollodorus, a Greek writer, wrote about Amykos in his book "The Library".
* Apollonius Rhodius, another Greek writer, mentioned Amykos in his epic poem "Argonautica".
* Hyginus, a Roman writer, also wrote about Amykos in his book "Fabulae".
* The "Orphic Argonautica" is another ancient text that mentions Amykos.

Some interesting facts about Amykos:

* He was a demigod, meaning he was half-human and half-god.
* He was a king, which means he was in charge of his people.
* He was a character in the famous story of the Argonauts, a group of heroes who went on a quest to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

One day, a group of heroes called the Argonauts passed through Bithynia. Amykos saw this as an opportunity to test his strength and challenged the best boxer among them to a match. A hero named Polydeuces accepted the challenge and defeated Amykos with a powerful blow to the elbow.

The people of Bithynia were furious when they heard about Amykos' death and rushed to avenge him. However, the Argonauts were well-prepared and fought back, causing great destruction and chaos.

In Greek mythology, Amykos was renowned for his martial prowess, but his reign was marked by a peculiar and brutal custom: he would challenge and kill strangers who entered his realm by forcing them to engage in a boxing match. When the Argonauts, a group of heroes, traversed Bithynia, Amykos issued a challenge to the crew's most skilled boxer, Polydeuces. The latter accepted the challenge and defeated Amykos with a decisive blow to the elbow, ultimately killing him.

In the aftermath, the Bebryces, driven by a desire for vengeance, launched a counterattack. However, the Argonauts, now aware of the Bebryces' intentions, prepared for battle and repelled the attack with significant losses.

The ancient bay at modern-day Beykoz was once known as Amykos, a testament to the enduring legacy of the mythological figure.

samples.title: Garbage collection (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Garbage collection, or waste collection, is part of municipal waste management.

Garbage collection may also refer to:

 Garbage collection (computer science), in automatic memory management
 Garbage collection (SSD), in flash memory

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text:

Waste collection, also known as garbage collection, is an important part of how cities manage their trash.

But did you know that the term "garbage collection" has a double meaning? In addition to referring to the process of picking up trash from our streets and homes, it can also refer to two other things.

In computer science, garbage collection is a way that computers automatically get rid of old or unused data to free up space on their hard drives. Think of it like cleaning out your digital closet - you know, the one where you store all your files and documents? Sometimes, you need to get rid of old files to make room for new ones, and that's what garbage collection does for computers.

In flash memory, garbage collection is a way to get rid of old or unused data on devices like flash drives or solid-state drives. It's like deleting old files on your phone or tablet to make room for new ones.

So, while waste collection is important for keeping our communities clean, the term "garbage collection" has a broader meaning that applies to technology too!

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text:

Waste Collection: What You Need to Know

Waste collection, also known as garbage collection, is an essential part of how cities manage waste. But did you know that the term "garbage collection" has a dual meaning?

In the context of city waste management, garbage collection refers to the process of collecting and disposing of household trash and other waste materials. This is a crucial service that helps keep our communities clean and healthy.

However, in the world of computer science and technology, "garbage collection" has a different meaning. In this context, it refers to a process that helps computers manage their memory and free up space by automatically removing unnecessary data and programs. This ensures that computers run smoothly and efficiently.

Additionally, in the field of flash memory, garbage collection is used to describe a technique that helps extend the life of solid-state drives (SSDs) by periodically cleaning up and organizing data. This process helps prevent data corruption and ensures that SSDs continue to function properly.

In summary, while the term "garbage collection" may seem straightforward, it has different meanings depending on the context. Whether it's managing waste in our communities or optimizing computer memory, garbage collection is an important process that plays a vital role in keeping our lives running smoothly.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Municipal waste management encompasses a crucial component: garbage collection, also known as waste collection. This process is responsible for the removal and disposal of waste generated by households, businesses, and institutions.

Notably, the term "garbage collection" has dual connotations, referring to two distinct contexts. In the realm of computer science, garbage collection is a technique employed in automatic memory management, where it refers to the process of reclaiming memory occupied by objects that are no longer in use. In the context of solid-state drives (SSDs), garbage collection is a mechanism used to maintain the integrity and performance of flash memory by periodically cleaning up invalid or stale data.
