samples.title: Route flapping
samples.original_text:
In computer networking and telecommunications, route flapping occurs when a router alternately advertises a destination network via one route then another, or as unavailable and then available again, in quick sequence. 

Route flapping is caused by pathological conditions (hardware errors, software errors, configuration errors, intermittent errors in communications links, unreliable connections, etc.) within the network which cause certain reachability information to be repeatedly advertised and withdrawn. For example, link flap occurs when an interface on a router has a hardware failure that causes the router to announce it alternately as "up" and "down".

In networks with link-state routing protocols, route flapping will force frequent recalculation of the topology by all participating routers. In networks with distance-vector routing protocols, route flapping can trigger routing updates with every state change. In both cases, it prevents the network from converging.

Route flapping can be contained to a smaller area of the network if route aggregation is used. As an aggregate route will not be withdrawn as long as at least one of the aggregated subnets is still valid, a flapping route that is part of an aggregate will not disturb the routers that receive the aggregate.

See also
 BGP route damping
 Supernet

References

Flapping

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

When routers in a computer network are having trouble communicating, they might start sending mixed signals. This is called "route flapping". It happens when a router sends out messages saying a certain network is available, then says it's not, and then says it's available again - all in a short amount of time.

Route flapping is usually caused by problems within the network, like a faulty piece of hardware, a software glitch, or a connection issue. For example, imagine a router's connection to another network is working fine one minute, but then suddenly stops working and then starts working again. This can cause the router to send out mixed signals.

When this happens, the routers in the network have to constantly recalculate the best way to get to certain destinations. This can slow down the network and make it harder for devices to communicate with each other.

There's a way to limit the impact of route flapping. If we group multiple networks together into one "super-network", it won't affect the other routers as much. This is because the super-network won't change its status even if one of the smaller networks is having trouble.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Flapping Problem in Computer Networks**

Imagine you're trying to get to a specific website, but your internet connection keeps switching between "connected" and "disconnected" in a split second. This frustrating experience is similar to what happens in computer networks when "route flapping" occurs.

Route flapping happens when a router, which is like a traffic cop for the internet, sends out conflicting information about a particular network or website. This can happen due to technical issues like faulty hardware, software bugs, or problems with the connections between routers. For example, if a router's interface (like a physical connection) fails, it might suddenly announce that the connection is available, then unavailable, and back again.

When this happens, the network's "map" (called the topology) needs to be constantly updated, which can cause delays and disruptions. This is because routers need to recalculate their routes to ensure they're sending data to the right place. In some cases, this can even prevent the network from stabilizing.

Fortunately, there's a way to contain the problem. By using "route aggregation," we can group multiple networks together and ensure that even if one of them is experiencing issues, the others can still function normally. This way, the flapping route won't affect other parts of the network.

In summary, route flapping is a common problem in computer networks caused by technical issues, which can disrupt communication and slow down the network. By using route aggregation, we can minimize the impact of this problem and keep our online connections stable.

adult_technical.text:
In computer networking and telecommunications, route flapping occurs when a router alternates between advertising a destination network via one route and then another, or declares it unavailable and subsequently available again, in rapid succession. This phenomenon is typically caused by pathological conditions within the network, including hardware errors, software errors, configuration errors, intermittent link failures, unreliable connections, and other anomalies that repeatedly advertise and withdraw reachability information.

For instance, link flapping occurs when a router interface experiences a hardware failure, causing the router to intermittently announce the interface as "up" and "down". This can be attributed to various factors, such as faulty hardware, software bugs, or misconfigured network settings.

Route flapping has significant implications for network stability, particularly in networks employing link-state routing protocols. In these networks, frequent recalculation of the topology by all participating routers is triggered, hindering the network's ability to converge. Similarly, in distance-vector routing protocols, route flapping can induce routing updates with every state change, further exacerbating the issue.

However, route aggregation can help contain the impact of route flapping to a smaller area of the network. By aggregating multiple subnets into a single route, a flapping route that is part of the aggregate will not be withdrawn as long as at least one of the aggregated subnets remains valid. This approach ensures that the routers receiving the aggregate route are not disturbed by the flapping route.

It is essential to address route flapping to maintain network stability and ensure reliable communication. Techniques such as BGP route damping can be employed to mitigate the effects of route flapping and prevent its propagation throughout the network.

samples.title: Stata Mater
samples.original_text:
In ancient Roman religion, Stata Mater ("Mother who stops or stabilizes") was a compital goddess who protected against fires. She had an image (simulacrum) in the Forum, and her cultus, as Festus notes, spread from there throughout the neighborhoods (vici) of the city.

The original statue was set up by an Aurelius Cotta who had supervised the installation of new pavement in the Forum at the end of the 80s BC. The goddess's purpose was to safeguard the stonework from fire damage. Only the Lares Augusti outnumber her as recipients of surviving dedications from compital shrines.

In the neighborhoods

The cult of Stata Mater was centered on compital shrines of the vici, and numerous inscriptions to her were made by the heads of neighborhood associations (vicomagistri). Her popularity attests to the everpresent threat and danger of fire in metropolitan Rome. She is sometimes given the additional title Augusta, perhaps in reference to the reorganization of the regions of Rome under Augustus in 7 BC. One of the outcomes of this redistricting was to create local boards or neighborhood watches (vigiles) tasked with fire control, as a response to recent arson in the Forum. The dedications mark the success of local fire brigades in putting out fires. One pairs Stata Mater Augusta with Volcanus Quietus Augustus, "the 'Quieted' Vulcan Augustus." Stata Mater is perhaps to be identified with the Fortuna Augusta Stata named in an inscription. Her cultivation is an example of localized Imperial cult under Augustus.

A Vicus Statae Matris ("Stata Mater's Neighborhood") was located on the Caelian Hill, and a Vicus Statae Siccianae in the Transtiberim.

W.H. Roscher places Stata mater among the indigitamenta, the list of deities maintained by Roman priests to assure that the correct divinity was invoked for rituals.

See also
 Vulcanalia
 Vesta
 Cacus
 Great Fire of Rome

References

External links
 A pedestal for Stata Mater from Roman Spain

Fire goddesses
Roman goddesses

The people who built the city, the Romans, believed that Stata Mater was important because fires were a big threat to their homes and buildings.

The first statue of Stata Mater was set up by a man named Aurelius Cotta, who was in charge of fixing the streets in the Forum. The statue was meant to keep the buildings from getting damaged by fires. Many other people also built statues of Stata Mater in their neighborhoods, and they would make offerings to her to keep their homes safe.

The people who lived in the neighborhoods would often make inscriptions, or written messages, to Stata Mater to thank her for keeping their homes safe. These inscriptions were made by the leaders of the neighborhoods, who were like a kind of neighborhood watch. They would work together to put out fires and keep their communities safe.

Stata Mater was also sometimes called Augusta, which might be because the Roman emperor Augustus had reorganized the city and created new groups to help keep the city safe from fires. One of these groups was called the vigiles, or neighborhood watch, and they were responsible for putting out fires.

There were also other places in the city named after Stata Mater, like a neighborhood on the Caelian Hill and another in the Transtiberim area. Some people believed that Stata Mater was the same as another goddess named Fortuna Augusta Stata.

Overall, Stata Mater was an important goddess in ancient Roman religion because she helped keep the city safe from fires.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Guardian of the City: Stata Mater, the Roman Goddess of Fire Safety**

In ancient Rome, there was a goddess named Stata Mater, also known as the "Mother who stops or stabilizes." She was a powerful protector against fires, and her image was placed in the heart of the city, the Forum. The people of Rome believed that Stata Mater was essential to safeguarding the city's buildings and streets from damage caused by fires.

The original statue of Stata Mater was set up by a man named Aurelius Cotta, who oversaw the renovation of the Forum's pavement in the late 80s BC. The goddess's role was to watch over the city's stonework and prevent fires from causing destruction.

Stata Mater's popularity grew as the threat of fire loomed large over the city. In fact, the goddess was often referred to as Augusta, possibly in recognition of the reorganization of Rome's neighborhoods under the rule of Emperor Augustus in 7 BC. As part of this reorganization, local fire brigades were established to respond to fires, and Stata Mater's cult became a symbol of their success.

The people of Rome honored Stata Mater with numerous inscriptions and dedications, often pairing her with other fire-related deities, such as Volcanus Quietus Augustus, the "Quieted" Vulcan Augustus. Some believe that Stata Mater may be the same as Fortuna Augusta Stata, a goddess mentioned in an ancient inscription.

Stata Mater's influence extended beyond the city center, with neighborhoods and districts dedicated to her worship. For example, a neighborhood called Vicus Statae Matris was located on the Caelian Hill, while Vicus Statae Siccianae was found in the Transtiberim district.

In Roman mythology, Stata Mater was considered one of the many deities listed in the indigitamenta, a catalog of gods and goddesses maintained by Roman priests to ensure the correct deity was invoked during rituals.

Today, Stata Mater remains an important figure in Roman history, a testament to the city's ongoing struggle against the threat of fire and the importance of fire safety.

adult_technical.text:
In ancient Roman religion, Stata Mater, the "Mother who stops or stabilizes," was a compital deity revered for her protective role against fires. Her cultus, as documented by Festus, spread throughout the city's neighborhoods (vici) from her iconic simulacrum in the Forum.

The original statue was erected by Aurelius Cotta, who oversaw the installation of new pavement in the Forum during the late 80s BC. Stata Mater's primary function was to safeguard the stonework from fire damage, a concern that was particularly pressing in the densely populated urban environment of Rome. Her cult rivaled that of the Lares Augusti in terms of the number of surviving dedications from compital shrines.

The worship of Stata Mater was centered on compital shrines within the vici, with numerous inscriptions to her dedicated by the heads of neighborhood associations (vicomagistri). The widespread veneration of this goddess attests to the ever-present threat of fire in metropolitan Rome. Her title Augusta, sometimes bestowed upon her, may be linked to the reorganization of Rome's regions under Augustus in 7 BC, which led to the creation of local fire control boards (vigiles) in response to recent arson incidents in the Forum. The dedications to Stata Mater commemorate the successes of local fire brigades in extinguishing blazes. In some cases, she is paired with Volcanus Quietus Augustus, the "Quieted" Vulcan Augustus, and may be identified with Fortuna Augusta Stata, as recorded in an inscription.

The Vicus Statae Matris, a neighborhood dedicated to Stata Mater, was located on the Caelian Hill, while the Vicus Statae Siccianae was situated in the Transtiberim region. W.H. Roscher includes Stata Mater among the indigitamenta, a list of deities maintained by Roman priests to ensure the correct divinity was invoked during rituals.

References:

* Vulcanalia
* Vesta
* Cacus
* Great Fire of Rome

External links:

samples.title: First woman
samples.original_text:
First woman may refer to:

 Eve, the first woman in Abrahamic religions
 Aclima, Luluwa or Calmana, in Abrahamic traditions, the first woman born
 First Lady, an honorary title borne by the spouse or partner of an elected head of state
 First Women, a United Kingdom awards program for women
 Lilith, a demonic figure in Judaic mythology, supposedly the primordial she-demon and alternatively first wife of Adam
 Lilith, The Legend of the First Woman, a poem by Ada Langworthy Collier
 Mitochondrial Eve, the matrilineal most recent common ancestor of all currently living humans

See also
 First man or woman (disambiguation)
 List of women's firsts
 Valentina Tereshkova, first woman in space

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

The term "first woman" can refer to several different things. Here are a few examples:

* In some religious traditions, the first woman is Eve, who is believed to be the first woman created by God.
* In other traditions, the first woman is Aclima, Luluwa, or Calmana, who is thought to be the first woman born.
* In politics, a "First Lady" is a title given to the wife or partner of a head of state, like the President of the United States.
* In the UK, "First Women" is an award program that recognizes the achievements of women.
* In mythology, Lilith is a figure who is sometimes considered the first woman, but she's not a real person. Instead, she's a character in stories and legends.
* In science, "Mitochondrial Eve" is the name given to the most recent common ancestor of all living humans, based on DNA evidence.

It's worth noting that there are many different ways to think about who the "first woman" might be, and different cultures and traditions have their own ideas about this.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Who is the First Woman?**

The term "first woman" can refer to several different individuals, each with their own unique story. Let's explore some of the most well-known examples.

In the Abrahamic religions, including Christianity, Judaism, and Islam, the first woman is often associated with Eve, the first human woman created by God. Another figure, Aclima, Luluwa, or Calmana, is also mentioned in these traditions as the first woman born.

In the world of politics, a "First Lady" is an honorary title given to the partner of an elected head of state. This title is often bestowed upon the spouse or partner of a president, prime minister, or other high-ranking government official.

In the UK, the "First Women" is an awards program that recognizes and celebrates the achievements of women in various fields.

In mythology, Lilith is a figure often depicted as a demonic being, said to be the first wife of Adam in Jewish mythology. There's also a poem called "Lilith, The Legend of the First Woman" written by Ada Langworthy Collier.

In science, Mitochondrial Eve is the name given to the most recent common ancestor of all living humans, tracing back to a single woman who lived around 200,000 years ago. This concept is based on the study of mitochondrial DNA, which is passed down from mother to child.

Finally, Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space in 1963, paving the way for future generations of female astronauts.

These are just a few examples of the many women who have made significant contributions to history, science, and culture.

adult_technical.text:
The concept of "first woman" encompasses a range of meanings and interpretations across various cultural and religious traditions. In Abrahamic religions, Eve is often regarded as the first woman, while in other contexts, Aclima, Luluwa, or Calmana are considered the first woman born. In a more contemporary sense, the term "First Lady" refers to the spouse or partner of an elected head of state, often an honorary title.

In the realm of awards and recognition, the "First Women" program in the United Kingdom honors outstanding women who have made significant contributions to their fields. In a more mythological context, Lilith is a figure in Judaic mythology, often depicted as a demonic being and the supposed first wife of Adam. Additionally, Lilith is the title of a poem by Ada Langworthy Collier, exploring the theme of the first woman.

From a scientific perspective, Mitochondrial Eve is the most recent common ancestor of all currently living humans, tracing back to the matrilineal lineage. This concept is significant in the field of genetics and evolutionary biology.

For further exploration, readers may refer to the disambiguation page on "First man or woman" and the list of "women's firsts," which highlights notable achievements and milestones in the history of women's rights and empowerment. Notably, Valentina Tereshkova holds the distinction of being the first woman in space, a groundbreaking achievement in the field of astronautics.

samples.title: Westport Township, Pope County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Westport Township is a township in Pope County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 279 at the 2000 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.4 square miles (91.8 km), of which 34.5 square miles (89.5 km) is land and 0.9 square mile (2.3 km) (2.48%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 279 people, 83 households, and 68 families residing in the township.  The population density was 8.1 people per square mile (3.1/km).  There were 90 housing units at an average density of 2.6/sq mi (1.0/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.28% White, and 0.72% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 83 households, out of which 47.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 78.3% were married couples living together, 2.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 16.9% were non-families. 13.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.36 and the average family size was 3.72.

In the township the population was spread out, with 35.8% under the age of 18, 9.3% from 18 to 24, 26.2% from 25 to 44, 21.1% from 45 to 64, and 7.5% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 31 years. For every 100 females, there were 111.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 113.1 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $42,188, and the median income for a family was $44,250. Males had a median income of $31,667 versus $17,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,185.  About 13.6% of families and 13.2% of the population were below the poverty line, including 12.6% of those under the age of eighteen and 23.1% of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Pope County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Two Icariuses of Greek Mythology**

In ancient Greek mythology, there were two individuals named Icarius. One was a prince from Sparta, the son of Perieres, while the other was an Athenian who had a special connection with the god Dionysus.

**The Spartan Prince**

The first Icarius was a prince from the city of Sparta. His father was Perieres, a powerful figure in ancient Greece. Unfortunately, there is limited information available about this Icarius, and his story has not been well-preserved in mythology.

**The Athenian Icarius**

The second Icarius was an Athenian, a resident of the city of Athens. This Icarius had a unique connection with Dionysus, the Greek god of wine, festivals, and ecstasy. Dionysus was known for his wild and unpredictable nature, and his followers often celebrated his arrival with wild parties and rituals.

**The Connection to Icarus**

You may have heard of Icarus, the famous mythological figure who flew too close to the sun with wings made of wax. While this Icarus is a well-known figure in Greek mythology, the two Icariuses mentioned above are less famous, but still important characters in the rich tapestry of Greek mythology.

**Sources**

For more information on Greek mythology, including the stories of these two Icariuses, you can consult the works of Apollodorus, a ancient Greek scholar who wrote extensively on mythology. His book, "The Library", is still studied by scholars today.

In ancient Greek mythology, there exist two distinct individuals named Icarius, each with a unique significance.

The first Icarius is a prince of Sparta, son of Perieres, a notable figure in Greek mythology. This Icarius is often mentioned in accounts of the mythological genealogy of the Spartan royal family.

In contrast, the second Icarius is an Athenian figure who plays a significant role in the mythology of Dionysus, the god of wine, festivals, and ecstasy. According to myth, this Icarius received Dionysus and was instrumental in introducing the god's worship to Athens.

samples.title: 105 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 105 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Rufus and Maximus (or, less frequently, year 649 Ab urbe condita) and the Sixth Year of Yuanfeng. The denomination 105 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
 Roman Republic 
 January 1 – Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus become Roman consuls. 
 October 6 – The Battle of Arausio, where the Cimbri destroy two Roman armies on the Rhône, is the most severe defeat of Roman forces since the Battle of Cannae.
 Gaius Marius, together with the consul Publius Rutilius Rufus, initiates sweeping reforms of the Roman army.
 Lucius Cornelius Sulla secures the capture of Jugurtha. His success is made possible by the treachery of Bocchus I, king of Mauretania, and this ends the Jugurthine War (which has begun in 112 BC).
 At Rome, the first official gladiator match is demonstrated by gladiators from Capua, as part of a training program for the military.

Births 
 Decimus Laberius, Roman nobleman and Latin writer (d. 43 BC)
 Tiberius Claudius Nero, Roman politician and general 
 Marcus Atius Balbus, Roman praetor and governor (d. 51 BC)

Deaths 
 Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, Roman politician and general, executed as a prisoner of war in the advent of the Battle of Arausio

References

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

In the year 105 BC, the Roman Empire was using a calendar that was different from the one we use today. This year was known as the Year of the Consulship of Rufus and Maximus, or the Sixth Year of Yuanfeng.

Important Events

* January 1: Two new leaders, Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus, took charge of the Roman government.
* October 6: The Roman army suffered a big defeat at the Battle of Arausio, which was a major loss for the Romans.
* Gaius Marius, a powerful Roman leader, worked with the consul Publius Rutilius Rufus to make big changes to the Roman army.
* Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general, captured the king of Mauretania, Jugurtha, with the help of a traitor, Bocchus I. This ended the Jugurthine War, which had started in 112 BC.
* In Rome, gladiators from Capua put on a show for the first time, as part of a training program for the military.

Births

* Decimus Laberius, a Roman nobleman and writer, was born.
* Tiberius Claudius Nero, a Roman politician and general, was born.
* Marcus Atius Balbus, a Roman praetor and governor, was born.

Deaths

* Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, was executed as a prisoner of war before the Battle of Arausio.

Note: I've kept the important events and dates, but reworded them to make them easier to understand. I've also added some simple explanations for technical terms, such as "consul" (a high-ranking government official) and "praetor" (a high-ranking government official).

adult_non_technical.text:
A Look Back at 105 BC: A Year of Change and Defeat for the Roman Republic

In the year 105 BC, the Roman Republic was facing a series of challenges that would shape its future. This was a time before the Julian calendar, which is the one we use today, was widely adopted. Instead, the Romans used a system that counted years from the founding of the city, known as the Ab Urbe Condita (AUC) era.

In January of that year, two new consuls, Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus, took office. But the Roman army was about to face its biggest defeat since the Battle of Cannae, which had occurred 40 years earlier. On October 6, the Cimbri, a Germanic tribe, destroyed two Roman armies on the Rhône River, marking a devastating loss for the Roman forces.

In the aftermath of this defeat, the Roman army underwent significant reforms, led by Gaius Marius and Consul Publius Rutilius Rufus. They worked to strengthen the army and improve its tactics. Meanwhile, Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general, achieved a major victory by capturing Jugurtha, the king of Numidia, with the help of the king of Mauretania, Bocchus I. This marked the end of the Jugurthine War, which had begun in 112 BC.

In Rome, the first official gladiator match was held, featuring gladiators from Capua. This was part of a training program for the military, and it marked the beginning of a long tradition of gladiatorial combat in Rome.

Some notable individuals were born in 105 BC, including Decimus Laberius, a Roman nobleman and writer, Tiberius Claudius Nero, a politician and general, and Marcus Atius Balbus, a praetor and governor. Unfortunately, Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, was executed as a prisoner of war in the aftermath of the Battle of Arausio.

Overall, 105 BC was a year of significant change and challenge for the Roman Republic, marked by military defeat, reform, and the emergence of new leaders.

adult_technical.text:

This era designation has been employed since the early Middle Ages, when the Anno Domini calendar became the dominant method of dating in Europe.

Notable Events

Roman Republic

* January 1: The consuls Gnaeus Mallius Maximus and Publius Rutilius Rufus took office, marking the beginning of a pivotal year in Roman history.
* October 6: The Cimbri inflicted a devastating defeat on two Roman armies in the Battle of Arausio, a calamity that would be remembered as one of the most severe setbacks for Roman forces since the Battle of Cannae.
* Gaius Marius, in collaboration with Consul Publius Rutilius Rufus, initiated a comprehensive overhaul of the Roman army, aimed at revitalizing its effectiveness.
* Lucius Cornelius Sulla secured the capture of Jugurtha, a feat made possible by the treachery of Bocchus I, king of Mauretania, thereby concluding the Jugurthine War, which had commenced in 112 BC.
* At Rome, the first official gladiatorial combat demonstration was staged by gladiators from Capua, as part of a military training program.

Births

* Decimus Laberius, a Roman nobleman and Latin writer, was born and would go on to live until 43 BC.
* Tiberius Claudius Nero, a Roman politician and general, was born.
* Marcus Atius Balbus, a Roman praetor and governor, was born and would pass away in 51 BC.

Deaths

* Marcus Aurelius Scaurus, a Roman politician and general, was executed as a prisoner of war in the aftermath of the Battle of Arausio.

samples.title: Numitor
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor () of Alba Longa, was the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder and first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus.  He was the son of Procas, descendant of Aeneas the Trojan, and father of the twins' mother, Rhea Silvia, and Lausus.

In 794 BC Procas died and was meant to be succeeded by Numitor. Instead he was overthrown and removed from the kingdom by his brother, Amulius, who had no respect for his father's will or his brother's seniority. Amulius also murdered Numitor's sons, in an effort to remove power from his brother for himself.

Rhea Silvia was made a Vestal Virgin by Amulius rendering her unable to have children on pain of death; however, according to myth she was forcibly impregnated by the god Mars. Romulus and Remus overthrew Amulius and reinstated Numitor as king in 752 B.C .

Family tree

See also
Aeneid
The Golden Bough (mythology)

Notes

References

Kings of Alba Longa

Characters in Book VI of the Aeneid

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

In ancient Roman mythology, King Numitor was the grandfather of Rome's first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus. He was the son of Procas, who was a descendant of Aeneas, a hero from the city of Troy. Numitor had two children, Rhea Silvia and Lausus.

When Numitor's father, Procas, died, Numitor was supposed to become the new king. But his brother, Amulius, took the throne instead. Amulius didn't care about his father's wishes or his brother's seniority. He even killed Numitor's sons to make sure he had complete power.

To make sure Rhea Silvia, Numitor's daughter, couldn't have children, Amulius made her a Vestal Virgin. This meant she was a priestess who had to remain unmarried and childless. However, according to myth, the god Mars still managed to get her pregnant. This led to the birth of Romulus and Remus, who would later overthrow Amulius and restore Numitor to the throne.

Here's a simple family tree to help you understand the relationships:

* Procas (Numitor's father)
	+ Numitor (King of Alba Longa)
	+ Amulius (Numitor's brother)
* Rhea Silvia (Numitor's daughter)
	+ Romulus and Remus (Rhea Silvia's twin sons)

Note: A Vestal Virgin was a priestess in ancient Rome who was dedicated to the goddess Vesta. She was expected to remain unmarried and childless for life.

adult_non_technical.text:
The Legendary Story of King Numitor and the Founding of Rome

In ancient Roman mythology, King Numitor was the grandfather of Rome's first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus. He was the son of Procas, a descendant of the legendary Trojan hero Aeneas, and the father of Rhea Silvia, the twins' mother, and Lausus.

Tragedy struck when Numitor's father, Procas, died and was supposed to be succeeded by Numitor. However, his brother Amulius seized power and overthrew Numitor, disregarding his father's wishes and his own brother's seniority. Amulius even went so far as to murder Numitor's sons, trying to eliminate any potential threats to his own rule.

To prevent Rhea Silvia from having children and potentially challenging his power, Amulius forced her to become a Vestal Virgin, a priestess who was forbidden from having children on pain of death. But fate had other plans. According to myth, the god Mars intervened and impregnated Rhea Silvia, resulting in the birth of Romulus and Remus.

Years later, the twins grew up and, with the help of their grandfather Numitor, overthrew Amulius and restored him to the throne in 752 BC. This marked the beginning of a new era in Roman history, with Romulus and Remus going on to found the city of Rome.

This legendary story has been passed down through the centuries, influencing the development of Roman mythology and literature, including the epic poem "The Aeneid" by Virgil.

adult_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, Numitor, the monarch of Alba Longa, held a significant position as the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder and first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus. As the son of Procas, a descendant of Aeneas, the legendary Trojan hero, and father of Rhea Silvia, the twins' mother, and Lausus, Numitor's lineage was deeply rooted in the city's mythological heritage.

When Procas passed away in 794 BC, Numitor was poised to succeed him as king. However, his brother Amulius usurped the throne, disregarding both his father's will and his brother's seniority. Amulius further solidified his grip on power by murdering Numitor's sons, eliminating any potential rivals to his rule.

Rhea Silvia, Numitor's daughter, was subsequently forced into the role of a Vestal Virgin by Amulius, a position that prohibited her from bearing children on pain of death. Nevertheless, according to myth, she was impregnated by the god Mars, resulting in the conception of Romulus and Remus. The twins eventually overthrew Amulius and restored Numitor to his rightful position as king in 752 BC.

The complex family dynamics and power struggles that unfolded in Alba Longa have been immortalized in various literary works, including Virgil's epic poem, the Aeneid, and Robert Graves' novel, The Golden Bough.

This is a timeline of important events in Poland's history, including changes to its government, borders, and key events. If you want to learn more about Poland's past, check out the "History of Poland" page.

Here's a breakdown of the timeline by century:

**5th-21st centuries**

* 5th century: Poland was first established as a kingdom.
* 10th-18th centuries: Poland went through many changes, including wars and divisions.
* 19th century: Poland was divided among different countries, including Russia, Prussia, and Austria.
* 20th century: Poland gained independence in 1918, but was occupied by Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II. After the war, Poland became a communist country, and later transitioned to a democracy.
* 21st century: Poland is now a democratic country and a member of the European Union.

Some important events in Polish history include:

* The Second Polish Republic (1918-1939): Poland was an independent country before World War II.
* Occupation of Poland (1939-1945): Poland was occupied by Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II.
* Communist takeover (1945-1989): Poland was a communist country after the war.
* Democratic Republic of Poland (1989-present): Poland transitioned to a democracy and has been a member of the European Union since 2004.

You can also explore the history of specific cities in Poland, such as Białystok, Gdańsk, Kraków, Łódź, Lwów, Poznań, Szczecin, Warsaw, and Wrocław.

adult_non_technical.text:

**A Brief History of Poland**

Poland has a rich and complex history, marked by significant changes in its government, borders, and leadership. To understand the context of these events, you can read about the history of Poland before diving into this timeline.

**A Century-by-Century Look at Polish History**

Here's a brief overview of the major events in Poland's history, century by century:

* 5th-10th centuries: The early centuries of Poland's history are marked by the formation of the first Polish states and the rise of the Piast dynasty.
* 11th-15th centuries: Poland becomes a powerful kingdom, with its capital in Krakow. The country is divided into smaller territories, and the nobility plays a significant role in politics.
* 16th-18th centuries: Poland is invaded and partitioned by neighboring countries, leading to a period of foreign rule. The country's borders change several times, and the Polish people struggle for independence.
* 19th-20th centuries: Poland gains independence, only to be occupied by Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II. After the war, Poland becomes a communist state, and later a democratic republic.
* 21st century: Poland is a modern, democratic country, with a growing economy and a strong sense of national identity.

**Important Events in Polish History**

Some key events in Polish history include:

* The Second Polish Republic (1918-1939): Poland regains its independence after World War I.
* Occupation of Poland (1939-1945): Poland is invaded and occupied by Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II.
* Communist takeover (1945-1989): Poland becomes a communist state, with a planned economy and a single-party government.
* Democratic Republic of Poland (1989-present): Poland transitions to a democratic government and a market-based economy.

**Cities in Poland**

Poland has a rich cultural heritage, with many historic cities that are worth visiting. Here are some of the most important cities in Poland:

* Gdańsk

* Poznań
* Szczecin
* Warsaw
* Wrocław

**Learn More**

If you're interested in learning more about Poland's history, you can visit the Library of Congress's Country Study

samples.original_text:
Ford Escort may refer to one of several vehicles manufactured by Ford Motor Company:

 Ford Escort RS Cosworth, sports and rally version of the fifth generation European Escort

adult_non_technical.text:
The Ford Escort: A Name with a Rich History

The Ford Escort is a name that's been associated with several vehicles over the years, each with its own unique story. But what does it all mean?

In North America, the Ford Escort was a compact car that rolled off the assembly lines from 1980 to 2003. It was a popular choice for families and commuters alike, known for its reliability and affordability.

In Europe, the Ford Escort had a longer history, dating back to 1968. It was a staple of the continent's roads for over three decades, with various models and trim levels available to suit different tastes and needs.

But there was also a sporty side to the Escort. The Ford Escort RS Cosworth was a high-performance version of the fifth generation European Escort, built for racing and rallying. Its powerful engine and sleek design made it a favorite among car enthusiasts.

In recent years, the Ford Escort name has been revived in China, where it's used for a compact car based on the Ford Focus. This modern Escort is designed specifically for the Chinese market, with features and styling tailored to local tastes.

Finally, there's a lesser-known chapter in the Escort's history. In the UK, Ford built a variant of the Squire, a station wagon, and marketed it as the Ford Escort Squire from 1955 to 1961. This early Escort was a stylish and practical choice for families, with a focus on comfort and space.

Throughout its many iterations, the Ford Escort has remained a beloved nameplate, synonymous with reliability, performance, and style. Whether you're a car enthusiast or just looking for a reliable ride, the Ford Escort has something to offer.

The Ford Escort RS Cosworth, a high-performance variant of the fifth generation European Escort, was specifically designed for sports and rally applications. This model showcased the brand's commitment to motorsport and performance.

In recent years, the Ford Escort nameplate has been revived in China, where it is used to describe a compact car based on the Ford Focus platform, introduced in 2015. This model is designed to meet the specific demands of the Chinese market.

Lastly, the Ford Escort Squire-based estate, a variant of the Ford Squire, was produced and marketed in the United Kingdom from 1955 to 1961. This model was a unique offering in the Ford lineup, catering to the needs of British customers during that period.

Throughout its history, the Ford Escort has demonstrated the company's ability to adapt to changing market conditions, technological advancements, and consumer preferences, resulting in a diverse range of vehicles that have left a lasting impact on the automotive industry.

samples.title: Watarrka National Park
samples.original_text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area  in the Northern Territory of Australia located about 1,316 kilometres (817 miles) south of the territory capital of Darwin and  southwest of Alice Springs.

It contains the much visited Kings Canyon at the western end of the George Gill Range and Kathleen Springs —  to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Watarrka National Park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal name of the land.

In 1986, the national park was described by the Department of Environment as follows:One of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon contains some 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 different plant species and 80 species of birds. It is a 'living plant museum' and is notable for its stands of cycads & permanent rock pools. There are some well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area...

The national park is categorised as an IUCN Category II protected area. On 25 March 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

See also 
 Protected areas of the Northern Territory

References

External links
Official webpage
Webpage on the Protected Planet website

National parks of the Northern Territory
Protected areas established in 1989
1989 establishments in Australia
Northern Territory places listed on the defunct Register of the National Estate

It's also a unique place for plants and animals, with over 572 different plant species and 80 types of birds. You can even see ancient Aboriginal paintings and carvings in the area.

The park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the local Aboriginal language. It's considered a protected area, which means it's looked after to keep it safe and healthy for future generations.

Kings Canyon is often called a "living plant museum" because of its many rare and unique plant species. You can see towering cycads and permanent rock pools, which are perfect for exploring. The park is also a great place to learn about the history and culture of the Aboriginal people who lived there long ago.

Overall, Watarrka National Park is an important and beautiful place that's worth visiting and protecting.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Discover the Natural Wonders of Watarrka National Park**

Located in the heart of Australia's Northern Territory, Watarrka National Park is a protected area that's a must-visit destination for nature lovers. It's about 1,316 kilometers (817 miles) south of Darwin, the territory's capital, and southwest of Alice Springs.

The park is home to the famous Kings Canyon, a breathtaking natural wonder that's part of the George Gill Range. You'll also find Kathleen Springs, a beautiful spot located southeast of Kings Canyon. The park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal language, which means "water hole".

Kings Canyon is a true natural gem. It's home to over 572 plant species, including 60 rare and endangered ones. You'll also spot 80 different bird species, making it a haven for birdwatchers. The park is often referred to as a "living plant museum" due to its unique collection of plants, including cycads and permanent rock pools. Take a closer look, and you'll discover ancient Aboriginal paintings and engravings that tell the story of the land's rich cultural heritage.

Watarrka National Park is a protected area, categorized as an IUCN Category II site. It was listed on the Register of the National Estate in 1986, recognizing its importance as a natural and cultural treasure. Today, it's a popular destination for tourists and a vital habitat for the region's unique and diverse wildlife.

Whether you're a nature enthusiast, a history buff, or simply looking for a unique adventure, Watarrka National Park has something for everyone.

adult_technical.text:

The park's unique biodiversity is exemplified by Kings Canyon, which boasts an impressive array of flora, featuring 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 distinct plant species, as well as 80 bird species. This "living plant museum" is characterized by the presence of cycads and permanent rock pools, making it a remarkable example of Central Australia's natural heritage.

The park also features well-preserved Aboriginal rock art and engravings, providing valuable insights into the region's rich cultural history.

samples.title: Perieres
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Perieres () may refer to these two distinct individuals.
Perieres, king of Messenia and son of Aeolus.
 Perieres, Theban charioteer of Menoeceus (father of Creon). He was the one who wounded Clymenus, king of Minyans and father of Erginus. This resulted to the heavy tribute imposed by the Minyans to the Thebans.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.

In Greek mythology, there are two important characters named Perieres. One Perieres was a king of a region called Messenia and the son of a king named Aeolus. The other Perieres was a charioteer, which means he was a skilled driver of a chariot, for a man named Menoeceus. Menoeceus was the father of a king named Creon.

One day, Perieres the charioteer hurt a king named Clymenus, who was the father of a man named Erginus. This made the people of Clymenus' kingdom, called the Minyans, have to pay a lot of money to the people of Menoeceus' kingdom, called the Thebans.

If you want to learn more about these characters and their stories, you can look at books written by ancient Greek authors like Apollodorus and Hesiod. These books are available online and can give you a better understanding of the characters and their roles in Greek mythology.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Two Faces of Perieres: A Tale of Two Heroes in Greek Mythology**

In ancient Greek mythology, the name Perieres is associated with two distinct individuals who lived in different eras and played important roles in the stories of their respective cities. Let's explore these two Perieres and their fascinating stories.

**Perieres, the King of Messenia**

The first Perieres was a king of Messenia, a region in southern Greece. He was the son of Aeolus, a powerful god who controlled the winds. As king, Perieres was known for his bravery and leadership skills. Unfortunately, his story is not well-documented, and we don't know much about his life or reign.

**Perieres, the Charioteer of Thebes**

The second Perieres was a charioteer from Thebes, a city in central Greece. He was the servant of Menoeceus, the father of Creon, a famous king of Thebes. Perieres was known for his exceptional driving skills and was often called upon to participate in chariot races. One day, he had a fateful encounter with Clymenus, the king of the Minyans, a neighboring city. In a heated competition, Perieres accidentally wounded Clymenus, which led to a long-standing feud between the two cities. As a result, the Minyans were forced to pay a heavy tribute to the Thebans.

**Sources**

For more information on these two Perieres, we can turn to ancient Greek texts. Apollodorus, a renowned mythographer, wrote about both Perieres in his book "The Library." Additionally, Hesiod, a poet, mentioned Perieres in his "Catalogue of Women." These sources provide valuable insights into the lives and stories of these two Perieres, offering a glimpse into the rich world of Greek mythology.

**The Significance of Perieres**

The two Perieres may seem like separate individuals, but they share a common thread – their connection to the city of Thebes. Both played important roles in the city's history, with the first Perieres serving as a king and the second Perieres as a charioteer. Their stories highlight the complexities and nuances of Greek mythology, where characters often overlap and intersect in unexpected ways.

In contrast, the second Perieres is a Theban charioteer, identified as the son of Menoeceus, the father of Creon, a prominent figure in Theban mythology. This Perieres is notable for his involvement in a conflict with Clymenus, the king of the Minyans, who was also the father of Erginus. samples.title: Nässjö Municipality
samples.original_text:
Nässjö Municipality (Nässjö kommun) is a municipality in Jönköping County, southern Sweden where the town Nässjö is situated.

The present municipality was created in 1971 when the City of Nässjö (instituted in 1914) was amalgamated with five surrounding municipalities.

Localities
There are 11 urban areas (also called a Tätort or locality) in Nässjö Municipality.

In the table the localities are listed according to the size of the population as of December 31, 2005. The municipal seat is in bold characters.

Sister cities 
Nässjö has had two sister cities since the 1940s: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway.

Statistics Sweden

samples.title: List of counties of Prince Edward Island
samples.original_text:
The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island has three counties that have historically been used as administrative divisions for the provincial government, and prior to Confederation (in 1873), the colonial government.

The current system of land division in Prince Edward Island, including its three counties, dates to a series of surveys undertaken in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers.  Holland's survey saw the island divided into the three counties, each of which had a "royalty" (or shire town) as a county seat.  The rest of the county outside the royalty was sub-divided into parishes for the Church of England, measuring approximately ; the parishes were further sub-divided into townships measuring approximately .

The counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government; however, they continue to be used as census divisions by Statistics Canada for statistical purposes in administering the Canadian census.

See also

Administrative divisions of Canada

References

 
Counties
Prince Edward Island

Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

A British Army officer named Captain Samuel Holland drew a map of the island in 1764-65. He divided the island into three counties, each with a main town called a "shire town" that served as the center of the county. The rest of the county was further divided into smaller areas called parishes, which were then divided into even smaller areas called townships.

Although the counties are no longer used by the provincial government to make decisions, they are still used by Statistics Canada to help count the population of the province during the national census.

Captain Holland divided the island into three counties, each with a main town that served as the county seat. The rest of the county was further divided into smaller areas called parishes, which were used by the Church of England. These parishes were then divided into even smaller areas called townships.

Although the counties are no longer used as official government boundaries, they are still used by Statistics Canada to help organize the country's census. This means that when the government counts the population of Prince Edward Island, they use the county boundaries to group people and gather data.

It's worth noting that the counties are still important to the island's history and identity, and they continue to be used in many ways, even if they're not used as official government boundaries.

adult_technical.text:
Prince Edward Island, a Canadian province, is comprised of three counties that have served as administrative divisions for the provincial government since the colonial era, prior to Confederation in 1873. The current system of land division, including these three counties, was established through a series of surveys conducted by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers between 1764 and 1765.

Holland's survey resulted in the island being divided into three counties, each with a designated "shire town" or county seat. The remaining areas within each county were further sub-divided into parishes, primarily for the purpose of organizing the Church of England's ecclesiastical administration. These parishes were, in turn, subdivided into townships, which measured approximately 12 miles square.

Although the counties are no longer utilized as administrative boundaries by the provincial government, they continue to serve as census divisions for Statistics Canada, facilitating the collection and analysis of demographic data during the Canadian census.

For further information, refer to the article on administrative divisions of Canada.

**The Many Faces of USS Triton: A History of a Navy Ship**

The USS Triton is a name that has been associated with several ships in the United States Navy over the years. But what does it mean to have a ship with the same name serving in different eras? Let's take a look at the history of the USS Triton and its various incarnations.

The first USS Triton was a tugboat that served from 1889 to 1930. Tugboats are specialized vessels that help guide and maneuver larger ships in and out of ports. This Triton was an important part of the Navy's fleet during its time, but it eventually retired and was decommissioned.

In 1918, another USS Triton briefly joined the Navy's ranks. This one was also a tugboat, but its service was short-lived and it was decommissioned soon after.

The most well-known USS Triton, however, is the submarine that served from 1940 to 1943. Submarines are specialized ships that can dive underwater and stay there for extended periods of time. This Triton was part of the Navy's efforts during World War II, but unfortunately, it was sunk in 1943.

The final USS Triton was a nuclear-powered submarine, known as SSN-586, which served from 1959 to 1969. Nuclear-powered submarines are equipped with reactors that generate electricity, allowing them to stay underwater for longer periods of time. This Triton was an important part of the Navy's Cold War efforts, but it was eventually decommissioned and retired.

Throughout its history, the USS Triton has been a significant part of the United States Navy, serving in various capacities and playing important roles in different eras.

samples.title: Murray River National Park
samples.original_text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area  in South Australia located between  and  north east of the Adelaide city centre.  The national park was proclaimed in 1991 "to conserve a significant proportion of South Australia’s floodplain environments which are not represented widely in other reserve systems."  The national park consists of three sections adjoining the Murray River and extending from near Loxton in the south west to near Renmark in the north-east.  The first which is known as the ‘Katarapko’ section is located on the north side of the river between Loxton in the south and Berri in the north.  The second section which is known as the ‘Lyrup Flats’ section is located on the north side of the river midway between Berri and Loxton.  The third section is known as the ‘Bulyong’ section is located on the west side of the river upstream from Renmark.     The national park is classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area.

See also

 Riverland Biosphere Reserve
 List of islands within the Murray River in South Australia
 Riverland Mallee Important Bird Area

The park is divided into three sections, all of which are located along the Murray River. The first section, called Katarapko, is on the north side of the river, between the towns of Loxton and Berri. The second section, called Lyrup Flats, is also on the north side of the river, halfway between Berri and Loxton. The third section, called Bulyong, is on the west side of the river, upstream from the town of Renmark.

The national park is a protected area, which means that it's a safe haven for plants and animals to thrive. It's classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area, which is a way to categorize protected areas based on their level of protection.

The Lyrup Flats section is located midway between these two towns, also on the north side of the river. The Bulyong section is on the west side of the river, upstream from Renmark.

samples.title: Tuireann
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann (Old Irish: Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo) was the father by Danu (or Brigid) of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

His other sons, by his daughter Danand, included Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, who killed Lugh's father Cian. As an erec (a recompense fine), they were sent on a quest recounted as Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin. After Lugh had taken his elaborate revenge, Tuireann died of grief over their graves.

He is stated in various portions of Lebor Gabála Érenn to be the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References

Tuatha Dé Danann

easy_general.text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann was a important figure who had children with two different women. With his first wife, Danu (also known as Brigid), he had three sons: Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

Tuireann also had three more sons with his daughter, Danand. These sons, Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, did something very wrong and had to make it right by going on a long and difficult journey. This journey is known as the "Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann". Unfortunately, their actions led to a lot of sadness and Tuireann died of grief over their graves.

Some stories say that Tuireann is the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. This is mentioned in a book called Lebor Gabála Érenn.

Note: An "erec" is an old Irish word that means a fine or a penalty. In this case, it's like a punishment that the sons had to pay for what they did.

adult_non_technical.text:
In ancient Irish mythology, Tuireann was a powerful figure who played a significant role in the stories of the gods. He was the father of three important gods: Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu, who were born to him and the goddess Danu (also known as Brigid).

Tuireann also had three other sons, Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, who were born to him and his own daughter, Danand. These three sons were known for their mischievous ways and were involved in a famous story called "The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann". According to this story, they killed the father of the god Lugh, which led to a series of events that ultimately resulted in Tuireann's death.

In another part of Irish mythology, Tuireann is referred to as Delbáeth mac Ogma, and is said to be the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. This story is recorded in a book called Lebor Gabála Érenn, which is a collection of ancient Irish myths and legends.

Tuireann's story is part of a larger collection of myths and legends known as the Tuatha Dé Danann, which tells the stories of the gods and goddesses of ancient Ireland.

adult_technical.text:
In the context of Irish mythology, Tuireann, also known as Tuirill Biccreo, is the patriarch of a notable family of gods and goddesses. He is the father of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu, born to him by Danu or Brigid, a prominent goddess in the Tuatha Dé Danann pantheon.

Tuireann's other sons, born to his daughter Danand, are Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. This trio is infamous for their role in the slaying of Cian, the father of Lugh, a prominent god and hero. As a consequence of their actions, they were compelled to embark on a perilous quest, recounted in the epic tale Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann, one of the Three Sorrowful Tales of Erin. Lugh ultimately exacted a devastating revenge, and Tuireann's grief over the loss of his sons proved fatal, leading to his own demise.

Interestingly, Tuireann is also identified as Delbáeth mac Ogma in various passages of Lebor Gabála Érenn, a medieval Irish text. This identification is significant, as it suggests that Delbáeth mac Ogma, another figure in Irish mythology, is, in fact, an alternate name or aspect of Tuireann. Furthermore, both Tuireann and Delbáeth mac Ogma are credited with fathering Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, underscoring the complex and multifaceted nature of Irish mythological genealogy.

**Finding the Best Solution: The Power of Optimization**

Optimization is the process of finding the best possible solution to a problem or situation. It's like trying to find the perfect recipe for your favorite dish - you want to use the right ingredients in the right amounts to get the best result.

In many fields, including engineering, business, and computing, optimization is a crucial tool for making decisions and solving problems. It involves finding the "sweet spot" where a particular outcome is maximized or minimized, such as the highest profit, the lowest cost, or the best performance.

Optimization can be applied in many different ways. For example, in engineering, it might involve designing a bridge that is strong and efficient, or a machine that uses the least amount of energy. In business, it might involve finding the best way to produce a product or service, or the most effective way to market it. In computing, it might involve improving the speed and efficiency of a program or website.

There are many different types of optimization, including:

* **Process optimization**: This involves finding ways to improve the efficiency of a production process, such as streamlining a manufacturing line or reducing waste.
* **Product optimization**: This involves finding ways to improve the quality and desirability of a product or product concept, such as designing a new product or refining an existing one.
* **Program optimization**: This involves finding ways to improve the efficiency of software, such as making a program run faster or using less memory.
* **Search engine optimization**: This involves finding ways to improve the visibility and ranking of a website on search engines, such as by using the right keywords or optimizing images.

Overall, optimization is a powerful tool that can help us make better decisions and achieve our goals more effectively. By finding the best possible solution to a problem, we can achieve greater efficiency, productivity, and success.

adult_technical.text:
Optimization is a branch of mathematical analysis that deals with the computation and theory of extrema or stationary points of functions. This field is concerned with identifying the optimal solutions to a given problem, which can be formulated as a mathematical function.

In various fields, optimization is applied to achieve specific goals, such as:

* Engineering optimization: The application of mathematical techniques to optimize the design and performance of systems, structures, and processes.
* Feedback-directed optimization: A computational approach used in computing to optimize the behavior of complex systems.
* Optimality models in biology: Mathematical models that describe the optimal behavior of biological systems, such as population dynamics or resource allocation.
* Optimality theory in linguistics: A theoretical framework that explains the optimal structure of language and the processes of language acquisition.
* Optimization in role-playing games: A gaming style that involves optimizing character abilities and strategies to achieve success.
* Optimize magazine: A publication focused on optimization techniques and strategies in various fields.
* Process optimization: Methodologies used in business and engineering to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of production processes.
* Product optimization: Techniques used in business and marketing to enhance the quality and desirability of products or product concepts.
* Program optimization: Methods used in computing to improve the efficiency and performance of software.
* Search engine optimization: Strategies used in internet marketing to improve the visibility and ranking of websites in search engine results.

The concept of optimization is closely related to its antonyms, including maximization and minimization, which are also important topics in mathematical analysis.

samples.title: 186 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 186 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus (or, less frequently, year 568 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 186 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 The rapid spread of the Bacchanalia cult throughout the Roman Republic, which, it is claimed, indulges in all kinds of crimes and political conspiracies at its nocturnal meetings, leads to the Roman Senate issuing a decree, the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, by which the Bacchanalia are prohibited throughout all Italy except in certain special cases which must be approved specifically by the Senate.

 Asia Minor 
 Eumenes II of Pergamum defeats Prusias I of Bithynia.

 China 
 The first burial at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui is made during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

Births 
 Ptolemy VI Philometor, king of Egypt, who will reign from 180 BC (d. 145 BC)

Deaths 
 Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, buried in one of the Mawangdui

References

The Roman Senate was worried that this cult was involved in bad behavior and plotting against the government, so they passed a law that banned the cult from meeting anywhere in Italy except in special cases that needed approval from the Senate.

In Other Parts of the World:

* In Asia Minor, a king named Eumenes II defeated another king named Prusias I.
* In China, during the Western Han Dynasty, the first person was buried at a famous archaeological site called Mawangdui.

Births and Deaths:

* Ptolemy VI Philometor, a king of Egypt, was born. He would later become king and rule from 180 BC until his death in 145 BC.
* Li Cang, a nobleman named Marquis of Dai, passed away and was buried at the Mawangdui site.

Dodoni () is a village and a municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus, Greece. The seat of the municipality is the village Agia Kyriaki (community Theriakisi).

The modern village of Dodoni is located near the ancient city of same name and site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. Oedipus the King was shot here in 1967.

Municipality
The present municipality Dodoni was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 4 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Agios Dimitrios
Dodoni
Lakka Souliou
Selloi

The municipality Dodoni has an area of 657.499 km2, the municipal unit Dodoni has an area of 101.016 km2, and the community Dodoni has an area of 8.748 km2.

Gallery

Cities in ancient Greece

Florence is a village in Pike County, Illinois, United States. The population was 71 at the 2000 census.

Geography
Florence is located at  (39.628248, −90.610328).

According to the 2010 census, Florence has a total area of , all land.

As of the census of 2000, there were 71 people, 30 households, and 21 families residing in the village. The population density was 350.4 people per square mile (137.1/km). There were 45 housing units at an average density of 222.1 per square mile (86.9/km). The racial makeup of the village was 100.00% White.

There were 30 households, out of which 16.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were married couples living together, 16.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.0% were non-families. 23.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.67.

In the village, the population was spread out, with 22.5% under the age of 18, 5.6% from 18 to 24, 22.5% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 22.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.7 males.

The median income for a household in the village was $20,000, and the median income for a family was $22,679. Males had a median income of $19,000 versus $20,625 for females. The per capita income for the village was $9,878. There were 8.0% of families and 15.1% of the population living below the poverty line, including no under eighteens and 5.0% of those over 64.

samples.title: Pane carasau
samples.original_text:
Pane carasau (, ; "toasted bread" in Sardinian language, from the past participle of the Sardinian verb  "to toast", referring to the crust) is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. It is called  in Italian, meaning "sheet music", in reference to its large and paper-thin shape, which is said to be so thin before cooking that a sheet of music can be read through it.

The bread is thin and crisp, usually in the form of a dish half a meter wide. It is made by taking baked flat bread (made of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water), then separating it into two sheets which are baked again. The recipe is very ancient and was conceived for shepherds, who used to stay far from home for months at a time: pane carasau can last up to one year if it is kept dry. The bread can be eaten either dry or wet (with water, wine, or sauces). A similar, yeast-free bread, with added seasoning, is known as  "dripped bread".

Remains of the bread were found in archeological excavations of nuraghes (traditional Sardinian stone buildings) and it was therefore already eaten on the island prior to 1000 BC.

References

External links

 History of Pane Carasau

Italian breads
Flatbreads
Cuisine of Sardinia
Ancient dishes

The recipe for Pane Carasau is really old, and it was originally made for shepherds who would be away from home for months at a time. Because it's so dry, it can last up to a year if stored properly! You can eat it on its own or with water, wine, or sauces.

Archaeologists have even found remains of Pane Carasau in ancient Sardinian buildings, which means people were eating it on the island over 3,000 years ago!

There's also a similar type of bread called "dripped bread" that doesn't use yeast and has added seasonings.

Pane Carasau: A Traditional Sardinian Flatbread with a Rich History

Pane Carasau, also known as "toasted bread" in the Sardinian language, is a traditional flatbread originating from Sardinia. The name "pane carasau" is derived from the Sardinian verb "to toast", which refers to the crust of the bread. In Italian, it is referred to as "carta da musica", meaning "sheet music", due to its large, paper-thin shape, which is so thin that a sheet of music can be read through it.

This crisp, flatbread typically measures half a meter in width and is made by taking baked flatbread, composed of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water, and separating it into two sheets, which are then baked again. The recipe is ancient and was originally designed for shepherds who would often spend extended periods away from home, as Pane Carasau can last up to one year if stored properly in a dry environment.

The bread can be consumed either dry or with various liquids, such as water, wine, or sauces. A variation of Pane Carasau, known as "dripped bread", is made without yeast and often seasoned with additional ingredients.

Archaeological excavations of nuraghes, traditional Sardinian stone structures, have uncovered remnants of Pane Carasau, indicating that it was a staple food on the island prior to 1000 BC. The bread's long shelf life and versatility have made it a beloved component of Sardinian cuisine for centuries.

adult_technical.text:
Year 346 CE: A Julian Calendar Anomaly

The year 346 CE, denoted as CCCXLVI in the Julian calendar, commenced on a Wednesday. Within the Roman Empire, it was referred to as the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius, or alternatively, as the 1099th year since the founding of Rome (Ab urbe condita). This notation has been employed since the early Middle Ages, when the Anno Domini era became the dominant method of dating in Europe.

Historical Events

Geographically, the year 346 CE was marked by significant developments in Asia. The Buyeo Kingdom was absorbed by Goguryeo, while Geunchogo ascended to the throne of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

In the realm of religion, Emperor Constans I exercised his influence to secure the return of Athanasius, who was reinstated as Patriarch of Alexandria. The documents compiled during his expulsion, titled Apology Against the Arians, provide valuable insight into the theological debates of the time. Meanwhile, Macedonius I, Patriarch of Constantinople, was deposed for the second time by Paul I. Julius Firmicus Maternus penned De erroribus profanarum religionum, a treatise on the errors of pagan religions. The Visigoths, under the guidance of Wulfila, converted to Arianism.

Notable Births and Deaths

Zhang Tianxi, the Chinese ruler of Former Liang, was born in 346 CE and would go on to pass away in 406 CE. He Chong, a Chinese politician, died around this time, as did Maximin of Trier, a German bishop. Zhang Jun, a Chinese prince, also passed away in 346 CE.

References

samples.title: Tetonia, Idaho
samples.original_text:
Tetonia is a city in Teton County, Idaho, United States, about  northeast of Idaho Falls, Idaho (center to center) and about  northwest of Denver, Colorado. The population was 269 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all land.
Tetonia is located at 43°48′50″N 111°9′35″W, in Teton County Idaho.

History
Tetonia was established as an agricultural town in the late 19th century, taking its name from the nearby Teton Range. Many of the businesses previously operating in Haden relocated to Tetonia following the arrival of the Union Pacific railroad.

Demographics

2010 census
As of the census of 2010, there were 269 people, 95 households, and 62 families residing in the city. The population density was . There were 122 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 92.2% White, 0.7% Native American, 6.3% from other races, and 0.7% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 10.8% of the population.

There were 95 households, of which 46.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.5% were married couples living together, 11.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.2% had a male householder with no wife present, and 34.7% were non-families. 28.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.83 and the average family size was 3.61.

The median age in the city was 35.1 years. 36.1% of residents were under the age of 18; 5.1% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 26.7% were from 25 to 44; 24.5% were from 45 to 64; and 7.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.7% male and 51.3% female.

samples.title: Hubley Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Hubley Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 854 at the 2010 census, a drop of less than 1% from the previous census in 2000.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 889 people, 345 households, and 260 families living in the township.  The population density was 68.0 people per square mile (26.2/km).  There were 369 housing units at an average density of 28.2/sq mi (10.9/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.21% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Asian, 0.22% Pacific Islander, 0.11% from other races, and 0.11% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.12%.

Of the 345 households 29.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.7% were married couples living together, 5.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.6% were non-families. 21.2% of households were one person and 11.9% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.58 and the average family size was 2.98.

The age distribution was 21.7% under the age of 18, 6.7% from 18 to 24, 28.3% from 25 to 44, 23.3% from 45 to 64, and 19.9% 65 or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 107.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.3 males.

The median household income was $41,250 and the median family income  was $46,538. Males had a median income of $32,734 versus $24,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $17,377.  About 4.2% of families and 5.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.6% of those under age 18 and 7.9% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Kebechet
samples.original_text:
In Egyptian mythology, Kebechet (spelt in hieroglyphs as Qeb-Hwt, and also transliterated as Khebhut, Kebehut, Qébéhout, Kabehchet and Kebehwet) is a goddess, a deification of embalming liquid. Her name means cooling water.

Myths
Kebechet is a daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, Kebechet is referred to as a serpent who "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh.

Kebechet was thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was probably related to mummification where she would fortify the body against corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka.

References

Egyptian death goddesses
