In ancient Egyptian mythology, Kebechet was a goddess who was associated with a special liquid used to preserve the bodies of the dead. Her name means "cooling water".

According to myths, Kebechet was the daughter of Anubis, the god of mummification, and his wife Anput. In some stories, Kebechet is described as a snake who helps to refresh and purify the pharaoh.

In Egyptian beliefs, Kebechet was thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for their bodies to be mummified. This was important because the Egyptians believed that the spirits needed to be kept fresh and pure in order to be reunited with their bodies in the afterlife. Kebechet was also believed to help protect the bodies from decay and corruption, so that they could be reanimated by the person's spirit when they were reborn.

In short, Kebechet was a goddess who played a crucial role in the ancient Egyptian process of mummification and the afterlife.

adult_non_technical.text:
Meet Kebechet, a fascinating goddess from ancient Egyptian mythology. Her name means "cooling water," and she's often depicted as a symbol of a special liquid used in the mummification process.

According to myth, Kebechet is the daughter of Anubis, the god of embalming, and his wife Anput. In the ancient texts, Kebechet is described as a serpent who brings refreshment and purification to the pharaoh. This powerful goddess is believed to have played a crucial role in the afterlife, providing water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for their bodies to be prepared for burial.

In Egyptian culture, the process of mummification was seen as a way to preserve the body and ensure the deceased person's spirit could return to it. Kebechet was thought to be responsible for fortifying the body against decay, allowing it to remain fresh and ready for the spirit to rejoin it. This way, the deceased person's ka, or spiritual essence, could be reborn into the afterlife.

In summary, Kebechet is a goddess of great importance in ancient Egyptian mythology, associated with the process of mummification and the afterlife. Her role in providing water and purification to the dead and the deceased's spirit is a testament to her significance in the Egyptian pantheon.

adult_technical.text:
In ancient Egyptian mythology, Kebechet (transcribed as Qeb-Hwt or Khebhut, among other variations) is a deified entity associated with the embalming process. Her name, meaning "cooling water," reflects her role in the mummification ritual.

Mythological accounts portray Kebechet as the daughter of Anubis, the god of mummification, and his consort Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, she is described as a serpent that "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh, underscoring her significance in the afterlife.

Kebechet's primary function was to provide water to the spirits of the deceased during the period between death and mummification. This water was likely used to revitalize the body, allowing it to withstand the process of desiccation and preservation. Her role may have also extended to fortifying the body against corruption, thereby enabling the reanimation of the deceased's ka (life force) during the afterlife.

In the context of Egyptian funerary practices, Kebechet's association with embalming and mummification underscores her importance in ensuring the successful transition of the deceased into the afterlife.

samples.title: Oostburg
samples.original_text:
Oostburg (Zeelandic Flemish: Wòstburg) is a town in the south-western Netherlands. It is the largest town in the municipality of Sluis, in the province of Zeeland. As of 1 January 2015, its population is 4731, down from 5008 in January 2005. It received city rights in 1237. Before 1 January 2003, Oostburg was also the name of a municipality. It merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the new municipality of Sluis. The municipality covered an area of 224.93 km², of which 1.05 km² was water. As well as the town of Oostburg, the former municipality also included the following towns, villages and townships:
Breskens
Cadzand
Groede
Hoofdplaat
IJzendijke
Nieuwvliet
Schoondijke
Waterlandkerkje
Zuidzande

Oostburg is typically a tourist town very close to the beaches at Cadzand. Every Wednesday is market day all year round but in the summer the town is busy and has many fun events.

The unicorn
Oostburg's symbol is the unicorn, from which the townsfolk are said to derive strength and courage. In reality, the unicorn's presence is represented by a sculpture produced by the sculptress Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek who for many years, with her husband, lived in the area: she evidently took inspiration from the name of a former inn. The sculpture has been repositioned at least once since it first appeared in 1952 during the postwar reconstruction: at one stage it adorned a small car park. Currently it shares with a modern fountain a spot in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) beyond the northern end of the old market square in the town centre.

WW2 Monument
During the Second World War approximately 140 Oostburg townsfolk died and most of all the buildings, shops and churches were destroyed. This monument is a tribute to them and the rebuilding of the town. Around the lower part of the monument are the names of those who perished.

Municipalities of the Netherlands disestablished in 2003
Populated places in Zeeland
Former municipalities of Zeeland
Sluis

adult_technical.text:
Oostburg, a municipality in the southwestern Netherlands, is situated in the province of Zeeland and is the largest town within the Sluis municipality. As of January 1, 2015, the town's population stood at 4,731, a decline from the 5,008 residents recorded in January 2005. Oostburg was granted city rights in 1237 and, prior to January 1, 2003, it was also the name of a separate municipality that merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the current Sluis municipality. The former municipality covered an area of 224.93 km², with 1.05 km² comprising water. In addition to Oostburg, the former municipality encompassed several other towns, villages, and townships, including Breskens, Cadzand, Groede, Hoofdplaat, IJzendijke, Nieuwvliet, Schoondijke, Waterlandkerkje, and Zuidzande.

Oostburg is a popular tourist destination, particularly due to its proximity to the beaches at Cadzand. The town hosts a weekly market every Wednesday throughout the year, and during the summer months, it is bustling with activity and hosts various events.

The town's symbol is the unicorn, which is said to embody the strength and courage of the townspeople. The sculpture, created by artist Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek, was originally installed in 1952 and has since been relocated to its current location in the "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) near the northern end of the old market square.

The town's history is marked by significant losses during World War II, with approximately 140 townsfolk perishing and most of the buildings, shops, and churches being destroyed. A monument was erected to honor the victims and the town's subsequent reconstruction. The monument features the names of those who lost their lives.

In conclusion, Oostburg is a town with a rich history, cultural significance, and a strong sense of community, as reflected in its symbol, the unicorn.

samples.title: Leaf River Township, Wadena County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Leaf River Township is a township in Wadena County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 515 at the 2000 census.

Leaf River Township was named after the Leaf River.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 515 people, 174 households, and 135 families residing in the township.  The population density was 14.6 people per square mile (5.7/km2).  There were 196 housing units at an average density of 5.6/sq mi (2.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 94.37% White, 2.14% African American, 1.75% Native American, 0.58% Asian, 0.19% Pacific Islander, and 0.97% from two or more races.

There were 174 households, out of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.9% were married couples living together, 0.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.4% were non-families. 21.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.16.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.2% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 23.9% from 25 to 44, 33.6% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 138.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $37,292, and the median income for a family was $46,750. Males had a median income of $32,411 versus $20,795 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,681.  About 6.5% of families and 19.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 11.1% of those under age 18 and 28.0% of those age 65 or over.

Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: Haddocks' Eyes
samples.original_text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a term for the name of a song sung by The White Knight from Lewis Carroll's  1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, chapter VIII.

"Haddocks' Eyes" is an example used to elaborate on the symbolic status of the concept of "name": a name as identification marker may be assigned to anything, including another name, thus introducing different levels of symbolization. It has been discussed in several works on logic and philosophy.

Naming

The White Knight explains to Alice a confusing nomenclature for the song.

To summarize:

The song's name is called Haddocks' Eyes
The song's name is The Aged Aged Man
The song is called Ways and Means
The song is A-sitting on a Gate

The complicated terminology distinguishing between 'the song, what the song is called, the name of the song, and what the name of the song is called' both uses and mentions the use–mention distinction.

The song

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims as his own invention, but which Alice recognises as "I give thee all, I can no more". By the time Alice heard it, she was already tired of poetry.

The song parodies the plot, but not the style or metre, of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth.

Upon the Lonely Moor

Like "Jabberwocky," another poem published in Through the Looking Glass, "Haddocks’ Eyes" appears to have been revised over the course of many years. In 1856, Carroll published the following poem anonymously under the name Upon the Lonely Moor. It bears an obvious resemblance to "Haddocks' Eyes."

See also

Nonsense verse

References

British poems
1871 poems
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
Nonsense poetry
Parodies of literature

easy_general.text:

"Haddocks' Eyes" is the name of a song sung by the White Knight in Lewis Carroll's famous book "Through the Looking-Glass". This song is special because it shows how we use names to identify things, and how we can use names to refer to other names. This idea is important in logic and philosophy.

The White Knight explains to Alice that the song has four different names:

* "Haddocks' Eyes"
* "The Aged Aged Man"
* "Ways and Means"
* "A-sitting on a Gate"

These names can be confusing, and they use a concept called the "use-mention distinction". This means that we need to be careful when we talk about names, because we can use a name to refer to something, or we can mention the name itself.

The song is sung to a tune that the White Knight claims he invented, but Alice recognizes it as a familiar melody. The song is a parody of a poem called "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth. It's a bit like a joke, where the White Knight takes the original poem and changes the words to make it silly.

Interestingly, the poem "Haddocks' Eyes" seems to have been written and rewritten over many years. In fact, Carroll published a similar poem called "Upon the Lonely Moor" in 1856, before he wrote "Through the Looking-Glass". This poem is very similar to "Haddocks' Eyes", and it shows how Carroll liked to experiment with language and ideas.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Curious Case of "Haddocks' Eyes"**

In Lewis Carroll's beloved novel "Through the Looking-Glass," a peculiar song called "Haddocks' Eyes" is sung by the White Knight. But what's fascinating about this song is not just its melody, but the way it plays with the concept of names and identity.

**The Song's Many Names**

The White Knight explains to Alice that the song has multiple names. It's called "Haddocks' Eyes," but also "The Aged Aged Man," "Ways and Means," and even "A-sitting on a Gate." This might seem confusing, but it's actually a clever example of how we use language to identify things. We can give a name to anything, including another name, which creates a layer of meaning and symbolism.

**The Song Itself**

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims to have invented, but Alice recognizes it as a familiar melody. The song is a parody of William Wordsworth's "Resolution and Independence," but with a humorous twist. It's a clever play on words, and Alice is initially skeptical of poetry, but the song's cleverness wins her over.

**A Revised Poem**

Interestingly, "Haddocks' Eyes" appears to have undergone revisions over the years. In fact, Carroll published a similar poem called "Upon the Lonely Moor" in 1856, which shares many similarities with "Haddocks' Eyes." This highlights the creative process behind Carroll's writing and the evolution of his ideas.

**In Conclusion**

"Haddocks' Eyes" is more than just a quirky song in a beloved novel. It's a thought-provoking exploration of language, identity, and creativity. By examining the song's multiple names and its evolution over time, we gain insight into the complexities of human communication and the power of imagination.

adult_technical.text:
In Lewis Carroll's 1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, Chapter VIII, the White Knight introduces the enigmatic song "Haddocks' Eyes," which exemplifies the complexities of the concept of naming and the use-mention distinction in logic and philosophy.

The song's nomenclature is deliberately convoluted, with multiple names assigned to the same entity. The White Knight explains to Alice that the song is referred to as:

1. Haddocks' Eyes
2. The Aged Aged Man
3. Ways and Means
4. A-sitting on a Gate

This intricate terminology illustrates the distinction between the song itself, its name, and the name of its name, highlighting the nuances of the use-mention distinction.

The song, sung to a tune claimed by the White Knight as his own invention, is actually a parody of William Wordsworth's "Resolution and Independence." Alice, already fatigued by poetry, recognizes the melody as "I give thee all, I can no more." The song's plot is parodied, but its style and meter remain faithful to the original.

Interestingly, "Haddocks' Eyes" bears a striking resemblance to "Upon the Lonely Moor," a poem published anonymously by Carroll in 1856. This earlier work appears to have undergone revisions over the years, ultimately evolving into the song "Haddocks' Eyes" in Through the Looking-Glass.

References:

* Carroll, L. (1871). Through the Looking-Glass.
* Carroll, L. (1856). Upon the Lonely Moor.
* Wordsworth, W. (1807). Resolution and Independence.

samples.title: Holland Township, Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Holland Township is a township in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 369 at the 2000 census.

Holland Township was organized in 1888. A large share of the early settlers being natives of Holland caused the name to be selected.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  of  land and 0.03% is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 369 people, 120 households, and 102 families residing in the township.  The population density was 10.4 people per square mile (4.0/km2).  There were 122 housing units at an average density of 3.5/sq mi (1.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.37% White, 0.27% African American, 1.08% from other races, and 0.27% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 120 households, out of which 47.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 84.2% were married couples living together, and 15.0% were non-families. 11.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.08 and the average family size was 3.40.

In the township the population was spread out, with 33.9% under the age of 18, 3.8% from 18 to 24, 30.4% from 25 to 44, 22.8% from 45 to 64, and 9.2% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 114.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $45,313, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $30,750 versus $19,107 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,243.  About 7.1% of families and 7.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 7.6% of those under age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: SI derived unit
samples.original_text:
SI derived units are units of measurement derived from the
seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation. 

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units (for example, hertz, the SI unit of measurement of frequency), but the rest merely reflect their derivation: for example, the square metre (m2), the SI derived unit of area; and the kilogram per cubic metre (kg/m3 or kg⋅m−3), the SI derived unit of density. 

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for metre is "m".

Derived units with special names
The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, which includes two dimensionless derived units, the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived quantities and units

Other units used with SI
Some other units such as the hour, litre, tonne, bar, and electronvolt are not SI units, but are widely used in conjunction with SI units.

Supplementary units
Until 1995, the SI classified the radian and the steradian as supplementary units, but this designation was abandoned and the units were grouped as derived units.

See also
 International System of Quantities (ISQ)
 International Vocabulary of Metrology
 Metric prefix
 Metric system

References

Bibliography

External links

Derived

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

The International System of Units (SI) has a set of basic units that we use to measure things like length, weight, and time. From these basic units, we can create new units by combining them in different ways. These new units are called derived units.

Some derived units have special names, like "hertz" for measuring frequency. Others, like "square meter" and "kilogram per cubic meter", are named based on how they're derived from the basic units. When we write the names of these units, we always use lowercase letters.

There are 22 derived units with special names, including two that don't have any size or value, like the radian and the steradian.

We also use other units, like hours, liters, and tons, that aren't officially part of the SI system, but are still widely used with SI units.

In the past, the radian and steradian were considered "supplementary units", but that label was dropped and they're now just considered derived units.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Understanding SI Derived Units: A Guide for the Non-Technical**

When we measure things, we use units of measurement to express the values. The International System of Units (SI) is a set of rules that helps us define these units. SI derived units are special units that are built from the seven basic units specified by the SI system. They can be either dimensionless (meaning they don't have a size or quantity) or a combination of the basic units, possibly with some extra numbers or powers.

Some SI derived units have special names, like "hertz" for measuring frequency, while others are simply described by their composition, such as "square meter" for measuring area or "kilogram per cubic meter" for measuring density. When writing these units in full, we use lowercase letters, but if they're named after people, we capitalize the first letter, like "Hz" for hertz and "m" for meter.

**Special Names for 22 Derived Units**

The SI system has given special names to 22 derived units, including two that don't have a size or quantity: the radian and the steradian. These special names make it easier to communicate and understand measurements.

**Other Units Used with SI**

While the SI system is the standard, some other units like hours, liters, tons, bars, and electronvolts are commonly used alongside SI units. These units aren't part of the SI system, but they're widely accepted and useful in many contexts.

**Supplementary Units**

In the past, the SI system classified the radian and steradian as supplementary units, but this designation was later dropped, and they're now considered derived units.

**In Summary**

SI derived units are built from the seven basic units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They can be dimensionless or a combination of basic units, and some have special names. Understanding SI derived units helps us communicate and work with measurements more effectively.

**The Many Faces of the Boston Braves**

You may have heard of the Boston Braves, but did you know there were actually several teams that went by this name? Let's take a look at the different sports teams that were once known as the Boston Braves.

In baseball, the Boston Braves were a Major League team that played in the city from 1912 to 1952. Today, they're known as the Atlanta Braves. The team was one of the original franchises in the National League and had some successful seasons, including a World Series win in 1914.

samples.title: Separate-channel signaling
samples.original_text:
Separate-channel signaling is a form of signaling in which the whole or a part of one or more channels in a multichannel system is used to provide for supervisory and control signals for the message traffic channels.  

The same channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, that are used for signaling are not used for message traffic.

See also

 Common-channel signaling

References

Telephony signals

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

"Separate-channel signaling is a way for a communication system to send extra messages, like "hello" or "goodbye", on a different channel than the main message. This is useful for controlling and managing the flow of messages.

For example, imagine you're on a phone call and you need to switch to a different line. The system would use a separate channel to send a signal to switch the call, so you don't have to hang up and dial again.

This type of signaling uses a different channel, like a different frequency or time slot, than the one used for the main conversation. This way, the main channel stays free for the actual conversation, and the extra channel handles the control signals.

This is different from common-channel signaling, where the same channel is used for both the main message and the control signals."

adult_non_technical.text:
"Supervisory Signals: A Special Lane for Control Messages

In a system that can handle multiple messages at the same time, like a highway with multiple lanes, there's a special way to manage the flow of traffic. This is called separate-channel signaling. It's like having a dedicated lane for control messages, separate from the lanes used for the main messages.

Think of it like a highway with a special lane for emergency vehicles or police cars. They need to be able to communicate with each other quickly and efficiently, so they have their own lane to do so. Similarly, in a multichannel system, the control messages, like supervisory signals, need their own dedicated channel to ensure smooth communication.

This way, the main message channels can focus on carrying the actual messages, while the supervisory signals can handle the control and management tasks, like keeping track of who's talking to whom and when. It's like having a separate lane for the traffic cops to direct the flow of traffic, so the main lanes can stay clear and efficient."

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

In a multichannel system, separate-channel signaling employs a dedicated subset of channels to convey supervisory and control information, distinct from the channels utilized for message traffic. This approach ensures that the same frequency bands or time slots used for signaling are not concurrently utilized for message transmission.

Note: I've maintained the original text's focus on technical terminology and precision, while rephrasing the sentences for clarity and structure. I've also added a brief clarification to emphasize the distinction between signaling and message traffic channels.

samples.title: 1440s BC
samples.original_text:
The 1440s BC is a decade which lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC.

Events and trends
 1449 BC: Fíachu Labrainne, Milesians' High King of Ireland, is killed and succeeded by Eochu Mumu
 c. 1448 BC: The Gnbtyw people (Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appear in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt
1445–1444 BC: The Book of Leviticus is written.
 c. 1440 BC: first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar which controlled the Gulf of İzmir

* In 1449 BC, the king of Ireland, Fíachu Labrainne, died and was replaced by Eochu Mumu.
* Around 1448 BC, a group of people called the Gnbtyw (pronounced "nab-ti-woo") appeared in a place called Ganibatum, which was part of ancient Egypt.
* Between 1445 and 1444 BC, a book called the Book of Leviticus was written. This book is part of the Bible and is important to the Jewish faith.
* Around 1440 BC, the first city was built on a mountain called Yamanlar, which controlled a big body of water called the Gulf of İzmir. This city was an important place in ancient times.

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text in plain language:

The 1440s BC was a decade that started in 1449 BC and ended in 1440 BC. Here are some significant events and trends that took place during this time:

In Ireland, the High King of the Milesians, Fíachu Labrainne, was killed and replaced by Eochu Mumu in 1449 BC.

In ancient Egypt, a group of people called the Gnbtyw (also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appeared in a region called Ganibatum during the 32nd year of the reign of Pharaoh Thutmose III, who was the sixth ruler of the Eighteenth dynasty.

Meanwhile, in ancient Egypt, the 32nd year of Pharaoh Thutmose III's reign saw the emergence of the Gnbtyw people (also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu) in Ganibatum. This event likely had significant consequences for the region's cultural and economic dynamics.

Meet Louis Pasteur: A Pioneer in Science

Louis Pasteur was a French scientist who lived from 1822 to 1895. He was a chemist and microbiologist, which means he studied the tiny living things that can't be seen with the naked eye. Pasteur's work changed the way we understand and fight diseases.

But did you know that his name is also associated with many other things? From islands and rivers to craters on the moon and Mars, there are many places and objects named after Louis Pasteur. In addition, there are train stations, museums, and even a university named after him.

In France, there's a famous underground train station called Pasteur, as well as a museum dedicated to his life and work. In Iran, there's a medical research institute that bears his name. And in Monaco, there's a building called Îlot Pasteur.

But what's most interesting is that Pasteur's name is also associated with some scientific concepts and tools. For example, the "Pasteur effect" is a phenomenon where certain bacteria grow faster in the presence of oxygen. The "Pasteur pipette" is a type of laboratory tool used to measure tiny amounts of liquid. And "Pasteurization" is a process that kills harmful bacteria in food and water by heating it to a certain temperature.

Overall, Louis Pasteur was a remarkable scientist who left a lasting impact on our understanding of the world. His name is a reminder of the importance of scientific discovery and innovation.

adult_technical.text:

In the medical sphere, PKD can signify Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia, a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements triggered by sudden physical activity. Additionally, PKD may refer to Pi Kappa Delta, a prestigious honor society dedicated to the art of forensic science.

In the realm of genetics, PKD1 and PKD2 are two human genes involved in the development and function of the kidneys. Furthermore, PKD can also stand for Polycystic kidney disease, a chronic and debilitating condition characterized by the growth of cysts on the kidneys.

Eagle Point Township is a township in Marshall County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 33 at the 2000 census.

Eagle Point Township was organized in 1890, and named for an eagle's nest in a nearby grove.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  is land and  (1.52%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 33 people, 13 households, and 10 families residing in the township. The population density was 1.2 people per square mile (0.5/km2). There were 18 housing units at an average density of 0.6/sq mi (0.2/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

Year 834 CE: A Year of Transition and Conflict

The year 834 CE, denoted as DCCCXXXIV in the Julian calendar, commenced on a Thursday. This period was marked by significant events in various regions, including Europe, Britain, and Asia.

In Europe, the Frankish Empire underwent a major shift in leadership. Emperor Louis the Pious, who had previously shared power with his sons, was restored as the sole ruler. This move led to a rift, and his eldest son, Lothair I, fled to Burgundy. Meanwhile, the Danish Vikings launched a raid on the trading settlement of Dorestad, located in the province of Utrecht, Netherlands. The Viking ship of Oseberg, which was buried in a mound near Tønsberg, Norway, dates back to this period. Additionally, the Jona River in Switzerland was first mentioned around this time.

In Britain, the Picts saw a change in leadership, as King Óengus II passed away after a 14-year reign. He was succeeded by his nephew, Drest IX.

In the realm of religion, Ansegisus, a prominent Frankish abbot and advisor to Charlemagne, died on July 20 at Fontenelle Abbey in Normandy.

Several notable individuals were born in 834 CE, including Aud the Deep-Minded, an Icelandic queen; Euthymius I, the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople; Lady Shuiqiu, the wife of Qian Kuan; Mo Xuanqing, a Chinese scholar; Pi Rixiu, a Chinese poet; Robert, a Frankish nobleman; and Tan Quanbo, a Chinese warlord.

The year 834 CE was also marked by the passing of several notable figures, including Ansegisus, Adelchis I, duke of Spoleto; Cellach mac Brain, king of Leinster; Fridugisus, an Anglo-Saxon abbot; Gaucelm, a Frankish nobleman; Nasr ibn 'Abdallah, a Muslim governor; Odo I, a Frankish nobleman; Óengus II, king of the Picts; Robert III, a Frankish nobleman; Wang Chengyuan, a Chinese general; Wang Tingcou, a general of the Tang Dynasty; and William, a Frankish nobleman.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 921 people, 339 households, and 267 families residing in the town.  The population density was 27.5 people per square mile (10.6/km). adult_non_technical.text:
A Long, Long Time Ago: 554 BC

Imagine a time before the calendar you use today. In ancient Rome, they had their own way of counting years, which started from the founding of the city. This system was called the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In this system, the year 554 BC was known as year 200 Ab urbe condita, or "200 years after the city was founded."

For a long time, people in Europe used a different way of counting years, called the Anno Domini calendar. This system started from the birth of Jesus Christ and is the one we use today. But before that, people used the old Roman system, and that's why we still see the year 554 BC mentioned in historical records.

What Happened in 554 BC

Unfortunately, there aren't many records of significant events that took place in 554 BC. However, we do know that Duke Ling of Qi, the ruler of the State of Qi, passed away that year.

If you're curious about ancient history, you might be interested to know that the year 554 BC is still used today in historical records and research. It's a reminder of the rich and complex history that came before our modern calendar.

The following events occurred during this year:

samples.original_text:
Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus (or, less frequently, year 1018 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 265 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Empire 
 Emperor Gallienus tries twice to crush the usurper Postumus, but on the first occasion Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, carelessly lets him escape. The second time, Gallienus sustains an arrow wound and has to break off his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus has holed up. He makes no other serious attempt to overcome his rival, instead devoting his attention to the political and military problems in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.  
 Postumus makes no move to march on Rome and claim his territory south of Gaul. 
 Gallienus gives the order to fortify Milan and Verona. 
 Gallienus repels the invasion of the Goths in the Balkans. 
 A general of Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defects to Postumus.

 China  
 Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and de facto primary authority of the state of Cao Wei for little over 10 years by this point, passes away, leaving his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who will go on to disestablish the state of Cao Wei in 266, founding the Jin dynasty.

Births 
 Eusebius of Caesarea, Greek historian (approximate date)

Deaths 
 September 6 – Sima Zhao, Chinese general and politician (b. 211)
 Ma Jun, Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
 Zhu (or Jing), Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state

References

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

In the year 265, the Roman Empire was dealing with some big problems. The emperor, Gallienus, was trying to defeat a rival named Postumus, who had taken control of some land in Gaul (modern-day France). Gallienus tried to attack Postumus twice, but both times he failed. The second time, Gallienus even got hurt by an arrow. After that, he gave up trying to defeat Postumus and focused on other problems in the empire.

Meanwhile, Postumus didn't try to take over Rome or the rest of the empire. Instead, Gallienus built up the defenses of two important cities, Milan and Verona. Gallienus also fought off an invasion by the Goths in the Balkans. One of his generals, Victorinus, even defected to Postumus' side.

In China, the leader of the state of Cao Wei, Sima Zhao, died after being in charge for over 10 years. His son, Sima Yan, took over and eventually abolished the state of Cao Wei, creating a new dynasty called the Jin dynasty.

Some notable people were born or died that year. Eusebius of Caesarea, a famous Greek historian, was born around this time. Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, died on September 6. Two other important Chinese figures, Ma Jun, an engineer and inventor, and Zhu (or Jing), the empress of the Eastern Wu state, also passed away.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

adult_technical.text:
Year 265 CE: A Critical Juncture in the Roman Empire and the Eastern World

The year 265 CE, denoted as the consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, marked a pivotal moment in the Roman Empire's tumultuous history. This era, also known as the Anno Domini calendar, had become the dominant method of dating years in Europe by the early medieval period.

Roman Empire

Emperor Gallienus faced a significant challenge in his bid to quell the usurper Postumus, who had risen to power in Gaul. Gallienus launched two campaigns against Postumus, but his efforts were thwarted by the incompetence of his commander, Aureolus, who allowed Postumus to escape on the first occasion. The second attempt ended in failure when Gallienus himself sustained an arrow wound and was forced to abandon his siege of a Gallic town. Rather than pursuing Postumus further, Gallienus redirected his attention to the pressing issues in the Danube region and the eastern provinces of the empire.

Meanwhile, Postumus remained inactive, failing to capitalize on his advantage by launching a campaign to claim Rome and the territories south of Gaul. Gallienus, however, took measures to fortify Milan and Verona, and successfully repelled a Gothic invasion in the Balkans. Notably, a trusted general of Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defected to Postumus' cause.

China

The death of Sima Zhao, regent and de facto ruler of the state of Cao Wei, marked the beginning of a new era in Chinese history. His eldest son, Sima Yan, succeeded him and would go on to disestablish Cao Wei, founding the Jin dynasty in 266 CE.

Births

Eusebius of Caesarea, a prominent Greek historian, was born around this time.

Deaths

September 6, Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, passed away at the age of 54.

Ma Jun, a renowned Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot, also died during this year.

Zhu (or Jing), the empress of the Eastern Wu state, succumbed to death.

References

samples.title: Bedrock Records
samples.original_text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label for trance, progressive house and techno started by Nick Muir and John Digweed. Its name comes from a long running and successful club night held in Hastings and also at Heaven nightclub, London - both also called Bedrock. Bedrock Records has released many singles from artists such as Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars and Jerry Bonham.  Bedrock is also the name that Digweed and Muir use as their production moniker.

Bedrock has had different imprints: Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock and Black (Bedrock). Currently it has Bedrock Digital and one called Lost & Found belonging to Guy J.

The first Bedrock album compiled and mixed by John Digweed was released in 1999, containing several tracks signed to the Bedrock label. 

In 2018, Digweed marked the 20th anniversary of the label with the release of Bedrock XX.

See also

samples.original_text:
Hippomedon (; Ἰππομέδων, gen.: Ἰππομέδοντος) may refer to several figures in Greek mythology:

 Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes.
 Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion.
Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe, a defender of Troy killed by Neoptolemus.
Hippomedon, father of Menoites. His son was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.

His son, also named Hippomedon, was another defender of Troy and was killed by a warrior named Teucer.

These characters are mentioned in ancient Greek stories and poems, such as the works of Apollodorus and Quintus Smyrnaeus. These stories were written many years ago, but they're still important parts of Greek mythology and the legend of the Trojan War.

In Greek mythology, Hippomedon is a name that appears in several stories, often referring to different characters. Let's explore these fascinating figures and their roles in ancient Greek tales.

Then there's Hippomedon, the son of Maenalus and the nymph Ocyrhoe, who defended the city of Troy during the Trojan War. Unfortunately, he was killed by the hero Neoptolemus.

Interestingly, there's another Hippomedon, the father of Menoites, who also fought in the Trojan War. His son, another defender of Troy, met his demise at the hands of the skilled archer Teucer.

A third Hippomedon is the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe. This Hippomedon is a defender of Troy, who met his demise at the hands of Neoptolemus. His son, Menoites, also fought in the Trojan War and was killed by Teucer.

samples.title: Blackwood National Park
samples.original_text:
Blackwood is a national park in the Charters Towers Region, Queensland, Australia.

Geography 
The park is west of Mount Coolon in North Queensland, 924 km northwest of Brisbane.  It is named after the Australian Blackwood tree species.

The parks is accessible via the Gregory Developmental Road.  Blackwood was created to protect Brigalow Belt plant communities and includes landscapes of rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges and alluvial flats.

About 80 species of birds have been recorded in the park.

Restrictions 
Camping and fires are not permitted within the park.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Queensland
Protected areas established in 1991
North Queensland
1991 establishments in Australia

Blackwood National Park is a unique place with different landscapes, including rugged hills, deep gorges, stony ridges, and flat areas with soft soil. The park is home to over 80 different species of birds, which is a lot of variety!

There are some rules to keep in mind when visiting the park. You're not allowed to camp or have fires within the park. This helps protect the park's environment and wildlife.

If you're interested in learning more about protected areas in Queensland, you can check out the links below.

The park's name comes from the Australian Blackwood tree, a unique species found only in this region. The park's geography is just as fascinating, with rugged hills, gorges, stony ridges, and alluvial flats creating a diverse landscape.

Birdwatchers will be thrilled to know that over 80 species of birds have been recorded in the park, making it a haven for feathered friends. However, to preserve the park's natural beauty, camping and fires are not permitted within the park boundaries.

If you're planning a visit, be sure to check out the park's protected areas and learn more about the Brigalow Belt plant communities that call this place home. With its unique landscapes and diverse wildlife, Blackwood National Park is a true gem of North Queensland.

Access to the park is facilitated by the Gregory Developmental Road. Established in 1991, Blackwood National Park was created to conserve the region's unique Brigalow Belt plant communities, which comprise rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges, and alluvial flats.

samples.title: Multiple homing
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, the term multiple homing has the following meanings: 
 telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility so that it can be served by one or several switching centers. Multiple homing may use a single directory number. 
 In telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility to more than one switching center by separate access lines. Separate directory numbers are applicable to each switching center accessed. 

 In military, such as Missiles and loitering munitions, it is ability of a single weapon system or projectile to select, focus and simultaneously engage multiple targets.

See also
 Homing pigeon
 Infrared homing
 Missile guidance

References

Communication circuits
Military terminology

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

In communication systems, "multiple homing" has two main meanings.

In phone systems, it means connecting a device, like a phone or computer, to multiple central hubs that can handle calls. This way, if one hub is busy or goes down, the device can still make and receive calls through another hub. The device can have the same phone number, but it's connected to multiple hubs.

In phone systems, it also means connecting a device to multiple central hubs using separate lines. Each hub has its own phone number, so you can call the device from each hub separately.

In the military, "multiple homing" refers to a weapon or projectile that can target and attack multiple enemies at the same time. This means it can choose its targets, focus on them, and attack them all at once.

For example, imagine a missile that can lock onto multiple enemy planes and destroy them simultaneously. This makes it a powerful and effective weapon.

Note: I avoided using technical words like "terminal facility" and "directory numbers" and instead used simpler language to explain the concepts. I also added examples to help illustrate the meanings of "multiple homing" in different contexts.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Multiple Homing: A Simple Explanation**

Imagine you're trying to reach a friend who's in a different part of town. You could call their home phone, but what if you're not sure which phone line is the best to use? That's where "multiple homing" comes in.

In the world of telecommunications, multiple homing refers to the ability of a device or system to connect to multiple destinations, like phone lines or switching centers. This means that instead of being tied to just one way to reach someone, you can use different paths to get in touch. For example, a business might have multiple phone lines that connect to different switching centers, so if one line is busy, the call can be rerouted through another line.

But multiple homing isn't just limited to phone systems. In the military, it's a crucial feature of some weapons, like missiles and loitering munitions. These weapons can target multiple enemies at the same time, selecting and engaging them simultaneously. This ability to focus on multiple targets makes them more effective and efficient.

In simple terms, multiple homing is about having multiple options to achieve a goal, whether it's making a phone call or taking out multiple targets. It's a powerful concept that has applications in both civilian and military contexts.

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, the concept of multiple homing refers to the connection of a terminal facility to multiple switching centers, enabling it to be served by one or several central offices. This configuration can utilize a single directory number, facilitating seamless communication.

In a more specific context, multiple homing in telephone systems involves connecting a terminal facility to multiple switching centers via separate access lines, each with its own dedicated directory number. This setup allows for redundant connections and increased reliability.

In the military context, multiple homing is a capability of certain weapon systems or projectiles, enabling them to select, focus, and simultaneously engage multiple targets. This feature is particularly relevant in applications such as missile guidance and loitering munitions.

It is worth noting that the term "homing" has additional meanings in other fields, including the use of homing pigeons for message delivery and infrared homing guidance systems.

References:

* Communication circuits
* Military terminology

The median household income was $49,286, while the median family income was $68,056. Males had a median income of $38,409, compared to $45,179 for females. The per capita income was $14,186. Only 3.9% of families and 0% of the population lived below the poverty line.

samples.title: Fionnuala
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala (modern spellings: Fionnghuala,  Fionnuala , or  Finola; literally  meaning "white shoulder") was the daughter of Lir of the Tuatha Dé Danann. In the legend of the Children of Lir, she was changed into a swan and cursed by her stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland, with her brothers Fiachra, Conn and Aodh, for 900 years until saved by the marriage of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin, whose union broke the curse. 'The Song of Fionnuala', with lyrics by Thomas Moore speaks of her wanderings.

The name is anglicized as Fenella. The shortened version Nuala is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland.

samples.title: Sluis-Aardenburg

Sluis-Aardenburg was a municipality in the province of Zeeland, in the south-western part of the Netherlands. It was created from a merger of Sluis and Aardenburg in 1995, and it merged with the municipality of Oostburg, on 1 January 2003, to form the new municipality of Sluis.  Sluis-Aardenburg covered an area of 83.48 km², of which 0.89 km² was water.

The municipality comprised the following towns, villages and townships:
Aardenburg

adult_non_technical.text:
**A Guide to Dog Breeds: Past and Present**

Are you fascinated by the incredible diversity of dog breeds? From the tiny Chihuahua to the majestic Great Dane, there are over 340 recognized breeds of dogs worldwide. But did you know that some breeds have disappeared over time, while new ones have emerged? In this article, we'll explore both extant and extinct dog breeds, varieties, and types.

**Living Breeds**

Let's start with the many breeds that still exist today. We've organized them alphabetically for your convenience:

* A to C: Affenpinscher, Beagle, Corgi, and more
* D to K: Dalmatian, German Shepherd, Husky, and more
* L to R: Labrador Retriever, Poodle, Rottweiler, and more
* S to Z: Shih Tzu, Yorkshire Terrier, and many others

**Breeds That Are No Longer with Us**

Unfortunately, some breeds have become extinct over time. These breeds may have been lost due to factors like disease, lack of popularity, or genetic issues. Here are some examples:

* Extinct breeds: These breeds have completely disappeared, and there are no longer any living individuals.
* Varieties: These are breeds that have become extinct, but their characteristics or traits have been preserved in other breeds.
* Types: These are breeds that have evolved over time and are now considered distinct from their original breed.

**Additional Resources**

If you're interested in learning more about dog breeds, here are some helpful resources:

* References: A list of sources used in this article
* Citations: Specific references for each breed mentioned
* Bibliography: A comprehensive list of books and articles on dog breeds

By exploring both living and extinct breeds, we can gain a deeper appreciation for the incredible diversity of dogs and the rich history behind each breed.

samples.title: Appendix
samples.original_text:
Appendix may refer to:

In documents
Addendum, an addition made to a document by its author after its initial printing or publication
Bibliography, a systematic list of books and other works
Index (publishing), a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document

Anatomy
Appendix (anatomy), a part of the human digestive system
Appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct of the epididymis
Appendix testis, a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct
Epiploic appendix, one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum
Appendix of the laryngeal ventricle, a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle
Mesoappendix, the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix

Arts and media

The Appendix, a quarterly journal of history and culture

 Appendicitis

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

**What is an Appendix?**

An appendix is a word that can refer to different things. Here are a few examples:

**In Documents**

* An addendum is an extra piece of information added to a document after it's been printed or published.
* A bibliography is a list of books and other sources used to research a topic.
* An index is a list of important words or phrases with page numbers that tell you where to find related information in a document.

**In the Human Body**

* The appendix is a small, usually harmless part of the digestive system.
* There are also other types of appendices in the body, such as small pouches of fat near the colon and rectum, or a sac near the voice box.

**In Other Areas**

* The Appendix is also the name of a Finnish punk rock band.
* There's a journal called The Appendix that publishes articles about history and culture.

**Important Note**

* If you have an appendix in your body, it's possible to get appendicitis, which is an infection that requires medical attention.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**What is an Appendix?**

You might have heard of the word "appendix" before, but did you know it has multiple meanings? Let's break it down.

**In Documents**

In the world of writing, an appendix is an addition to a document that's added after it's been printed or published. It's like a bonus section that provides extra information or clarification. You might also see a bibliography, which is a list of books and other sources used in the document. And then there's an index, which is a list of important words or phrases with page numbers to help you find related information.

**In the Human Body**

In the human body, the appendix is a small, tube-like structure attached to the large intestine. It's a vestigial organ, which means it's no longer necessary for our survival, but it's still present in many people. There are other types of appendices in the body too, such as the appendix of the epididymis, which is a small tube that carries sperm, and the epiploic appendix, which is a small pouch of fat near the colon.

**In Other Areas**

In the world of music, there's a Finnish punk rock band called Appendix. And in the world of academia, there's a quarterly journal called The Appendix that focuses on history and culture.

**What's the Connection?**

While the different meanings of "appendix" might seem unrelated, they all share a common thread. They're all about adding something extra, whether it's information, a new section, or a new perspective. And that's what makes the word "appendix" so interesting – it's a reminder that there's always more to learn and discover.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The term "appendix" has multiple meanings across various fields, including documents, anatomy, and arts and media.

In the context of documents, an appendix refers to an addition made by the author after the initial printing or publication, such as an addendum, bibliography, or index. The latter is a systematic list of words or phrases with pointers to related material within the document.

In anatomy, the appendix is a part of the human digestive system, specifically a small, vestigial structure attached to the cecum. Additionally, there are other anatomical structures referred to as appendices, including the appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct; the appendix testis, a remnant of the Müllerian duct; the epiploic appendix, a small pouch of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum; and the appendix of the laryngeal ventricle, a sac extending from the laryngeal ventricle. Furthermore, the mesoappendix is the portion of the mesentery connecting the ileum to the vermiform appendix.

In the realm of arts and media, the term "appendix" is used to refer to a Finnish punk rock group and a quarterly journal of history and culture, titled "The Appendix".

Finally, it is worth noting that the term "appendicitis" refers to a medical condition characterized by inflammation of the appendix.

I hope this rewritten text meets your requirements!

samples.title: Hreiðmarr
samples.original_text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr (Old Norse: ; anglicized as Hreidmar) is a sorcerer. He is featured in the Völsunga saga and in Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr was the father of Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr and Lofnheiðr. He owned a house of glittering gold and flashing gems built by Regin and guarded by Fafnir. After Otr was accidentally killed by Loki, the Æsir repaid Hreiðmarr with Andvari's gold and the ring Andvaranaut, a magical ring that could create gold. However, Andvari had cursed the ring to bring misfortune and destruction to whoever else possessed it. Hreiðmarr ignored Loki's warnings about the curse and kept the ring, only to have Fafnir and Regin later kill him for it. Fafnir decided he wanted Andvaranaut for himself, so he turned into a dragon and drove Regin away. Fafnir guarded the treasure until Sigurd, on Regin's instigation, arrived and delivered a fatal blow to the dragon. Regin was then also killed by Sigurd while attempting to murder him for the ring, thus leaving all of Hreiðmarr's family dead.

See also
Völsung Cycle

References

Other sources
Byock, Jesse L. (1990) Saga of the Volsungs: The Norse Epic of Sigurd the Dragon Slayer (University of California Press) 
Orchard, Andy (1997)  Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend  (Cassell & Co)

External links
The Saga of the Volsungs, a summary in English



Völsung cycle
Norse dwarves
Nibelung tradition

Hreiðmarr had five children: Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. He lived in a beautiful house made of gold and precious gems, built by his son Regin and guarded by his son Fafnir.

Tragedy struck when Ótr was accidentally killed by the trickster god Loki. The gods of the Æsir (a group of powerful beings in Norse mythology) gave Hreiðmarr a special ring and a pile of gold as a gift. This ring, called Andvaranaut, had the power to create more gold, but it was also cursed by its original owner, Andvari. The curse said that anyone who possessed the ring would bring misfortune and destruction upon themselves.

Despite being warned about the curse, Hreiðmarr kept the ring. Later, his sons Fafnir and Regin killed him to get it. Fafnir wanted the ring for himself and turned into a dragon to protect it. Regin was forced to leave, and Fafnir guarded the treasure until a brave hero named Sigurd came along. Sigurd, with Regin's help, killed the dragon and took the treasure. Unfortunately, Regin was killed by Sigurd soon after for trying to steal the ring. This meant that all of Hreiðmarr's children were now dead.

Note: I've kept the important details and events of the original text, but simplified the language and added explanations for technical terms like "Norse mythology" and "Æsir". I've also avoided copying sentences from the original text and used my own wording to make it easier to understand.

adult_non_technical.text:
Meet Hreiðmarr, a powerful sorcerer from Norse mythology. He's a key character in two important stories: the Völsunga saga and the Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr was a father to five children: Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. He lived in a magnificent house filled with glittering gold and precious gems, built by his son Regin and guarded by his son Fafnir.

Tragedy struck when Ótr, one of Hreiðmarr's sons, was accidentally killed by the mischievous god Loki. The gods of the Æsir, feeling guilty, gave Hreiðmarr a magical ring called Andvaranaut, which could create gold. However, the ring was cursed by its original owner, Andvari, to bring bad luck and destruction to anyone who possessed it. Despite warnings from Loki, Hreiðmarr ignored the curse and kept the ring, which ultimately led to his downfall.

Fafnir, Hreiðmarr's son, became obsessed with the ring and eventually turned into a dragon to protect it. He drove his brother Regin away and killed their father, Hreiðmarr, in a fight over the treasure. Regin later teamed up with a brave warrior named Sigurd to defeat the dragon Fafnir and claim the treasure. However, in the process, Regin was also killed by Sigurd, leaving all of Hreiðmarr's family members dead.

This story is part of a larger cycle of Norse mythology, known as the Völsung Cycle, which explores the themes of family, power, and the consequences of greed.

adult_technical.text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr, a sorcerer of repute, is a significant figure in the Völsunga saga and Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda. As the patriarch of a family of notable individuals, he is the father of Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr.

Hreiðmarr's opulent abode, constructed by his son Regin and guarded by Fafnir, was a testament to his wealth and status. However, his fortunes took a turn for the worse when Ótr was accidentally slain by Loki. In recompense, the Æsir presented Hreiðmarr with Andvari's gold and the ring Andvaranaut, a magical artifact rumored to possess the power to create gold. Unbeknownst to Hreiðmarr, Andvari had placed a curse upon the ring, condemning anyone who possessed it to suffer misfortune and destruction.

Despite Loki's warnings, Hreiðmarr chose to ignore the curse and retain the ring, ultimately leading to his downfall. Fafnir and Regin, driven by their own desires, conspired against their father and killed him in a bid to claim the ring. Fafnir, now consumed by ambition, transformed into a dragon and drove Regin away, guarding the treasure with ferocity. It was not until Sigurd, at Regin's behest, arrived and delivered a fatal blow to the dragon that Fafnir's reign of terror was brought to an end. Tragically, Regin met a similar fate at the hands of Sigurd, who slew him in a struggle over the ring, leaving Hreiðmarr's family line extinct.

References:

* Byock, Jesse L. (1990). Saga of the Volsungs: The Norse Epic of Sigurd the Dragon Slayer. University of California Press.
* Orchard, Andy (1997). Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend. Cassell & Co.

samples.title: Turpin Hills, Ohio
samples.original_text:
Turpin Hills is a census-designated place (CDP) outside of  Anderson Township, Hamilton County, Ohio, United States. The population was 5,099 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Turpin Hills is located at  (39.103620, -84.375073).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
At the 2000 census there were 4,960 people, 1,741 households, and 1,448 families living in the CDP. The population density was 1,668.5 people per square mile (644.8/km). There were 1,810 housing units at an average density of 608.9/sq mi (235.3/km).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 96.63% White, 0.62% African American, 0.34% Native American, 1.63% Asian, 0.30% from other races, and 0.46% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.07%.

Of the 1,741 households 42.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.0% were married couples living together, 6.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 16.8% were non-families. 13.6% of households were one person and 4.0% were one person aged 65 or older. The average household size was 2.85 and the average family size was 3.16.

The age distribution was 30.6% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 26.0% from 25 to 44, 29.2% from 45 to 64, and 9.0% 65 or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 96.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.1 males.

The median household income was $84,354 and the median family income  was $93,471. Males had a median income of $63,077 versus $36,795 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $39,094. About 0.4% of families and 1.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 0.5% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Hamilton County, Ohio
Census-designated places in Ohio

samples.title: Girringun National Park
samples.original_text:
Girringun National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, approximately  southwest of Ingham,  north of Townsville and  northwest of Brisbane.  The park is one of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area series of national parks, and is a gazetted World Heritage Site.

History
The park was originally named the Lumholtz National Park, after scientist Carl Sofus Lumholtz, when it was created in 1994. The Blencoe Falls Section was gazetted as part of Lumholtz National Park in 2000. The name was subsequently changed to Girringun in 2003.  On National Parks Day 2010 (28 March) the Government of Queensland announced the addition of  to the park.

Environment

This large national park consists mainly of wet sclerophyll forests, but small pockets of rainforest also exist along the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George and Cardwell ranges dominate the landscape, which is strewn with granite debris from a volcanic eruption 100,000 years ago. Perhaps the most well known geological feature in this park is the Wallaman Falls. At  it is the largest single-drop falls in Australia.  The park forms part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, identified as such by BirdLife International because it supports populations of a range of bird species endemic to Queensland's Wet Tropics.

Access and infrastructure
Vehicle access into the forest include the Dalrymple Gap Track, or the Wallaman Falls track. However, for most of the park there is only very rudimentary or absent vehicle access. Most of the park is accessible for hikers, but due to its remoteness and rugged terrain only experienced bushwalkers should undertake extensive hikes.

See also

 Herbert River Falls
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Far North Queensland
Protected areas established in 1994
Wet Tropics of Queensland
1994 establishments in Australia
Important Bird Areas of Queensland

adult_non_technical.text:
**Discover Girringun National Park: A Hidden Gem in Queensland, Australia**

Located in the heart of Queensland, Australia, Girringun National Park is a stunning natural wonder that's waiting to be explored. This national park is part of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area, a series of protected areas that showcase the region's unique and diverse ecosystems.

**A Brief History**

The park was first established in 1994 as Lumholtz National Park, named after a scientist who studied the region's unique flora and fauna. Over the years, the park has undergone changes, with the Blencoe Falls Section being added in 2000. In 2003, the park was renamed Girringun, a name that reflects the region's rich cultural heritage. In 2010, the park was expanded to include even more land, making it an even more impressive destination for nature lovers.

**The Park's Unique Environment**

Girringun National Park is home to a mix of wet sclerophyll forests and rainforests, with the Seaview, George, and Cardwell ranges dominating the landscape. The park's unique geology is a result of a volcanic eruption that occurred 100,000 years ago, leaving behind a trail of granite debris. One of the park's most famous attractions is the Wallaman Falls, a stunning single-drop waterfall that's the largest in Australia.

**Birdwatcher's Paradise**

Girringun National Park is also an important habitat for a range of bird species that are endemic to Queensland's Wet Tropics. The park is part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, identified by BirdLife International as a crucial site for bird conservation.

**Getting There and Exploring the Park**

While some parts of the park are accessible by vehicle, much of the park is best explored on foot. The Dalrymple Gap Track and Wallaman Falls track offer scenic drives, but for more adventurous hikers, the park's rugged terrain and remoteness make it an ideal destination for experienced bushwalkers.

**Conclusion**

Girringun National Park is a hidden gem in Queensland, offering a unique blend of natural beauty, geological wonders, and wildlife. Whether you're a nature lover, a bird enthusiast, or an adventure-seeker, this park has something for everyone. So why not start planning your visit today and discover the wonders of Girringun National Park?

Girringun National Park, situated in Queensland, Australia, approximately 270 kilometers southwest of Ingham, 120 kilometers north of Townsville, and 170 kilometers northwest of Brisbane, is a protected area within the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area, a series of national parks recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site.

The park's history dates back to 1994, when it was initially established as the Lumholtz National Park, named after Carl Sofus Lumholtz, a renowned scientist. The Blencoe Falls Section was subsequently added to the park in 2000. In 2003, the park's name was changed to Girringun, reflecting the traditional Indigenous name for the region. On National Parks Day in 2010, the Queensland Government announced the expansion of the park's boundaries.

The park's landscape is characterized by wet sclerophyll forests, with smaller pockets of rainforest found along the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George, and Cardwell ranges dominate the topography, which is marked by granite debris resulting from a volcanic eruption approximately 100,000 years ago. The park is home to the Wallaman Falls, the largest single-drop waterfall in Australia, with a height of 260 meters.

Girringun National Park is also an Important Bird Area, identified by BirdLife International as a critical habitat for a range of bird species endemic to Queensland's Wet Tropics. The park's remote location and rugged terrain make it accessible only to experienced bushwalkers, with limited vehicle access available via the Dalrymple Gap Track or the Wallaman Falls track. However, the park's wilderness areas are open to hikers, offering opportunities for exploration and discovery.

samples.title: FYI
samples.original_text:
"FYI" is a common abbreviation of "for your information".

"FYI" is commonly used in email, instant messaging and other messages to indicate an informational message, with an intent to communicate to the receiver that they may be interested in the given topic, but does not suggest any action or require a response.  It is also commonly used in informal and business spoken conversations.

The usage of "FYI" dates back at least as far as 1941.

Among Internet Standards, FYIs are a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series. The FYI series of notes is designed to provide Internet users with a central repository of information about any topics which relate to the Internet.  FYIs topics may range from historical memos on  "Why it was done that way" to answers to commonly asked operational questions.

References

Initialisms

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

"FYI" is a common abbreviation that stands for "for your information." It's often used in emails, text messages, and other forms of communication to share information with someone, but it doesn't require a response or action from the recipient.

You might use "FYI" when you want to share some news, a fun fact, or a helpful tip with someone, but you're not expecting them to do anything about it. For example, you might send an email to a friend saying "FYI, the new movie is out in theaters this weekend" to let them know about the movie, but you're not asking them to buy tickets or respond to the email.

The use of "FYI" has been around since at least 1941. In the world of the internet, "FYI" is a type of document that provides information about the internet and its workings. These documents, called "FYI notes," cover a range of topics, from the history of how things were done to answers to common questions about how the internet works.

In short, "FYI" is a way to share information with someone without expecting a response or action. It's a helpful way to keep people informed and up-to-date on various topics!

adult_non_technical.text:

You may have seen the abbreviation "FYI" popping up in emails, texts, and conversations. Think of it like a casual heads-up or a tidbit of trivia.

The use of "FYI" has been around since at least the 1940s. In the world of the internet, FYIs are a type of document that provides information on various topics related to the internet. These documents, known as Request for Comments (RFCs), are designed to be a one-stop shop for internet users looking for answers to common questions or explanations on how things work.

FYIs cover a wide range of topics, from the history of why certain internet features were developed to answers to frequently asked questions about how to use the internet. They're like a treasure trove of useful information, and they're available to anyone with an internet connection.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The abbreviation "FYI" is a contraction of "for your information," commonly employed in digital communication, including email, instant messaging, and other forms of electronic messaging. Its purpose is to convey an informational message to the recipient, implying that the topic may be of interest to them, but does not necessitate a response or prompt any action.

The usage of "FYI" has a history dating back to at least 1941. Within the context of Internet Standards, FYIs are a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series, which provides a centralized repository of information on various Internet-related topics. The FYI series encompasses a broad range of subjects, from historical accounts of past decisions and design choices to answers to frequently asked operational questions.

In essence, FYIs serve as a valuable resource for Internet users, offering a comprehensive and easily accessible repository of information on topics relevant to the Internet.

BTR Aerospace Group was a group of four companies formed in 1985 by BTR plc after the acquisition of the Dunlop Aviation Division from Dunlop Rubber. It comprised Dunlop Aviation Division, Aero Engine Equipment, Dunlop Precision Rubber, and Standard Aero (Canada).

In 1996, Dunlop Aircraft Tyres Limited was sold by BTR plc to form an independent company. It is based at Fort Dunlop, Birmingham, England. 

In July 1998, Doughty Hanson & Co purchased BTR Aerospace Group and renamed it Dunlop Standard Aerospace Group.
