samples.title: Extragalactic astronomy
samples.original_text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the branch of astronomy concerned with objects outside the Milky Way galaxy. In other words, it is the study of all astronomical objects which are not covered by galactic astronomy.

The closest objects in extragalactic astronomy include the galaxies of the Local Group, which are close enough to allow very detailed analyses of their contents (e.g. supernova remnants, stellar associations). As instrumentation has improved, distant objects can now be examined in more detail and so extragalactic astronomy includes objects at nearly the edge of the observable universe. Research into distant galaxies (outside of our local group) is valuable for studying aspects of the universe such as galaxy evolution and Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) which give insight into physical phenomena (e.g.  super massive black hole accretion and the presence of dark matter). It is through extragalactic astronomy that astronomers and physicists are able to study the effects of General Relativity such as gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, that are otherwise impossible (or nearly impossible) to study on a galactic scale.

Famous examples 

 Hubble Deep Field
 LIGO's detection of gravitational waves
 Chandra Deep Field South

Topics 
Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), Quasars
Dark Matter
Galaxy clusters, Superclusters
Intergalactic stars
Intergalactic dust
 the observable universe
Radio galaxies
Supernovae
Extragalactic planet

See also
 Andromeda–Milky Way collision
 Galaxy color–magnitude diagram
 Galaxy formation and evolution
 Observational cosmology

References

 
Astronomical sub-disciplines
Physical cosmology
Edwin Hubble

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

Extragalactic astronomy is the study of objects outside our own galaxy, the Milky Way. This includes stars, galaxies, and other objects that are too far away to be studied using the same methods as galactic astronomy.

The closest objects we can study in extragalactic astronomy are the galaxies in our local group, which are close enough for us to learn a lot about their contents, like supernovae and star clusters. As our technology has improved, we can now study objects that are much farther away, almost to the edge of what we can see in the universe.

Studying distant galaxies helps us learn about the universe as a whole. For example, we can learn about how galaxies change over time and how supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies work. We can also learn about dark matter, which is a type of matter that we can't see, but we know it's there because of its effects on the universe.

Some famous examples of extragalactic astronomy include the Hubble Deep Field, which shows a small part of the universe in great detail, and the detection of gravitational waves by LIGO, which helps us understand how the universe works.

Some of the topics that extragalactic astronomers study include:

* Active galaxies with supermassive black holes
* Dark matter and its effects on the universe
* Galaxy clusters and superclusters
* Stars and dust between galaxies
* The observable universe and what we can see in it
* Radio galaxies and supernovae
* Exoplanets outside our own galaxy

If you're interested in learning more, you can also look into topics like the collision between the Andromeda and Milky Way galaxies, how galaxies form and evolve, and the study of the universe as a whole.

adult_non_technical.text:
Exploring the Universe Beyond Our Own Galaxy

Astronomy is the study of the universe, but there's more to it than just looking at the stars and planets in our own galaxy, the Milky Way. Extragalactic astronomy is the branch of astronomy that focuses on objects outside our galaxy, giving us a glimpse into the vastness of the universe beyond our cosmic neighborhood.

We can study nearby galaxies, like those in the Local Group, in great detail, examining their contents, such as supernovae remnants and star clusters. With better technology, we can now examine even more distant objects, right up to the edge of what we can see. This allows us to learn about the evolution of galaxies, supermassive black holes, and dark matter, which are difficult or impossible to study within our own galaxy.

By exploring distant galaxies, we can gain insights into the fundamental laws of physics, such as gravity and the behavior of black holes. For example, we can study how gravity warps space and time, causing strange effects like gravitational lensing, and even detect gravitational waves, which are ripples in the fabric of space-time.

Some notable examples of extragalactic astronomy include the Hubble Deep Field, which captured a stunning image of distant galaxies, and the detection of gravitational waves by LIGO. Other topics of interest include active galactic nuclei, dark matter, galaxy clusters, and the mysterious intergalactic dust that fills the universe.

By exploring the universe beyond our own galaxy, we can gain a deeper understanding of the cosmos and its many mysteries.

adult_technical.text:
Extragalactic astronomy is a subfield of astronomy that focuses on the study of celestial objects beyond the Milky Way galaxy, encompassing all astronomical entities not addressed by galactic astronomy. This discipline has evolved significantly with advancements in instrumentation, enabling the examination of distant objects at the edge of the observable universe.

The Local Group, comprising nearby galaxies, offers a unique opportunity for in-depth analysis of their contents, including supernova remnants and stellar associations. Conversely, the study of distant galaxies outside our local group provides valuable insights into the evolution of galaxies and the behavior of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), which are thought to be powered by supermassive black hole accretion and the presence of dark matter. Extragalactic astronomy also enables the investigation of phenomena that are challenging or impossible to study on a galactic scale, such as gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, which are predicted by General Relativity.

Notable examples of extragalactic astronomy include the Hubble Deep Field, LIGO's detection of gravitational waves, and the Chandra Deep Field South. Research in this field encompasses a range of topics, including:

* Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) and Quasars
* Dark Matter and its role in galaxy evolution
* Galaxy clusters and superclusters
* Intergalactic stars and dust
* The observable universe and its boundaries
* Radio galaxies and their properties
* Supernovae and their role in galaxy evolution
* Extragalactic planets and their potential for hosting life

This field is closely related to other areas of astronomy, such as physical cosmology, and has contributed significantly to our understanding of the universe. Notable astronomers who have made significant contributions to extragalactic astronomy include Edwin Hubble, who first proposed the expansion of the universe, and others who have pushed the boundaries of our understanding of the cosmos.

References:

* Astronomical sub-disciplines: Physical cosmology
* Edwin Hubble

In Hawaiian mythology, Laʻa Maomao is the god of the wind. According to legend, he was born during a time of great turmoil, created by his father, the sun god. Despite being born in chaos, Laʻa Maomao is a kind and forgiving god.

In ancient Hawaiian mythology, there was a powerful god named Laʻa Maomao, who was believed to control the wind. According to legend, he was born in a time of great turmoil, when the world was still in its early stages of creation. His father, the sun god, brought him into being.

Despite being a god, Laʻa Maomao was known for his kind and forgiving nature. He was often called upon to pardon wrongdoings and bring peace to those who sought it.

adult_technical.text:
In Hawaiian mythology, Laʻa Maomao is a deity revered as the patron of the wind. As a benevolent entity, Laʻa Maomao is often associated with the concept of forgiveness, embodying the qualities of mercy and pardon.

It is worth noting that Laʻa Maomao shares similarities with other wind deities in Hawaiian mythology, such as Raka Maomao and Fa'atiu, who also hold significance in the pantheon of Hawaiian gods.

samples.title: Geneva Township, Freeborn County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Geneva Township is a township in Freeborn County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 439 at the 2000 census.

Geneva Township was organized in 1858.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which   is land and   (7.24%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 439 people, 156 households, and 126 families residing in the township.  The population density was 13.3 people per square mile (5.1/km2).  There were 168 housing units at an average density of 5.1/sq mi (2.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.63% White, 0.23% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.23% from other races, and 0.68% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.51% of the population.

There were 156 households, out of which 42.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 70.5% were married couples living together, 6.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 16.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.81 and the average family size was 3.12.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.9% under the age of 18, 6.8% from 18 to 24, 27.6% from 25 to 44, 25.7% from 45 to 64, and 10.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.2 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $46,563, and the median income for a family was $48,594. Males had a median income of $27,045 versus $28,438 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,674.  About 3.2% of families and 5.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 6.1% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Freeborn County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: 266 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 266 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor (or, less frequently, year 488 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 266 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 January 23 – Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrate triumphs over the Salentini.
 Calabria and Messapia are annexed by the Roman Republic.

 Asia Minor 
 Ariobarzanes becomes the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father Mithridates I Ctistes.

 India 
 The Mauryan emperor Ashoka converts to Buddhism.

Births 
 Berenice II, queen and co-regent of Egypt (or 267 BC)

Deaths 
 Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao (b. 310 BC)
 Mithridates I Ctistes, founder of the kingdom of Pontus

References

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

A long time ago, in the year 266 BC, the Roman calendar was different from the one we use today. Back then, it was called the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor. We still use the number 266 BC to refer to this year because it's a way to keep track of time.

Important Events

* In Rome, two important leaders, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo, celebrated big victories over a group of people called the Salentini.
* The Roman Republic took control of two new areas, Calabria and Messapia.
* In a region called Asia Minor, a new king named Ariobarzanes took over the kingdom of Pontus after his father, Mithridates I Ctistes, passed away.
* In India, the powerful emperor Ashoka converted to a new religion called Buddhism.
* In Egypt, a queen named Berenice II was born (or maybe in the following year, 267 BC).

People Who Died

* Huiwen of Zhao, the king of a region called Zhao in China, passed away.
* Mithridates I Ctistes, the founder of the kingdom of Pontus, also died.

Note: I used simple language and broke up long sentences into shorter ones to make it easier to understand. I also avoided technical words like "Anno Domini calendar era" and explained them in simple terms. Let me know if you have any further requests!

In Asia Minor, a new king named Ariobarzanes took over the kingdom of Pontus after his father, Mithridates I Ctistes, passed away.

samples.title: Kilo Ali
samples.original_text:
Andrell D. Rogers (born May 1, 1973), better known as Kilo Ali, formerly Kilo, is an American rapper from Atlanta, Georgia. Kilo Ali recorded mainly bass music (described more closely to Miami bass style music), but also hip-hop tracks with a less distinctive Southern flavor. His most well known singles include "Show Me Love", "Baby Baby", and "Love In Ya Mouth".

As Kilo Ali, he released Organized Bass in 1997 on Interscope, with featured artists including George Clinton, Cee-Lo of Goodie Mob, Big Boi of OutKast, and JT Money. In 2011, Ali was released from prison after serving six years of a 15-year sentence for arson. In June 2021, Ali sued rapper NLE Choppa for copyright infringement for unauthorized use of his 1997 song, "Love In Ya Mouth".

Following a 15-year prison sentence for arson, which he served from 2005 to 2011, Ali resumed his music career.

In 2021, Ali filed a lawsuit against rapper NLE Choppa for copyright infringement, alleging unauthorized use of his 1997 single "Love In Ya Mouth".

samples.title: Slow fire
samples.original_text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe paper embrittlement resulting from acid decay. The term is taken from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record.

Solutions to this problem include the use of acid-free paper stocks, reformatting brittle books by microfilming, photocopying or digitization, and a variety of deacidification techniques.

See also
Acid-free paper
Double Fold
Wood-pulp paper
Preservation: Library and Archival Science

External links
 International Journal of Library Science 
Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts
 Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record
 Slow fires at IMDB

Preservation (library and archival science)

easy_general.text:
**What is a "Slow Fire" in Libraries?**

In libraries, a "slow fire" is a problem that happens when old papers become brittle and break easily because of acid inside the paper. This acid comes from the way the paper was made a long time ago.

**What Causes Slow Fires?**

When paper is made from wood pulp, it can contain acidic chemicals that can damage the paper over time. This makes the paper weak and prone to tearing or breaking.

**How Can We Stop Slow Fires?**

To prevent or fix slow fires, libraries use a few different methods:

* They use special paper that is acid-free, so it won't get damaged as easily.
* They make copies of old books by microfilming, photocopying, or digitizing them, so the originals can be preserved.
* They use special techniques to remove the acid from the paper.

**Learn More**

If you want to learn more about preserving paper and stopping slow fires, you can check out some of the links below:

* International Journal of Library Science
* Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts
* Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record (a film)
* Slow fires at IMDB
* Preservation in library and archival science

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Silent Threat to Our Paper Heritage: Slow Fires**

Imagine a library where books are crumbling to dust, their pages disintegrating before our eyes. This is not a scene from a disaster movie, but a reality that many libraries and archives face today. The culprit behind this destruction is not a fire, but a slow and insidious process called acid decay.

Acid decay occurs when paper, which is made from wood pulp, breaks down over time due to the presence of acidic compounds. This process, also known as "slow fires," can cause books to become brittle and fragile, making them prone to tearing and disintegration.

Fortunately, there are ways to prevent or slow down this process. One solution is to use acid-free paper, which is made from materials that don't contain acidic compounds. Another approach is to digitize or microfilm books, making them easier to preserve and access. Additionally, there are various deacidification techniques that can be used to neutralize the acidity in paper.

By taking these steps, we can help preserve our paper heritage for future generations. It's a crucial task, as our written records and cultural artifacts are a vital part of our history and identity.

**What You Can Do**

* Use acid-free paper for your own documents and projects
* Support libraries and archives in their preservation efforts
* Learn more about the importance of paper preservation and how you can help

**Resources**

* International Journal of Library Science: Extinguishing Slow Fires: Cooperative Preservation Efforts
* Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record (film)
* Preservation: Library and Archival Science (article)

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

In the context of library and information science, the term "slow fire" refers to the degradation of paper caused by acid decay, a process that can lead to embrittlement and eventual disintegration of the material. This concept is rooted in the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 documentary film, "Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record".

To mitigate this issue, various strategies can be employed. These include the use of acid-free paper stocks, which are designed to resist degradation over time. Additionally, brittle books can be preserved through microfilming, photocopying, or digitization, allowing for the creation of durable and accessible copies. Furthermore, deacidification techniques can be applied to neutralize the acidic compounds responsible for the degradation.

For further information, readers may consult the following related topics:

The town of Speed was founded by Andrew Jackson Parker Sr. It was named after the town doctor Eugene Travis Speed Sr.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of , all  land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 70 people, 28 households, and 15 families residing in the town. The population density was 247.3 people per square mile (96.5/km). There were 60 housing units at an average density of 212.0 per square mile (82.7/km). The racial makeup of the town was 51.43% White, 45.71% African American, 2.86% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.86% of the population.

There were 28 households, out of which 21.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 53.6% were married couples living together, and 42.9% were non-families. 42.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 25.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.50 and the average family size was 3.50.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 20.0% under the age of 18, 2.9% from 18 to 24, 25.7% from 25 to 44, 30.0% from 45 to 64, and 21.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 47 years. For every 100 females, there were 100.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 107.4 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $25,938, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $33,333 versus $36,250 for females. samples.title: Francis Hyacinth, Duke of Savoy
samples.original_text:
Francis Hyacinth (; 14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638) was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638 under regency of his mother  Christine Marie.

Biography

Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin he was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy and his wife Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who had died in 1628 prior to the birth of Francis Hyacinth.

At his father's death in October 1637, he succeeded and his mother took power having been claimed regent. While Duke of Savoy he also held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, count of Aosta, Moriana and Nice, and claimant King of Jerusalem. The infant was nicknamed the Flower of Paradise (French: Fleur de Paradis). Having succeeded his father at such a young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto being only 5 years old. Having caught a fever, he died at the Castle of Valentino, and was succeeded by his brother Charles Emmanuel II. The infant was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Ancestry

1638 deaths
17th-century Dukes of Savoy
Nobility from Turin

Princes of Piedmont
Claimant Kings of Jerusalem

Counts of Aosta

When their father died in October 1637, Francis became the new Duke of Savoy, but he was only five years old. Francis was nicknamed the "Flower of Paradise" because of his young age and innocence. Unfortunately, he caught a fever and died at the Castle of Valentino in 1638. He was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Francis's short time as Duke of Savoy was marked by his youth and the fact that his mother had to make decisions for him. He was succeeded by his brother Charles Emmanuel II.

samples.title: John II, Duke of Brabant
samples.original_text:
John II (27 September 1275 – 27 October 1312), also called John the Peaceful, was Duke of Brabant, Lothier and Limburg (1294–1312). He was the son of John I of Brabant and Margaret of Flanders.

John II succeeded his father in 1294 During the reign of John II, Brabant continued supporting a coalition to stop French expansion. He tried to conquer South Holland (district of medieval Holland) from the pro-French Count John II of Holland, but was not successful.

In 1309, the Crusade of the Poor besieged the castle of Genappe in Brabant because it was sheltering Jews. John sent an army that defeated the crusaders, who incurred heavy losses.

John, who suffered from kidney stones and wanted his duchy to be peacefully handed over to his son upon his death, in 1312 signed the famous Charter of Kortenberg. John died in Tervuren in 1312. He was buried in the St. Michael and Gudula Cathedral in Brussels.

Family
On 8 July 1290, John married Margaret of England in Westminster Abbey, London. She was a daughter of King Edward I of England and his first wife, Eleanor of Castile. Only one child was born out of this marriage:
 John III, Duke of Brabant.

John II had several illegitimate children:
 Jan van Corsselaer, was later named Lord of Witthem, Wailwilre, Machelen, la Rochette and Colonster.
 Jan van Wyvliet. Lord of Blaesveld and Kuyc. Married to Margaret Pipenpoy.
 Jan Cordeken: Founder of the House of Glymes. He was legitimized by the emperor Louis IV by charter dated of 27 August 1344, lists John II as the father and Elisabeth Gortygin as his mother.
 Jan Magermann. Married to Adelise d'Elsies.
 Jan II van Dongelberg (- 1383). His mother was Marguerite van Pamel.

John II, also known as John the Peaceful, was the Duke of Brabant, Lothier, and Limburg from 1294 until his death in 1312. He was the son of John I of Brabant and Margaret of Flanders.

Upon his father's demise, John II inherited the duchy and continued to support the coalition against French expansion. He attempted to conquer South Holland from the pro-French Count John II of Holland, but ultimately failed to achieve his objective.

In 1309, the Crusade of the Poor laid siege to the castle of Genappe in Brabant, which was providing shelter to Jews. John II responded by dispatching an army that decisively defeated the crusaders, inflicting significant casualties.

Throughout his reign, John II struggled with kidney stones and sought to ensure a peaceful succession for his son. In 1312, he signed the Charter of Kortenberg, which formalized the transfer of power upon his death. John II passed away in Tervuren later that year and was interred in the St. Michael and Gudula Cathedral in Brussels.

John II's personal life was marked by his marriage to Margaret of England, daughter of King Edward I of England and Eleanor of Castile, in Westminster Abbey, London, on July 8, 1290. The union produced a single legitimate child, John III, Duke of Brabant.

John II also fathered several illegitimate children, including Jan van Corsselaer, later Lord of Witthem, Wailwilre, Machelen, la Rochette, and Colonster; Jan van Wyvliet, Lord of Blaesveld and Kuyc, married to Margaret Pipenpoy; Jan Cordeken, founder of the House of Glymes, legitimized by Emperor Louis IV in 1344; Jan Magermann, married to Adelise d'Elsies; and Jan II van Dongelberg, who died in 1383, with Marguerite van Pamel as his mother.

samples.title: Bindarri National Park
samples.original_text:
Bindarri National Park is a national park in New South Wales, Australia, 431 km northeast of Sydney.

It is considered the epicenter of biodiversity, due to the rare and endangered species found here, such as fish bone fern, southern quassia and palm orchid.

One of the natural beauties of this park is the mouth of the river Urumbilum, which, descending through the Great Escarpment, carved through spectacular waterfalls.

One of the most amazing things about this park is the Urumbilum River, which flows through the park and creates stunning waterfalls as it descends from the Great Escarpment. The river has carved out a beautiful path over time, making it a must-see sight.

If you're interested in learning more about Bindarri National Park, you can visit the official website or check out other resources online.

samples.title: Cubomania
samples.original_text:
Cubomania is a surrealist method of making collages in which a picture or image is cut into squares and the squares are then reassembled without regard for the original image, either automatically "or at random." The word can also mean the collage made using this method, a "rearrangement... suffic[ing] to create an entirely new work."  The technique was invented by the Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca. It has been described as a "statistical method".  Robert Hirsch has seemed to imply that this process can be done with digital photography. Although seemingly a contradiction in terms, at least one cubomania has been made with triangular shapes, rather than rectangles.

Penelope Rosemont and Joseph Jablonski have suggested that cubomania, with other surrealist methods, can "subvert the enslaving 'message' of advertising and to free images from repressive contexts."

Using cubomania as a method for arranging soundscapes has been suggested.

Other meanings
"Cubomania" can also mean "love of cubes", or, specifically, Rubik's Cube.

See also
Cut-up technique
Surautomatism

References

External links
Bill McKeeman Proposed Glossary

Surrealism

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

Cubomania is a fun and creative way to make collages. It involves cutting up a picture or image into small squares, and then rearranging those squares to create a new and unique image. You don't have to worry about keeping the original image intact - you can mix and match the squares in any way you like!

This technique was invented by a Romanian artist named Gherasim Luca, who was part of a group called Surrealism. Surrealism is all about exploring the world of dreams and the subconscious, and cubomania is a way to tap into that world.

Some people think that cubomania can be used to challenge the way we think about images and messages in advertising. By rearranging images in unexpected ways, we can break free from the usual meanings and associations that we have with certain images.

Cubomania isn't just limited to visual art, either. Some people have even suggested using it to create new sounds and music!

But what does "cubomania" mean, exactly? Well, it can also refer to a love of cubes - like the popular puzzle toy, Rubik's Cube. And, of course, it can also refer to the art technique itself.

Overall, cubomania is a fun and creative way to experiment with art and challenge our perceptions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Art of Cubomania: A Surrealistic Twist on Collage**

Imagine taking a picture, breaking it into small squares, and then rearranging those squares to create a completely new image. This is the concept behind cubomania, a surrealist technique that challenges our traditional understanding of art and creativity. Developed by Romanian artist Gherasim Luca, cubomania involves cutting up an image into squares and reassembling them without worrying about the original picture. The result is a unique and often surprising new work of art.

But cubomania isn't just about cutting up pictures. It's also a way to subvert the messages and meanings that are often imposed on us through advertising and other forms of media. By rearranging images in unexpected ways, artists can free themselves from the constraints of traditional representation and create something entirely new.

In fact, cubomania can be applied to other forms of art, too. For example, some artists have used the technique to create new soundscapes by rearranging sounds and music. The possibilities are endless!

Interestingly, the term "cubomania" can also refer to a love of cubes, specifically the popular puzzle toy, Rubik's Cube. But in the context of art, cubomania is all about pushing the boundaries of creativity and challenging our perceptions.

**How it works**

To create a cubomania collage, an artist starts by cutting an image into small squares. They then rearrange these squares to create a new composition, often without worrying about the original meaning or context of the image. The result is a unique and often surprising new work of art that challenges our traditional understanding of representation and meaning.

**The benefits**

By using cubomania, artists can:

* Challenge traditional notions of representation and meaning
* Subvert the messages and meanings imposed by advertising and other forms of media
* Create new and unexpected forms of art
* Experiment with different mediums, such as sound and music

**In conclusion**

Cubomania is a powerful tool for artists and creatives, offering a unique way to challenge our perceptions and push the boundaries of art. By rearranging images and sounds in unexpected ways, we can create new and innovative works that inspire and delight.

adult_technical.text:
Cubomania is a surrealist artistic technique that involves dissecting an image into square fragments and reassembling them in a non-hierarchical, often arbitrary manner, thereby creating a novel composition that diverges from the original image. This method, pioneered by Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca, can be characterized as a statistical approach to collage, as the reassembly process is often driven by chance or automatism.

The technique has been extended to digital photography, as suggested by Robert Hirsch, allowing for the creation of cubomanias that transcend traditional rectangular shapes. In fact, some cubomanias have employed triangular shapes, defying the conventional notion of a square-based composition.

Cubomania has been posited as a means to subvert the dominant narratives and repressive contexts often associated with advertising, as well as to liberate images from their original contexts. This technique can be applied not only to visual art but also to soundscapes, as proposed by some artists.

Beyond its artistic applications, the term "cubomania" can also refer to a fascination with cubes, particularly the iconic Rubik's Cube.

References to related concepts include the cut-up technique and surautomatism, both of which share similarities with cubomania in their emphasis on chance and non-hierarchical composition.

External links:

* Bill McKeeman's Proposed Glossary of Surrealism
* Surrealism

samples.title: Endeavour River National Park
samples.original_text:
Endeavour River National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, gazetted to protect and preserve some of the natural and cultural resources in and around the mouth of the Endeavour River, immediately north of the small town of Cooktown. The park is located  northwest of Brisbane.

Naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected specimens of local 'Australian' flora in 1770 from this area which were taken back to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson first illustrated local Australian Aboriginal people encountered nearby, plus flora collected and fauna seen; and kangaroos were first given their modern English name (borrowing from the local Guugu Yimithirr language).

HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, had struck reefs and been pulled ashore for repairs along the river locally known within Guugu Yimithirr as Wabalumbaal, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was renamed on James Cook's charts as the Endeavour River, after Endeavour, and the current National Park appears, in turn, to be named after the river.

The present National Park contains coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands and the estuary plus parts of the Endeavour River catchment. It is mostly accessible by boat only, and still contains flora and fauna species of the kind collected and illustrated back in 1770.

See also

 Captain Cook mythology: Australia
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

External links
 Map showing area and location of Endeavour River National Park near Cooktown

National parks of Far North Queensland
Protected areas established in 1975
1975 establishments in Australia

They also drew pictures of the local Aboriginal people and the plants and animals they saw. This was the first time Europeans had seen many of these species, and they gave the kangaroo its modern name, which comes from the local Aboriginal language.

The famous ship HM Bark Endeavour, commanded by Captain James Cook, ran aground on the river's reefs and had to be repaired. The river was named after the ship, and the national park was later named after the river.

Today, the park is home to a variety of ecosystems, including coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, and tropical woodlands. The park also includes parts of the Endeavour River and its catchment area. Unfortunately, the park is mostly only accessible by boat, but it still has many of the same plants and animals that were seen and collected by the scientists in 1770.

**Discover the Natural and Cultural Wonders of Endeavour River National Park**

Located in Queensland, Australia, Endeavour River National Park is a protected area that safeguards the region's natural and cultural heritage. Situated near the small town of Cooktown, the park is nestled in the northwest of Brisbane.

In 1770, two naturalists, Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander, collected plant specimens from this area and took them back to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. They also documented the local Aboriginal people and the unique flora and fauna they encountered. Interestingly, the name "kangaroo" was first used to describe this iconic Australian animal, borrowed from the local Guugu Yimithirr language.

The HMS Endeavour, commanded by Lieutenant James Cook, ran aground on the nearby reefs and was repaired along the river, which was later named Endeavour River. The national park, in turn, was named after the river.

Today, the park is home to a diverse range of ecosystems, including coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, and tropical woodlands. The estuary and parts of the Endeavour River catchment are also part of the park. Unfortunately, the park is mostly accessible only by boat, but it still boasts many of the same plant and animal species that were collected and documented over 250 years ago.

**About the Park**

Endeavour River National Park is a unique and fascinating place that offers a glimpse into Australia's rich natural and cultural history. With its diverse ecosystems and rich heritage, it's a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the natural world and learning about the country's indigenous culture.

The area has a rich scientific history, with naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collecting specimens of local flora in 1770, which were subsequently transported to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson's illustrations of the local Aboriginal people, flora, and fauna, as well as the first recorded use of the term "kangaroo" in English, are also significant contributions to the region's cultural heritage.

HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, ran aground on the nearby reefs and was repaired at a site locally known as Wabalumbaal, possibly near the present-day location of Cooktown. Cook renamed the river Endeavour River, and the national park was subsequently established in his honor.

The park's unique biodiversity is characterized by the presence of flora and fauna species that were collected and illustrated by European explorers in the 18th century. Access to the park is primarily by boat, and it remains a vital habitat for a range of species that have remained relatively unchanged since the time of European discovery.

samples.title: Boardman, North Carolina
samples.original_text:
Boardman is a town in Columbus County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 157 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Boardman is located at  (34.439790, -78.948495).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of , of 
which 3.1 square miles (8.1 km2)  is land and  of it (0.64%) is water.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 202 people, 79 households, and 54 families residing in the town. The population density was 64.8 people per square mile (25.0/km2). There were 89 housing units at an average density of 28.6 per square mile (11.0/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 54.46% White, 44.55% African American, 0.99% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.99% of the population.

There were 79 households, out of which 22.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 39.2% were married couples living together, 24.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.4% were non-families. 29.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.56 and the average family size was 3.15.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 23.8% under the age of 18, 9.4% from 18 to 24, 28.7% from 25 to 44, 22.3% from 45 to 64, and 15.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 69.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 69.2 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $20,500, and the median income for a family was $28,333. Males had a median income of $25,500 versus $20,417 for females. The per capita income for the town was $10,339. About 19.0% of families and 27.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 45.5% of those under the age of eighteen and 28.6% of those 65 or over.

References

Towns in North Carolina

samples.title: Psophometric voltage
samples.original_text:
Psophometric voltage is a circuit noise voltage measured with a psophometer that includes a CCIF-1951 weighting network. 

"Psophometric voltage" should not be confused with "psophometric emf," i.e., the emf in a generator or line with 600 Ω internal resistance. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the corresponding psophometric voltage. 

Psophometric voltage readings, V, in millivolts, are commonly converted to dBm(psoph) by dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V – 57.78.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

**What is Psophometric Voltage?**

Psophometric voltage is a type of noise that can be found in electrical circuits. It's measured using a special tool called a psophometer, which includes a special filter that helps to detect this noise.

**Don't Confuse it with Something Else!**

Some people might get confused between psophometric voltage and another type of electrical measurement called psophometric emf. Think of it like this: psophometric emf is like the "pressure" inside a water pipe, while psophometric voltage is like the "ripples" on the surface of the water. For most practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the psophometric voltage.

**How to Measure Psophometric Voltage**

When we measure psophometric voltage, we usually express it in units of millivolts (mV). To make it easier to understand, we can convert these measurements to a different unit called decibels (dBm). This is done using a simple formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 x log10(V) - 57.78, where V is the voltage reading in millivolts.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Understanding Psophometric Voltage: A Key Measure of Circuit Noise**

When it comes to electronics, noise can be a major problem. It's like trying to have a conversation in a busy restaurant - you can't hear what the other person is saying because of all the background chatter. In the world of electronics, this "chatter" is known as circuit noise, and it can be caused by a variety of factors, from faulty wiring to interference from other devices.

To measure this noise, engineers use a special tool called a psophometer. This device uses a special filter, known as a CCIF-1951 weighting network, to detect the noise and give a reading of its strength. This reading is called the psophometric voltage.

It's important to note that psophometric voltage is different from another type of electrical measurement called emf (electromotive force). Emf is the force that drives an electric current through a circuit, and it's often measured in devices like generators or power lines. Psophometric voltage, on the other hand, is a specific type of noise that's measured in a particular way.

When engineers take a reading of the psophometric voltage, they usually convert it into a unit called decibels (dBm(psoph)). This is done using a simple formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 log10(V) - 57.78, where V is the voltage reading in millivolts.

In simple terms, this formula helps engineers to compare the strength of different types of noise and to identify the sources of the noise in a circuit. By understanding and measuring psophometric voltage, engineers can design and build more reliable and efficient electronic systems that are less prone to noise and interference.

adult_technical.text:
Here is a rewritten version of the text for an adult reader with a technical background in the topic:

The psophometric voltage is a measure of circuit noise voltage, typically assessed using a psophometer equipped with a CCIF-1951 weighting network. It is essential to distinguish this concept from psophometric electromotive force (emf), which refers to the emf present in a generator or transmission line with an internal resistance of 600 ohms. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is equivalent to twice the corresponding psophometric voltage.

The psophometric voltage readings, typically expressed in millivolts, are often converted to decibels relative to one milliwatt (dBm) using the formula dBm(psoph) = 20 log10(V) - 57.78, where V represents the voltage reading.

Note: I've kept the same structure and content as the original text, but rephrased it to use more precise technical terminology and avoid ambiguity. I've also added a brief clarification to distinguish between psophometric voltage and psophometric emf, as requested.

samples.title: Aristodemus
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus (Ancient Greek: Ἀριστόδημος) was one of the Heracleidae, son of Aristomachus and brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. He was a great-great-grandson of Heracles and helped lead the fifth and final attack on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers complained to the Oracle that its instructions had proved fatal to those who had followed them (the Oracle had told Hyllas to attack through the narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe). They received the answer that by the "third fruit" the "third generation" was meant, and that the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium. They accordingly built a fleet at Naupactus, but before they set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning (or shot by Apollo) and the fleet destroyed, because one of the Heraclidae had slain an Acarnanian soothsayer.

His brothers were later able to conquer the Peloponnese.

By his wife Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, he was the father of twin Kings Eurysthenes and Procles, the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources
Diodorus Siculus, iv. 57, 58.
Pausanias, i. 32, 41, ii. 13, 18, iii. I, iv. 3, v. 3.
Euripides, Heraclidae.
Pindar, Pythia, ix. 137.
Herodotus, ix. 27.
Karl Otfried Müller. Dorians, Part I, Chapter 3.
Connop Thirlwall. History of Greece, Chapter VII.
George Grote. History of Greece, Part I, Chapter XVIII.
Georg Busolt. Griechische Geschichte, Part I, Chapter 11, Section 7, where a list of authorities is given.

References

Heracleidae
Ancient Messenians

Aristodemus was a famous figure in ancient Greek mythology. He was a descendant of Heracles, a legendary hero, and was part of a group called the Heracleidae. Aristodemus had two brothers, Cresphontes and Temenus, and together they were trying to conquer the region of Mycenae in Greece.

However, their plans were foiled when they received confusing instructions from the Oracle, a wise and powerful being. The Oracle told them to attack through a narrow passage when a certain fruit was ripe, but Aristodemus and his brothers misunderstood the message. They thought the "narrow passage" was a physical path, not a metaphorical one. As a result, they built a fleet of ships to attack through the wrong place.

Tragedy struck when Aristodemus was struck by lightning (or possibly shot by the god Apollo) before they could set sail. The fleet was destroyed, and the brothers' plans were ruined. Despite this setback, Aristodemus' brothers were eventually able to conquer the region.

Aristodemus was also the father of twin sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who went on to become kings of Sparta. His wife, Argia, was the daughter of a king from Thebes.

Sources:

* Ancient Greek historians like Diodorus Siculus, Pausanias, and Herodotus wrote about Aristodemus and his family.
* Poets like Euripides and Pindar also mentioned him in their works.
* Modern historians like Karl Otfried Müller, Connop Thirlwall, George Grote, and Georg Busolt have studied Aristodemus and his role in Greek history.

Note: I've kept the original text's focus on Aristodemus and his story, while simplifying the language and removing technical terms whenever possible. I've also added a brief explanation of the Oracle and the concept of a metaphorical "narrow passage" to help readers understand the story better.

Aristodemus and his brothers, Cresphontes and Temenus, were frustrated with the Oracle's instructions, which had led to the downfall of their predecessors. They asked the Oracle to clarify its message, and it revealed that the "third fruit" referred to the third generation, not a specific fruit, and the "narrow passage" was actually a different route altogether. The brothers decided to build a fleet at Naupactus, but before they set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning (or, according to some accounts, killed by the god Apollo) and the fleet was destroyed. This was because one of the Heraclidae had killed a soothsayer from the region.

Despite this setback, Aristodemus' brothers went on to conquer the Peloponnese region.

Aristodemus was married to Argia, the daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, and they had twin sons, Eurysthenes and Procles. These sons would go on to become the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

The stories of Aristodemus and his family can be found in various ancient Greek texts, including works by Diodorus Siculus, Pausanias, Euripides, Pindar, Herodotus, and others.

adult_technical.text:
Aristodemus, a scion of the Heracleidae, was the son of Aristomachus and brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. As a great-great-grandson of Heracles, he played a pivotal role in the fifth and final assault on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers initially disputed the Oracle's instructions, which had led to the downfall of previous expeditions. The Oracle's enigmatic response, which referred to the "third fruit" and the "narrow passage," was clarified to mean the third generation and the straits of Rhium, respectively. Undeterred, the Heraclidae constructed a fleet at Naupactus, but Aristodemus's untimely demise, allegedly caused by a lightning strike or an arrow from Apollo, and the subsequent destruction of the fleet, thwarted their plans. The reason for this calamity was the murder of an Acarnanian soothsayer by one of the Heraclidae.

Subsequently, Aristodemus's brothers succeeded in conquering the Peloponnese.

Through his marriage to Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, Aristodemus fathered twin sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who would go on to become the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources:

samples.original_text:
Southern Moreton Bay Islands is a national park in Queensland, Australia, 44 km southeast of Brisbane.  It forms part of the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, so identified by BirdLife International because it supports large numbers of migratory waders, or shorebirds.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

This park is special because it's an important place for many types of birds that migrate to Australia each year. These birds, called shorebirds, stop here to rest and refuel before continuing their journey.

In fact, this area is so important for these birds that it's been recognized as an Important Bird Area by BirdLife International. This means that conservation efforts are in place to protect the park and its wildlife.

If you're interested in learning more about protected areas in Queensland or national parks in South East Queensland, there are some helpful resources listed below.

This special place is part of a larger protected area known as the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, recognized by BirdLife International for its significance in supporting the migration of thousands of shorebirds.

These birds, also known as waders, travel from distant lands to rest and refuel in this unique ecosystem, making it a vital stopover point on their incredible journeys. As a national park, the Southern Moreton Bay Islands is protected to preserve its natural beauty and biodiversity, ensuring that future generations can continue to enjoy this incredible natural wonder.

The Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park, situated approximately 44 kilometers southeast of Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, is a vital component of the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, as designated by BirdLife International. This designation is due to the region's capacity to support substantial populations of migratory waders, also known as shorebirds.

The park's ecological significance is underscored by its inclusion in the protected areas of Queensland, a testament to the state's commitment to conservation and biodiversity preservation. Furthermore, the Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park is part of the broader network of national parks in South East Queensland, which collectively provide a vital habitat for a diverse range of flora and fauna.

In addition to its ecological importance, the park is also recognized as an Important Bird Area, a designation that highlights its critical role in supporting the migratory patterns of various bird species. This recognition is a testament to the park's unique environmental characteristics and its ability to provide a vital stopover point for these migratory birds.

References:

* Protected areas of Queensland
* National parks of South East Queensland
* Important Bird Areas of Queensland
* Islands of Moreton Bay

samples.title: Transmission level point
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a transmission level point (TLP) is a physical test point in an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where a test signal may be inserted or measured.  Typically, various parameters, such as the power of the signal, noise, or test tones inserted are specified or measured at the TLP.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is a function of system design and is an expression of the design gain or attenuation (loss).

Voice-channel transmission levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of ca. 1000 hertz. The dBm is an absolute level with respect to 1 mW. The TLP is thus characterized by the relation:

TLP = dBm — dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP,  the test point is called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. In general, the term TLP is commonly used as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, the expression 0TLP refers to a .  At a −16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm.

See also
 Alignment level
 Nominal level

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

In telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a special spot in an electronic circuit where we can test the signal being sent. This spot is usually a channel that carries the signal, and we can insert a test signal or measure the signal's strength at this point.

The strength of the signal at a TLP is determined by the design of the system and is a measure of how much the signal is amplified or weakened.

When we measure the strength of a voice signal at a TLP, we use a unit called decibel-milliwatts (dBm). This unit is based on a reference point of 1 milliwatt. The TLP is defined by a simple equation:

TLP = dBm - dBm0

When the signal strength is 0 dBm at the TLP, it's called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. We often use the term TLP as if it were a unit, adding the nominal level to it. For example, "0TLP" means the signal strength is 0 dBm. If the signal strength is -16 dBm, it's like saying the signal is 16 dBm stronger than the reference point.

When we connect an instrument, like a phone, to a TLP, the signal strength is usually set to 0 dBm.

Note: I removed the technical terms "nominal transmission level" and "design gain or attenuation" and replaced them with simpler language. I also added a brief explanation of decibel-milliwatts (dBm) to help readers understand the unit. Let me know if you'd like me to make any further changes!

adult_non_technical.text:
**Understanding Transmission Level Points in Telecommunications**

In the world of telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a specific spot in an electronic circuit where we can insert or measure a test signal. This signal can be a voice, data, or any other type of communication. At this point, we can check various characteristics, such as the strength of the signal, the level of noise, or the presence of test tones.

The strength of the signal at a TLP is determined by the design of the system and is a measure of how much the signal is amplified or reduced. For voice channels, we typically measure the signal strength in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of around 1000 hertz. Think of dBm like a volume control on your stereo - it's a way to measure how loud or soft the signal is.

A TLP is characterized by a specific level, which is usually expressed as a number followed by "TLP". For example, a 0TLP means the signal is at its normal strength, while a -16TLP means the signal is 16 decibels weaker than normal. When we connect an end instrument, like a phone, to a TLP, the signal level is usually set to 0dBm, which is the standard reference point.

In summary, a transmission level point is a crucial spot in a telecommunications system where we can test and measure the strength of a signal. By understanding the level at this point, we can ensure that our communication systems are working properly and efficiently.

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a physical location within an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where a test signal can be injected or measured. At this point, various parameters such as signal power, noise, or test tones are specified or measured.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is a function of the system design and represents the design gain or attenuation (loss) of the system. In voice-channel transmission, levels at test points are typically measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of approximately 1000 Hz. The dBm scale is an absolute measure, referenced to 1 milliwatt.

The TLP is characterized by the relationship:

TLP = measured level (dBm) - reference level (dBm0)

When the nominal signal power is 0 dBm at the TLP, the test point is referred to as a zero transmission level point or zero-dBm TLP. The term TLP is often used as a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, the expression "0TLP" refers to a test point with a nominal level of 0 dBm. Conversely, a level of -16TLP indicates a measured level of +16 dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is typically specified as 0 dBm. This reference level serves as a baseline for measuring signal levels in the system.

Note: The rewritten text maintains the same level of technical detail as the original, using precise terminology and avoiding simplification. It also maintains the same structure and organization as the original text, with the addition of a brief clarification on the dBm scale.

samples.title: X-dimension of recorded spot
samples.original_text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of recorded spot is the effective recorded spot dimension measured in the direction of the recorded line. The effective recorded spot dimension" is the largest center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, which gives minimum peak-to-peak variation of density of the recorded line. X-dimension of recorded spot implies that the facsimile equipment response to a constant density in the object (original) is a succession of discrete recorded spots.

References

Fax

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text:

When we talk about fax machines, the "X-dimension" refers to the distance between the centers of the tiny dots that make up the image being sent. This distance is important because it affects how clear the image looks.

Think of it like a puzzle: the X-dimension is the distance between the centers of the puzzle pieces that make up the picture. If the pieces are too close together, the picture might look blurry. If they're too far apart, the picture might look pixelated.

In a fax machine, the X-dimension is the distance between the tiny dots that make up the image. The machine reads the original image and breaks it down into these tiny dots, which are then sent over the phone line. When the receiving machine gets the dots, it puts them back together to create the final image.

So, the X-dimension is important because it determines how well the fax machine can capture the details of the original image. If the X-dimension is too small, the image might look blurry or fuzzy. If it's too large, the image might look pixelated or grainy.

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text in plain language:

"When we talk about fax machines, the X-dimension of a recorded spot refers to the distance between the centers of two adjacent spots on a line. This distance is important because it determines the minimum amount of variation in the density of the line. Think of it like this: when a fax machine reads a document, it breaks it down into a series of tiny dots, or spots. The X-dimension is the distance between the centers of these dots.

In other words, the X-dimension is a measure of how well the fax machine responds to a consistent density in the original document. If the X-dimension is small, the fax machine will be able to capture the details of the document more accurately, resulting in a clearer and more precise copy."

adult_technical.text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of the recorded spot refers to the effective recorded spot dimension measured along the direction of the recorded line. This dimension represents the maximum center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, which yields the minimum peak-to-peak variation in the density of the recorded line. The X-dimension of the recorded spot is a fundamental characteristic of fax systems, as it describes the manner in which the facsimile equipment responds to a constant density in the original object by producing a sequence of discrete recorded spots.

Note: I've kept the same level of technical detail as the original text, using precise terminology and avoiding simplifications. I've also rephrased the sentences to improve clarity and flow, while maintaining the original meaning and content.

samples.title: Tunneling
samples.original_text:
Tunneling or tunnelling may refer to:

 Digging tunnels (the literal meaning)
Hobby tunneling
 Quantum tunneling, the quantum-mechanical effect where a particle crosses through a classically forbidden potential energy barrier
 Tunneling (fraud), a fraud committed by a company's own management or by major shareholders
 Tunneling protocol, transmitting one computer network protocol that is encapsulated inside another network protocol

See also
 
 
 Tunnel (disambiguation)

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

Tunneling can refer to a few different things. Here are a few examples:

* Digging tunnels: This is the most obvious meaning. It's when people dig holes or channels underground, like for a subway or a sewer.
* Hobby tunneling: Some people enjoy digging tunnels as a hobby. They might dig tunnels in their backyard or in a park.
* Quantum tunneling: This is a scientific concept that's a bit more complicated. It's when tiny particles, like atoms or electrons, can pass through a barrier that would normally stop them. It's like if you were trying to get through a fence, but you could somehow slip through a tiny hole that's too small for you to see.
* Tunneling (fraud): Unfortunately, some people use the word "tunneling" to describe a type of fraud. This is when someone in charge of a company or a group of people secretly takes money or resources for themselves.
* Tunneling protocol: This is a technical term that refers to a way that computers can send information through the internet. It's like sending a message in a bottle, but instead of a bottle, it's a special kind of package that can travel through the internet.

If you're looking for more information on any of these topics, you can check out the links below.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Tunneling: More Than Just Digging Holes**

When we think of tunneling, we often imagine digging tunnels underground or through mountains. But did you know that the term has several other meanings beyond just digging?

One type of tunneling is a hobby where enthusiasts dig tunnels for fun, often in sand or soil. This can be a fun and creative activity for those who enjoy digging and exploring.

But tunneling can also refer to a fascinating phenomenon in the world of physics called quantum tunneling. In this case, tiny particles like electrons can pass through seemingly impenetrable barriers, defying the laws of classical physics. This is because at a quantum level, particles can exhibit strange and unpredictable behavior.

In the business world, tunneling can also refer to a type of fraud where company executives or major shareholders secretly siphon off funds or resources for their own gain. This is a serious issue that can have devastating consequences for the company and its employees.

Finally, tunneling can also refer to a way of transmitting data between computer networks. In this context, one network protocol is wrapped inside another, allowing data to be sent securely and efficiently.

So, the next time you hear someone mention tunneling, remember that it's not just about digging holes – it's a term with many different meanings and applications!

adult_technical.text:
Here is a rewritten version of the text for an adult reader with a technical background:

The term "tunneling" encompasses several distinct concepts, each with its own unique context and significance.

Firstly, tunneling refers to the physical process of excavating a subterranean passageway, typically through soil, rock, or other geological formations. This literal meaning is often associated with civil engineering, mining, and construction projects.

In the realm of physics, tunneling describes the phenomenon of quantum-mechanical particles traversing a classically forbidden energy barrier. This quantum tunneling effect is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics, where particles can exhibit wave-like behavior and penetrate seemingly impenetrable barriers.

In the context of finance and business, tunneling refers to a type of fraud perpetrated by corporate management or major shareholders, where funds are diverted from a company for personal gain or to benefit specific individuals.

Furthermore, tunneling protocol is a networking technique that involves encapsulating one network protocol within another, allowing for the transmission of data across different network layers. This protocol is essential for ensuring secure and efficient communication over the internet.

For a comprehensive understanding of the term "tunneling," it is essential to consider these distinct meanings and their respective applications.

**What is a Route?**

* In computer science, a route is a program that helps decide how data gets sent from one place to another.
* In geography, a route can be a specific area or path, like a route in Northern Ireland or a commune in France.

**Other Meanings of Route**

* A GPS route is a series of points that a GPS device uses to guide you to your destination.
* A scenic route is a road that's designated as beautiful or interesting because of the views along the way.

**Other Words Related to Route**

* Routing is the process of deciding how data gets sent from one place to another.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

A route can refer to different things, but they all have one thing in common: they're a path or a way to get from one place to another.

In sports, a route is a path that a wide receiver runs to catch a ball in American football. It's like a secret recipe for success on the field!

In geography, a route can be a specific area or a path that connects two places. For example, there's a Route in Northern Ireland and a commune called Routes in France.

In entertainment, there's a 2013 film called The Route and a video game called Routes.

But that's not all! A route can also refer to:

* A GPS route, which is a series of points that a GPS device uses to guide you from one place to another.

And if you're feeling adventurous, you can even take a route number or road number to get to your destination!

In the military, a rout is when a group of soldiers retreats quickly and disorderly from a battle. And in woodworking, a router is a tool used to shape and smooth wood.

So, that's what a route is! It's a path, a way, or a journey that can take many forms.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The term "route" can have multiple meanings depending on the context. In the context of American football, a route refers to a predetermined path run by a wide receiver to receive a pass from the quarterback.

Geographically, Route can also refer to a specific area, such as Route, County Antrim, a region in Northern Ireland, or Routes, Seine-Maritime, a commune in France.

In the realm of entertainment, The Route is a 2013 Ugandan film, while Routes is a 2003 video game.

Additionally, the term "route" can be used in various other contexts, including:

samples.title: Joule per mole
samples.original_text:
The joule per mole (symbol: J·mol−1 or J/mol) is an SI derived unit of energy per amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For example, Gibbs free energy is quantified as joules per mole. It is also a SI derived unit of molar thermodynamic energy defined as the energy equal to one joule in one mole of substance. 

Since 1 mole = 6.02214076×1023 particles (atoms, molecules, ions etc.), 1 joule per mole is equal to 1 joule divided by 6.02214076×1023 particles, 1.66054×10−24 joule per particle. This very small amount of energy is often expressed in terms of a smaller unit such as the electronvolt (eV, see below).

Physical quantities measured in J·mol−1 usually describe quantities of energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. Division by the number of moles facilitates comparison between processes involving different quantities of material and between similar processes involving different types of materials.  The precise meaning of such a quantity is dependent on the context (what substances are involved, circumstances, etc.), but the unit of measurement is used specifically to describe certain existing phenomena, such as in thermodynamics it is the unit of measurement that describes molar energy.

For convenience and due to the range of magnitudes involved these quantities are almost always reported in kJ·mol−1 rather than in J·mol−1. For example, heats of fusion and vaporization are usually of the order of 10 kJ·mol−1, bond energies are of the order of 100 kJ·mol−1, and ionization energies of the order of 1000 kJ·mol−1. 

1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.239 kcal·mol−1, 1.04×10−2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm−1. At room temperature (25 °C, 77 °F, or 298.15 K) 1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.4034 .

References 

SI derived units

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

The joule per mole (J/mol) is a unit of measurement that shows how much energy is in a certain amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For example, scientists use this unit to measure the energy needed to change the state of a substance, like melting or boiling.

One mole is equal to a really big number of tiny particles, like atoms or molecules - 6.022 x 10^23 to be exact. So, if we divide 1 joule by this huge number, we get a very small amount of energy, about 1.66 x 10^-24 joules per particle. This tiny amount of energy is often measured in a smaller unit called electronvolts (eV).

Scientists use the joule per mole unit to compare different processes that involve different amounts of material or different types of materials. For example, they might use it to measure the energy needed to melt or boil a substance, or to break a chemical bond. The meaning of this unit depends on the specific situation, but it's always used to describe energy changes in materials.

Because the amounts of energy involved can be really big or really small, scientists often use a bigger unit called kilojoules per mole (kJ/mol) instead of joules per mole. For example, the energy needed to melt or boil a substance might be around 10-1000 kJ/mol. To help you understand just how big or small these numbers are, 1 kJ/mol is equal to about 0.24 kcal/mol, 0.104 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm^-1.

At room temperature, 1 kJ/mol is equal to about 0.4034.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Understanding Joules per Mole: A Measure of Energy**

When we talk about energy, we often use the term "joule" (J). But what does it mean when we add "per mole" to it? In simple terms, a mole is a unit of measurement that represents a huge number of tiny particles, like atoms or molecules. So, joules per mole (J/mol) is a way to measure the energy of a specific amount of material.

Think of it like a recipe. Imagine you're baking a cake that requires 2 cups of flour. The recipe might say the energy needed to mix the ingredients is 100 joules. But what if you wanted to make a smaller or larger cake? You'd need to adjust the amount of energy accordingly. That's where joules per mole comes in. It helps us compare the energy needed for different amounts of material, whether it's a small or large batch.

Joules per mole is also used to describe the energy involved in chemical reactions or phase changes, like when a solid turns into a liquid or a gas. By dividing the energy by the number of moles, we can compare these processes more easily.

In practice, we often use a larger unit of measurement, called kilojoules per mole (kJ/mol), which is equal to 1,000 joules per mole. This makes it easier to work with larger amounts of energy. For example, the energy needed to melt a substance might be around 10 kJ/mol, while the energy needed to break a chemical bond might be around 100 kJ/mol.

To give you an idea of just how small these amounts are, 1 kJ/mol is equivalent to about 0.24 calories per mole, or 0.04 electronvolts per particle. At room temperature, 1 kJ/mol is equivalent to about 0.4034 calories.

In summary, joules per mole is a unit of measurement that helps us understand the energy of a specific amount of material. By using this unit, we can compare and analyze different processes involving energy, making it a powerful tool in fields like chemistry and physics.

adult_technical.text:
The joule per mole (J·mol−1) is a derived SI unit of energy per amount of substance, where energy is measured in joules and the amount of substance is measured in moles. This unit is particularly relevant in thermodynamics, where it is used to quantify molar energy. For instance, Gibbs free energy is expressed in J·mol−1.

The relationship between J·mol−1 and the number of particles in a mole is established by the Avogadro constant, which defines 1 mole as 6.02214076 × 10^23 particles (atoms, molecules, ions, etc.). Therefore, 1 J·mol−1 is equivalent to 1 J divided by 6.02214076 × 10^23 particles, or approximately 1.66054 × 10^−24 J per particle. This extremely small energy value is often expressed in smaller units, such as electronvolts (eV).

Physical quantities measured in J·mol−1 typically describe energy transfers during phase transformations or chemical reactions. By dividing the energy by the number of moles, it becomes possible to compare processes involving different quantities of material and similar processes involving different types of materials. The precise meaning of such a quantity depends on the context, including the substances involved and the circumstances. However, the unit of measurement is specifically used to describe certain phenomena, such as molar energy in thermodynamics.

For practical purposes, these quantities are usually reported in kilojoules per mole (kJ·mol−1) due to the wide range of magnitudes involved. For example, heats of fusion and vaporization typically range from 10 to 100 kJ·mol−1, bond energies range from 100 to 1000 kJ·mol−1, and ionization energies range from 1000 to 10,000 kJ·mol−1.

1 kJ·mol−1 is equivalent to 0.239 kcal·mol−1, 1.04 × 10^−2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm^−1. At room temperature (25 °C, 77 °F, or 298.15 K), 1 kJ·mol−1 is equivalent to 0.4034.
