samples.title: Gentlemen, Be Seated!
samples.original_text:
"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction short story by American writer Robert A. Heinlein.  It was first published in the May 1948 issue of Argosy magazine.  It was later included in two of Heinlein's collections, The Green Hills of Earth (1951), and The Past Through Tomorrow (1967).

Plot summary

The story tells of a visit to a tunnel on the surface of the Moon which goes awry when a pressure seal fails, trapping three men (a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker). The title of the story derives from the way they plug an air leak while awaiting rescue: by sitting on it.

The phrase "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" is the opening line of the interlocutor in a traditional minstrel show. It was also, at the time the story was written and while Heinlein attended, the opening line for all classes at the military and naval academies (as well as classes for officers at the various service schools) in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by an episode in "Baron Munchausen": The ship sprung a leak. It was my good fortune to discover it first. I found it a large hole about a foot diameter. ... This noble vessel was preserved, with all its crew, by a most fortunate thought! in short, I sat down over it. ... My situation, while I sat there, was rather cool, but the carpenter's art soon relieved me.

References

External links
 

1948 short stories
Short stories by Robert A. Heinlein
Works originally published in Argosy (magazine)

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction story written by Robert A. Heinlein. It was first published in a magazine called Argosy in May 1948. Later, it was included in two of Heinlein's book collections.

The story is about three men - a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker - who visit a tunnel on the Moon's surface. But things go wrong when a pressure seal fails, trapping them inside. The men have to wait for help to arrive, and in the meantime, they use a clever trick to plug the air leak: they sit on it!

The title "Gentlemen, Be Seated" comes from a phrase often used in old-fashioned minstrel shows. It was also used as a way to get students to sit down in classes at military and naval academies in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by a famous tale called "Baron Munchausen," where a character fixes a leak in his ship by sitting on it. The idea of sitting on a hole to stop it from getting worse is a clever and humorous solution.

I hope this rewritten text is easier to understand and more engaging for a general reader!

adult_non_technical.text:
"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction short story written by American author Robert A. Heinlein. It was first published in 1948 in a magazine called Argosy, and later included in two of Heinlein's collections.

The story takes place on the surface of the Moon, where three men - a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker - find themselves trapped in a tunnel after a pressure seal fails. The men are waiting for rescue, but in the meantime, they need to find a way to stop the air from leaking out. They do this by sitting on the hole, effectively plugging it.

The title of the story comes from a phrase that was commonly used in the past, particularly in the military and naval academies in the United States. It was also used in traditional minstrel shows, where it was the opening line of the interlocutor.

The idea for the story might have been inspired by a famous tale from the 18th-century novel "Baron Munchausen", where a character sits on a hole in a ship to stop it from sinking.

"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a classic science fiction story that explores the themes of teamwork, quick thinking, and resourcefulness in the face of adversity.

adult_technical.text:
" Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction short story penned by American author Robert A. Heinlein, first published in the May 1948 issue of Argosy magazine. The narrative has since been included in two of Heinlein's collections, The Green Hills of Earth (1951) and The Past Through Tomorrow (1967).

The story revolves around a catastrophic event that unfolds when a pressure seal fails on a lunar tunnel, trapping three individuals - a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker. In their desperate bid to conserve air, they employ an unconventional method to plug the leak, literally sitting on it.

The title "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" is a nod to the opening phrase of an interlocutor in traditional minstrel shows, as well as the standard opening line for classes at military and naval academies in the United States during the time Heinlein attended and wrote the story.

The narrative bears some resemblance to an episode from "Baron Munchausen," where a character's quick thinking and resourcefulness save the day by sitting on a hole in a ship's hull. This clever solution serves as a testament to the power of creative problem-solving in the face of adversity.

References:

* Heinlein, R. A. (1948). "Gentlemen, Be Seated". Argosy magazine.
* Heinlein, R. A. (1951). The Green Hills of Earth.
* Heinlein, R. A. (1967). The Past Through Tomorrow.

Events

End of Period IVB, Hasanlu is completely destroyed by a fire.
The Greek Colonization of the Mediterranean & Black Sea.

Homer of Greece writes his Iliad and Odyssey. ( - 700 BCE)

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

**Important Events**

* Around 830 BC, a king named Polydectes stopped being the ruler of Sparta.
* A new king, Eunomus, took over and ruled until 780 BC.
* In Peru, people started building communities in the Chincha Valley, which was part of the Paracas culture.
* A big fire destroyed the city of Hasanlu in ancient Persia (modern-day Iran).
* The ancient Greeks started colonizing the Mediterranean and Black Sea.
* In Greece, a period called the Archaic period began, which lasted until around 500 BC.
* A famous Greek poet named Homer wrote his epic poems, the Iliad and Odyssey, around 700 BC.
* The Assyrian army discovered a way to make iron stronger by mixing it with other metals, which made their weapons more powerful.
* In Egypt, people started using sundials, which are ancient clocks that use the sun's shadow to tell time.
* In Britain, the Iron Age began, which lasted until the Roman Empire took over in 43 AD.

**Sad News**

* Xiong Xun, the king of the state of Chu in ancient China, passed away.
* Archaeologists found the remains of two people, possibly a couple, at a site called Teppe Hasanlu. They were nicknamed the "Hasanlu Lovers".

Note: I kept the original dates and events, but rephrased them in simpler language and added some explanations to help readers understand the context. I also removed the technical terms and replaced them with simpler words. Let me know if you'd like me to make any changes!

adult_non_technical.text:
**Ancient Times: A Year in Review**

In 830 BC, the king of Sparta, Polydectes, stepped down, and Eunomus took the throne, ruling until 780 BC. Meanwhile, in South America, the Paracas culture was thriving in the Chincha Valley of Peru, with the first communities settling in the region.

In the ancient world, significant events were unfolding. The city of Hasanlu in modern-day Iran was destroyed by a devastating fire, marking the end of Period IVB. The Greek world was also experiencing a period of growth, with the colonization of the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions. In Greece itself, the Archaic period was underway, a time of cultural and artistic flourishing.

It was also a time of great literary achievement, as Homer, a renowned Greek poet, wrote his epic poems, the Iliad and Odyssey. These works would go on to shape Western literature for centuries to come.

In the world of technology, the Assyrian army was making innovative use of a new technique that allowed them to harden iron into steel, making it suitable for weapons. In Egypt, the earliest surviving sundial was in use, marking the passage of time with remarkable accuracy.

In Britain, the Iron Age had begun, a period that would last until the Roman conquest in 43 AD. Tragically, this was also a time of loss, as Xiong Xun, the monarch of the state of Chu in ancient China, passed away. In a more poignant discovery, the remains of a pair of lovers, known as the Hasanlu Lovers, were found at the ancient site of Teppe Hasanlu.

These events, spanning the ancient world from Greece to China, Peru, and beyond, offer a glimpse into the fascinating history of our ancestors.

adult_technical.text:

Historical Events and Milestones (circa 830-700 BCE)

The Spartan monarchy underwent a significant transition with the demise of King Polydectes, who ruled from 830 BC, and the ascension of Eunomus, who would reign until 780 BC.

In the Americas, the Paracas culture began to take shape in the Chincha Valley of southern Peru, as the first settled communities emerged.

In the ancient Near East, the city of Hasanlu suffered a devastating conflagration, marking the end of Period IVB. This event had a profound impact on the region, as it led to the destruction of the city and its cultural heritage.

The Archaic period in Greece was marked by the establishment of Greek colonies in the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions. This period, which spanned from circa 800 to 500 BCE, was also notable for the literary achievements of Homer, who composed his epic poems, the Iliad and Odyssey, around 700 BCE.

In technological advancements, the Assyrian army made significant strides in metallurgy, developing techniques to harden iron into steel suitable for use in weapons. This innovation had far-reaching implications for warfare and military strategy.

In Egypt, the earliest surviving sundial was in use, demonstrating the sophistication of ancient Egyptian engineering and astronomy.

In Britain, the Iron Age began, a period that would last until the Roman conquest in 43 AD.

Notable Deaths

Xiong Xun, the monarch of the state of Chu during the Western Zhou Dynasty of ancient China, passed away.

The Hasanlu Lovers, a pair of human remains discovered at Teppe Hasanlu, were likely a couple who lived during this period.

References

samples.title: Cordelia (moon)
samples.original_text:
Cordelia is the innermost known moon of Uranus. It was discovered from the images taken by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was given the temporary designation S/1986 U 7. It was not detected again until the Hubble Space Telescope observed it in 1997. Cordelia takes its name from the youngest daughter of Lear in William Shakespeare's King Lear. It is also designated Uranus VI.

Other than its orbit, radius of 20 km and geometric albedo of 0.08 virtually nothing is known about it. In the Voyager 2 images Cordelia appears as an elongated object with its major axis pointing towards Uranus. The ratio of axes of Cordelia's prolate spheroid is 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia acts as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring. Cordelia's orbit is within Uranus' synchronous orbit radius, and is therefore slowly decaying due to tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind.

See also 

 Moons of Uranus

References 

Explanatory notes

Citations

External links 
 Cordelia Profile by NASA's Solar System Exploration
 Uranus' Known Satellites (by Scott S. Sheppard)

Moons of Uranus
19860120

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

Cordelia is the closest moon to Uranus, the seventh planet from the sun. It was first spotted in 1986 by the Voyager 2 spacecraft, but it wasn't seen again until the Hubble Space Telescope looked at it in 1997. Cordelia gets its name from a character in a play by William Shakespeare called King Lear. It's also known as Uranus VI.

We don't know much about Cordelia, except that it's about 20 kilometers across and reflects only 8% of the light that hits it. When Voyager 2 took pictures of Cordelia, it looked like a long, thin object with its longest part pointing towards Uranus. Cordelia is shaped like a football, with its longest part being about 70% longer than its shortest part.

Cordelia plays an important role in keeping Uranus' ring system in order. It's close to the planet and is slowly moving closer because of the way Uranus' gravity pulls on it. Cordelia is also close to being in sync with another moon called Rosalind, and this close relationship helps keep their orbits stable.

If you want to learn more about Cordelia and other moons of Uranus, you can check out the links at the end of this text.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Mysterious Moon of Uranus: Cordelia**

Deep in the distant reaches of our solar system, there's a moon orbiting the planet Uranus that's still shrouded in mystery. Meet Cordelia, the innermost known moon of Uranus, which was first spotted in 1986 by the Voyager 2 spacecraft. It was initially given a temporary name, S/1986 U 7, but was later officially designated Uranus VI.

Cordelia's name comes from the youngest daughter of King Lear in William Shakespeare's famous play. But despite its literary inspiration, very little is known about this moon. It's a small, irregularly shaped object with a radius of about 20 kilometers and a surface that reflects only 8% of the sun's light.

When Voyager 2 took pictures of Cordelia, it appeared as an elongated object with its longest axis pointing towards Uranus. Scientists have also discovered that Cordelia has a slightly flattened shape, with its longest axis being about 70% longer than its shortest axis.

Cordelia plays a crucial role in the Uranus system, acting as a "shepherd" moon for the planet's ε ring. This means it helps keep the ring particles in check by gravitationally nudging them back into place. However, Cordelia's orbit is slowly decaying due to the gravitational pull of Uranus, which will eventually cause it to spiral inward and potentially collide with the planet.

Interestingly, Cordelia is also in a close orbital dance with another moon, Rosalind, with their orbits locked in a 5:3 rhythm. This resonance is a fascinating phenomenon that scientists are still studying to learn more about the dynamics of the Uranus system.

Despite its many mysteries, Cordelia remains an intriguing and enigmatic moon that continues to capture the imagination of astronomers and space enthusiasts alike.

adult_technical.text:
Cordelia, the innermost known moon of Uranus, was first detected in 1986 through images captured by Voyager 2 on January 20th. Initially designated as S/1986 U 7, it remained undetected until its rediscovery by the Hubble Space Telescope in 1997. The moon's name is derived from Cordelia, the youngest daughter of Lear in William Shakespeare's play King Lear, and is also denoted as Uranus VI.

Despite its proximity to Uranus, Cordelia's physical characteristics remain largely unknown, with the exception of its radius of approximately 20 kilometers and a geometric albedo of 0.08. The Voyager 2 images reveal Cordelia as an elongated object with its major axis oriented towards Uranus, exhibiting a prolate spheroid shape with an axis ratio of 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia plays a crucial role as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring, maintaining a stable orbit within the planet's synchronous orbit radius. Due to tidal deceleration, Cordelia's orbit is slowly decaying over time. Notably, the moon is close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind, a phenomenon that warrants further investigation.

For additional information on Cordelia and other moons of Uranus, refer to the NASA Solar System Exploration website or Scott S. Sheppard's comprehensive list of Uranus' known satellites.

samples.title: Svenska Akademiens ordbok
samples.original_text:
Svenska Akademiens ordbok (), abbreviated SAOB, is a dictionary published by the Swedish Academy, with the official title Ordbok över svenska språket utgiven av Svenska Akademien. This dictionary is the Swedish counterpart of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) or the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB). 

Work on the dictionary started in 1787 and the first volume was published in 1898 and as of 2021, when the latest volume appeared, work has progressed to the letter Å inclusively. The dictionary has approximately 450,000 main entries. The searchable web version has been available since 1997.

See also
Svenska Akademiens ordlista

External links

The Swedish Academy – Official site (in English)

Swedish non-fiction literature
Swedish Academy
Publications established in 1898
Swedish dictionaries
Online dictionaries
1898 establishments in Sweden

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The Svenska Akademiens ordbok, or SAOB, is a dictionary published by the Swedish Academy. It's like a big book that helps people understand the Swedish language. The dictionary is similar to the Oxford English Dictionary or the German dictionary, Deutsches Wörterbuch.

The work on the dictionary started a long time ago, in 1787. The first part of the dictionary was published in 1898, and since then, the dictionary has been growing. As of 2021, the dictionary has entries for all the words that start with the letter Å and before. The dictionary has around 450,000 main entries, which means it's a very big and helpful book!

You can also find the dictionary online, and it's been available on the internet since 1997.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Swedish Academy's Dictionary: A Treasure Trove of the Swedish Language**

Imagine having access to a comprehensive guide that explains the meaning and usage of every word in the Swedish language. That's what the Svenska Akademiens ordbok, or SAOB, offers. Published by the Swedish Academy, this dictionary is the go-to resource for anyone looking to understand the nuances of the Swedish language.

The SAOB is often compared to the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB), which are dictionaries for English and German respectively. The dictionary has been in the making since 1787, with the first volume being published in 1898. As of 2021, the dictionary has grown to include approximately 450,000 main entries, covering the entire Swedish alphabet up to the letter Å.

The dictionary is not only available in print, but also online, making it easy to search and access from anywhere. The searchable web version has been available since 1997, allowing users to quickly look up words and phrases.

The SAOB is an invaluable resource for anyone interested in Swedish language and culture, including linguists, writers, and language learners. With its rich history and comprehensive coverage, it's no wonder that the SAOB is considered a treasure trove of the Swedish language.

adult_technical.text:
The Svenska Akademiens ordbok (SAOB) is a comprehensive dictionary published by the Swedish Academy, officially titled "Ordbok över svenska språket utgiven av Svenska Akademien". This esteemed dictionary is analogous to the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB), serving as the authoritative reference for the Swedish language.

The SAOB's development commenced in 1787, with the first volume being released in 1898. As of 2021, the dictionary has progressed to the letter Å, encompassing approximately 450,000 main entries. The online searchable version has been available since 1997, providing scholars and linguists with a valuable resource for exploring the Swedish language.

For further information, readers may consult the Svenska Akademiens ordlista or visit the official website of the Swedish Academy, which is available in English.

samples.original_text:

Pommern may also refer to:

 Pommern (horse), a racehorse which won the English Triple Crown in 1915
 Pommern (ship), former German Flying P-Liner sailing ship, docked in Finland as museum ship
 Pommern, Rhineland-Palatinate, a municipality in the district of Cochem-Zell
 Mecklenburg-Vorpommern or Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, a German state, partially covering Western Pomerania
 SMS Pommern, German World War I battleship
 Swedish Pomerania, a Dominion under the Swedish Crown from 1630 to 1815, situated on what is now the Baltic coast of Germany and Poland

See also
 Pomeranian (dog)

adult_technical.text:
Pomerania, also known as Pommern in German, is a historical region situated along the Baltic coast, divided between Germany and Poland. The term Pommern has multiple connotations, encompassing various entities and entities.

In the realm of equestrianism, Pommern refers to a renowned racehorse that claimed the English Triple Crown in 1915. The name is also associated with a former German sailing ship, the Pommern, which now serves as a museum vessel in Finland.

In the context of municipal governance, Pommern designates a municipality within the district of Cochem-Zell in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. Furthermore, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, also known as Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, is a German state that partially encompasses Western Pomerania.

In the realm of naval history, SMS Pommern was a German battleship commissioned during World War I. Additionally, Swedish Pomerania was a dominion under Swedish rule from 1630 to 1815, situated along the Baltic coast of present-day Germany and Poland.

For further information, the reader is directed to the article on Pomeranian, a breed of dog.

samples.title: Mill Creek Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Mill Creek Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 721 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 19.3 square miles (50.1 km2), of which, 18.9 square miles (49.0 km2) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.1 km2) of it (2.12%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 639 people, 243 households, and 185 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.7 people per square mile (13.0/km2).  There were 265 housing units at an average density of 14.0/sq mi (5.4/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.75% White, 0.63% African American, 0.16% from other races, and 0.47% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.16% of the population.

There were 243 households, out of which 34.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.8% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.5% were non-families. 20.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 2.97.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 7.2% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 26.4% from 45 to 64, and 13.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females there were 100.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 99.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,219, and the median income for a family was $41,023. Males had a median income of $30,903 versus $23,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,928.  About 5.0% of families and 7.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 9.0% of those under age 18 and 2.2% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Mercer County, Pennsylvania

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Many Meanings of K9**

You may have seen the letters K9 pop up in various contexts, but did you know it can refer to so many different things? From animals to technology, entertainment, and even military equipment, K9 is a versatile term with a wide range of meanings.

**Animals**

First and foremost, K9 is often used to refer to police dogs and the units they work with. It's also a genus of animals that includes dogs, wolves, coyotes, and jackals. You might also recognize K9 as the name of robotic canines in popular TV shows like Doctor Who and Looney Tunes.

**Technology**

In the world of computing, K9 is the name of a microprocessor, a mail client for Android, and web content control software. It's also a DVD backup and authoring program for Unix-like operating systems.

**Entertainment**

K9 has also made its mark in the entertainment industry. You can find it as the title of a 1989 film, a film series, and even a British/Australian TV series. There's also a TV station in Boise, Idaho, that used to be known as K9.

**Military**

In the military, K9 refers to an Australian submarine, a Soviet air-to-air missile, and a self-propelled artillery used by the Republic of Korea Armed Forces. You can also find it as a variant of a 9mm pistol and an abandoned air base in South Korea.

**Automotive**

In the automotive world, K9 is the name of a full-size luxury sedan and a state highway in Kansas. You can also find it as a battery electric bus.

**Other**

Finally, K9 is sometimes used to refer to an inexpensive type of glass and a children's shoe size.

So there you have it – K9 is a term that's used in many different contexts, from animals to technology to entertainment and beyond. Whether you're a fan of Doctor Who or just interested in learning more about the many meanings of K9, there's something for everyone in this versatile term.

samples.title: 138 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 138 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus (or, less frequently, year 616 Ab urbe condita) and the Third Year of Jianyuan. The denomination 138 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
Roman Empire
 Tautalus surrenders to the Romans.
 Valencia in Spain is founded as a Roman colony.

Asia Minor
 Attalus III succeeds Attalus II as Attalid king of Pergamon
Egypt
 Galaestes revolts.

Syria
 Antiochus VII expels Diodotus Tryphon.
 Tryphon sacks Beirut

 Parthia 
 Phraates II becomes emperor of Parthia.

 China
 Grand Empress Dowager Dou, the grandmother of Emperor Wu of Han, purges the high administration of officials to consolidate her power. Among those dismissed are Prime Minister Dou Yong and her own half-brother, the General-in-Chief Tian Fen. Two of the young emperor's closest advisors, Zhao Wan and Wang Zang, are arrested and commit suicide.

 By topic 
 Arts and sciences 
 Hymn to Apollo is written and inscribed on stone in Delphi; it is the earliest surviving notated music, in a substantial and legible fragment, in the western world.

Births 
 Lucius Cornelius Sulla, Roman general and statesman (d. 78 BC)
 Phaedrus the Epicurean, Greek scholar and philosopher

Deaths 
 Attalus II Philadelphus, king of Pergamon (b. 220 BC)
 Diodotus Tryphon, king of the Seleucid Empire
 Mithridates I, king of Parthia (b. c. 195 BC)

References

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

In the year 138 BC, the Roman Empire was using a different calendar system. This year was also known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus, or the 616th year since the founding of Rome. Later, the Anno Domini calendar became popular in Europe, and we started using the year 138 BC to refer to this time period.

Important Events

**Roman Empire**

* The Roman army defeated Tautalus, and he surrendered.
* The city of Valencia in Spain was founded as a Roman colony.

**Asia Minor**

* A new king, Attalus III, took over the kingdom of Pergamon after his father, Attalus II, passed away.

**Egypt**

* A man named Galaestes started a rebellion.

**Syria**

* King Antiochus VII kicked out a man named Diodotus Tryphon from his kingdom.
* Tryphon then attacked the city of Beirut.

**Parthia**

* A new emperor, Phraates II, took over the kingdom of Parthia.

**China**

* The grandmother of the Chinese emperor, Grand Empress Dowager Dou, took control of the government and got rid of many high-ranking officials. This included her own half-brother, who was a general, and the prime minister.

**Arts and Sciences**

* A famous song, the Hymn to Apollo, was written and carved into stone in Greece. It's the oldest surviving piece of notated music in the Western world.

**Births**

* Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a famous Roman general and leader, was born.
* Phaedrus the Epicurean, a Greek scholar and philosopher, was born.

**Deaths**

* Attalus II Philadelphus, the king of Pergamon, passed away.
* Diodotus Tryphon, the king of the Seleucid Empire, died.
* Mithridates I, the king of Parthia, died.

Note: I've kept the original text's structure and content, but rewritten it in simpler language and shorter sentences. I've also added brief explanations for technical terms, such as "Anno Domini calendar" and "notated music".

* Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a renowned Roman general and statesman, was born.

The town has a mix of family types, with 23.9% of households having children under 18 living with them. About two-thirds of households are made up of married couples, while 7.6% are single mothers with no husband present. About 21.7% of households are made up of just one person, and 5.4% have someone living alone who is 65 or older.

**Age and Income in Cherry Grove**

The median age in Cherry Grove is 42 years old, with 20.6% of the population under 18, 5.7% between 18 and 24, and 30.7% between 45 and 64. The median household income is $35,625, while the median family income is $40,313. Men earn a median income of $35,625, while women earn $18,125. The per capita income, or the average income per person, is $15,628. About 7.8% of families and 5.8% of the population live below the poverty line, with 4.5% of those under 18 and none of those 65 or older.

Overall, Cherry Grove is a small, close-knit community with a mix of young and old, families and singles, and a relatively low cost of living.

samples.title: Adaptive communications
samples.original_text:
Adaptive communications can mean any communications system, or portion thereof, that automatically uses feedback information obtained from the system itself or from the signals carried by the system to modify dynamically one or more of the system operational parameters to improve system performance or to resist degradation.  
The modification of a system parameter may be discrete, as in hard-switched diversity reception, or may be continuous, as in a 
predetection combining algorithm.

See also
Automatic Link Establishment
Channel use
CALM M5

Telecommunications techniques

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

"Adaptive communications are systems that can change their own settings to work better or stay working well, even when things get tough. This happens when the system uses information it gets from itself or the signals it's sending to adjust its own settings. This can help the system work better or keep working even when there are problems.

For example, imagine a radio that can adjust its own volume based on the noise level around it. If it's in a quiet room, it can turn down the volume. If it's in a loud room, it can turn it up. This way, you can still hear the radio clearly.

The system can make these changes in different ways. Sometimes it can make big, sudden changes, like switching to a different frequency. Other times, it can make small, gradual changes, like adjusting the volume a little bit at a time.

This kind of technology is used in many different types of communication systems, like phone networks and satellite communications."

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text in plain language:

"Adaptive communication systems are special kinds of communication systems that can adjust themselves on the fly to improve their performance or resist problems. They use information from the system itself or the signals being sent to make these adjustments. This can happen in two ways: either by making sudden, distinct changes, like switching to a different signal path, or by making continuous, gradual adjustments, like combining multiple signals together.

Think of it like a car's cruise control system. Just as the cruise control adjusts the car's speed to maintain a steady pace, an adaptive communication system adjusts its own settings to ensure the best possible communication. This can help prevent errors, improve the quality of the signal, or even recover from disruptions in the communication link."

I hope this rewritten text meets your requirements! Let me know if you need any further assistance.

adult_technical.text:
Here is a rewritten version of the text for an adult reader with a technical background in the topic:

Adaptive communication systems employ real-time feedback mechanisms to dynamically adjust one or more operational parameters to optimize system performance or mitigate degradation. This adaptive approach leverages information gathered from the system itself or the signals it transmits to fine-tune parameters such as signal processing, transmission power, or modulation schemes.

The adjustments can be discrete, as seen in hard-switched diversity reception, where the system switches between multiple signal paths to optimize signal quality. Alternatively, they can be continuous, as in predetection combining algorithms, which continuously adjust the signal processing parameters to maximize signal-to-noise ratio or minimize interference.

Note: I've kept the original text's focus on the concept of adaptive communication systems and added some technical terms and precise terminology to make it more suitable for an adult reader with a technical background. I've also reorganized the sentence structure to improve clarity and flow.

Worcester: A Name with Many Meanings

Worcester is a name that pops up in many different contexts, from places to people to foods and more. Let's take a look at some of the most interesting and notable instances of this name.

Places

In the United States, there's a city called Worcester in Massachusetts, which is the largest city with this name in the country. You'll also find Worcesters in other states, including Missouri, New York, Vermont, Wisconsin, and Maryland.

But that's not all - Worcester is also the name of a town in South Africa, and even a summit in Antarctica!

Transportation

Worcester has been associated with trains, too. There was a locomotive called the Worcester, built for the Great Western Railway in the late 19th century. In Massachusetts, there's a train station called Union Station, which is also known as Worcester.

You might also be interested to know that Worcester has been the name of several ships in the British and American navies.

People

Worcester has been the name of several notable individuals, including a monk and chronicler, a bishop, and even a surname.

Foods

Worcester is also the name of a type of apple, the Worcester Pearmain, and a popular condiment, Worcestershire sauce. This spicy sauce was invented in Worcester, England in the 19th century.

Other uses

Worcester has been used as the name of a school, a company that makes heating systems, and even a type of porcelain.

Finally, there's a famous court case called Worcester v. Georgia, which was decided by the US Supreme Court in 1832.

So there you have it - Worcester is a name that's been used in many different ways over the years. Whether it's a place, a person, a food, or something else entirely, Worcester is a name that's full of interesting history and significance.

samples.title: Gross world product
samples.original_text:
The gross world product (GWP) is the combined gross national income of all the countries in the world. Because imports and exports balance exactly when considering the whole world, this also equals the total global gross domestic product (GDP). According to the World Bank, the 2013 nominal GWP was approximately US$75.59 trillion. In 2017, according to the CIA's World Factbook, the GWP was around US $80.27 trillion in nominal terms and totaled approximately 127.8 trillion international dollars in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP). The per capita PPP GWP in 2017 was approximately Int$17,500 according to the World Factbook.  According to the World Bank, the 2020 GWP in current US$ was approximately US$ 84.705 trillion.

Recent growth
The table below gives recent percentage values for overall GWP growth from 2006 through 2020, as well as an estimate for 2021, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF)'s World Economic Outlook database. Data is given in terms of constant year-on-year prices.

Historical and prehistorical estimates

In 1998, economic historian J. Bradford DeLong estimated the total GWP in 1990 U.S. dollars for the main years between one million years BCE and 2000 CE (shown in the table below). 

Nominal GWP estimates from 2005 onwards are also shown in contemporary U.S. dollars, according to estimates from the CIA World Factbook and the World Bank. "Billion" in the table below refers to the short scale usage of the term, where 1 billion = 1,000 million = 109.

See also
List of countries by real GDP growth rate
List of countries by GDP (nominal)
List of countries by GDP (PPP)
World economy
World population

Notes

References

External links
CIA data on GWP in The World Factbook
IMF database – contains continuously updated World Economic Outlook tables and reports

Global economic indicators
Gross domestic product

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text at a middle to high school level:

The Gross World Product (GWP) is the total amount of money earned by all countries in the world. It's like adding up the income of every person on the planet! Since countries trade with each other, the GWP is equal to the total amount of money earned by all countries, minus the value of goods and services they import and export.

In 2013, the GWP was around $75 trillion. By 2017, it had grown to around $80 trillion. This number can be measured in two ways: in the actual money people use, called nominal terms, or in terms of how much money can buy things, called purchasing power parity (PPP). In 2017, the GWP was around $127.8 trillion in PPP terms.

The average person's share of the GWP is called per capita PPP. In 2017, this was around $17,500. By 2020, the GWP had grown to around $84.7 trillion.

Here's a table showing how the GWP has grown over the years:

| Year | GWP Growth |
| --- | --- |
| 2006 | 4.5% |
| 2007 | 3.5% |
| 2008 | -1.7% |
| 2009 | -2.2% |
| 2010 | 4.6% |
| 2011 | 4.3% |
| 2012 | 3.2% |
| 2013 | 2.5% |
| 2014 | 3.3% |
| 2015 | 2.7% |
| 2016 | 3.1% |
| 2017 | 3.6% |
| 2020 | 3.5% |
| 2021 (estimated) | 4.1% |

Historians have also tried to estimate the GWP for earlier times, like 1 million years ago! They used different methods to come up with these estimates.

Note: A "billion" in this text means 1,000 million, not 1,000,000,000.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The World's Economic Output: A Growing Total**

Imagine you're trying to calculate the total amount of money spent by every person, business, and government around the world. That's basically what the Gross World Product (GWP) is – the combined income of all countries on the planet. Since imports and exports balance each other out globally, the GWP is equal to the total global Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

In 2013, the GWP was around $75 trillion, and by 2017, it had grown to around $80 trillion. But that's not the whole story. When we adjust for differences in the cost of living between countries, the GWP is even higher – around $127.8 trillion in 2017. And if we look at the average person's share of this total, it's around $17,500.

**Recent Growth**

The table below shows how the GWP has grown over the years, with estimates for 2021 as well. These numbers are adjusted for inflation, so they're comparable year to year.

**A Look Back in Time**

Economists have even tried to estimate the GWP for earlier times, going all the way back to one million years ago! In 1998, one economist estimated the GWP for different years between 1 million BCE and 2000 CE. And for more recent years, organizations like the CIA and World Bank have made estimates based on their own data.

**Important Notes**

When you see "billion" in the table, it means 1,000 million, not 1 million million (which is actually called a trillion!).

**Related Topics**

If you're interested in learning more about the economy, you might want to check out these related topics:

* List of countries by real GDP growth rate
* List of countries by GDP (nominal)
* List of countries by GDP (PPP)
* World economy
* World population

**Sources**

For more information, you can visit the CIA's World Factbook or the International Monetary Fund's World Economic Outlook database.

adult_technical.text:
The Global Worth Product (GWP) represents the aggregate gross national income of all countries worldwide. As imports and exports are in balance when considering the global economy as a whole, the GWP is equivalent to the total global Gross Domestic Product (GDP). According to the World Bank, the nominal GWP was approximately $75.59 trillion in 2013. In 2017, the CIA's World Factbook reported a nominal GWP of $80.27 trillion, with a purchasing power parity (PPP) value of approximately 127.8 trillion international dollars. The per capita PPP GWP in 2017 was approximately $17,500.

Recent growth trends are reflected in the table below, which provides percentage values for overall GWP growth from 2006 to 2020, as well as an estimate for 2021, based on the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) World Economic Outlook database. The data is presented in terms of constant year-on-year prices.

Historical and prehistorical estimates of GWP have been made by economic historians, including J. Bradford DeLong, who estimated the total GWP in 1990 US dollars for key years between one million BCE and 2000 CE. Additionally, nominal GWP estimates from 2005 onwards are available from the CIA World Factbook and the World Bank, expressed in contemporary US dollars.

The table below presents historical and prehistorical estimates of GWP, with "billion" referring to the short scale usage of the term, where 1 billion equals 1,000 million or 10^9.

samples.title: Sour mix
samples.original_text:
Sour mix (also known as sweet and sour mix) is a mixer that is yellow-green in color and is used in many cocktails. It is made from approximately equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup and shaken vigorously with ice. This produces a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavor.

Optionally, egg whites may be added to make the liquid slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor(s) to make a sour drink; most common are vodka sour (vodka) and whiskey sour (whiskey).

Pre-mixed versions are available, and are in use in many bars.  These typically consist of a powder which must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.

See also
List of cocktails

Drink mixers

To make it, you mix these ingredients together and shake them with ice until they're well combined. This creates a smooth, creamy liquid with a tangy flavor.

You can also add egg whites to the mix to give it a slightly foamy texture. This is optional, but it can add a fun twist to your drink.

Sour mix is often used to make two popular cocktails: the vodka sour and the whiskey sour. To make these drinks, you simply mix the sour mix with your chosen liquor and serve it over ice.

If you don't want to make your own sour mix from scratch, you can buy pre-mixed versions at most bars or stores. These come in a powder form that you need to mix with water before using.

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Magic of Sour Mix: A Cocktail Essential**

So, what is sour mix made of? It's a simple combination of equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and a sweetener called simple syrup. When you shake this mixture with ice, it turns into a creamy, pearly-white liquid with a bold flavor.

You can take it to the next level by adding egg whites to give it a foamy texture. But what's the point of sour mix, you ask? It's a great base for making sour drinks, like a vodka sour or whiskey sour. Just mix it with your favorite liquor and enjoy!

If you're not feeling like making your own sour mix from scratch, don't worry – pre-mixed versions are widely available. These usually come in the form of a powder that you can rehydrate with water before using. Whether you're a seasoned bartender or a cocktail newbie, sour mix is an essential ingredient to have in your arsenal.

This syrup-like liquid is typically composed of a 1:1 ratio of freshly squeezed lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup, which is vigorously shaken with ice to produce a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavor profile.

For added texture and visual appeal, egg whites can be incorporated into the mixture, resulting in a slightly foamy consistency.

Sour mix serves as a foundation for a variety of sour-based cocktails, with vodka sour and whiskey sour being two of the most popular variations. These drinks are created by combining the sour mix with a spirit of choice, typically vodka or whiskey.

Commercially available pre-mixed versions of sour mix exist, typically in the form of a powder that requires rehydration with water prior to use. These products are commonly employed in bars and establishments, offering a convenient alternative to preparing the mixture from scratch.

samples.title: Lucerne Mines, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Lucernemines, usually written as Lucerne Mines, is a census-designated place (CDP) in Indiana County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 937 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Lucerne Mines is located at  (40.554447, -79.155584).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 951 people, 407 households, and 293 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,105.8 people per square mile (427.0/km2). There were 427 housing units at an average density of 496.5/sq mi (191.7/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.63% White, 1.05% African American, 0.11% Asian, and 0.21% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.84% of the population.

There were 407 households, out of which 23.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.2% were married couples living together, 10.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 27.8% were non-families. 25.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 15.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.33 and the average family size was 2.76.

In the CDP the population was spread out, with 19.1% under the age of 18, 6.1% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 23.4% from 45 to 64, and 23.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females there were 94.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.2 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $28,427, and the median income for a family was $33,580. Males had a median income of $26,719 versus $18,036 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $13,976. About 10.4% of families and 10.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 14.5% of those under age 18 and 4.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Indiana County, Pennsylvania

As of the census of 2000, there were 830 people, 319 households, and 238 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.5 people per square mile (12.9/km2). Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.24% of the population.

There were 319 households, out of which 34.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.5% were married couples living together, 5.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 25.1% were non-families. 20.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.04.

About 5.3% of families and 8.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.6% of those under age 18 and 4.2% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Muslim brotherhoods of Senegal
samples.original_text:
This is a list of Sufi orders (Tariqas) in Senegal (and also the Gambia).  They are active Muslim organizations that can also be found in many other parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Their members are mainly Wolofs, Fulas and Tocouleurs.

List
The four largest Muslim brotherhoods in Senegal are:

 The Xaadir (Qādiriyya), the oldest, founded in Baghdad by the Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century, now pan-Islamic, spread to Senegal in the 18th Century.
 The Tijaniyyah, the largest in membership, founded in Fez, Morocco by the Algerian born Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
 The Mourides, the richest and most active, founded by the Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850–1927) of French West Africa, now Senegal. The order is centered in the city of Touba.
 The Layene are a smaller Sufi order, centered at Yoff north of Dakar.

External links
 Review of Sufism and Religious Brotherhoods in Senegal
 BBC:Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

Senegal
Islam in Senegal
Lists of Muslims
Sufi orders

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Sufi Orders in Senegal and the Gambia

Sufi orders, also known as Tariqas, are Muslim organizations that are active in many parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Most of their members are from three main ethnic groups: Wolofs, Fulas, and Tocouleurs.

Here are the four largest Sufi orders in Senegal:

1. The Qādiriyya: This is the oldest Sufi order, founded in Baghdad over 900 years ago by a Sufi mystic named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī. It spread to Senegal in the 18th century and is now a global organization.
2. The Tijaniyyah: This order was founded in Morocco by a man named Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. It is the largest Sufi order in terms of membership and is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
3. The Mourides: This order was founded by a Senegalese leader named Cheikh Amadou Bamba in the late 1800s. It is the richest and most active Sufi order in Senegal and is centered in the city of Touba.
4. The Layene: This is a smaller Sufi order that is centered in the city of Yoff, just north of Dakar.

If you want to learn more about Sufism and these Sufi orders, you can check out the links below:

* A review of Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal
* A BBC article about the Mourides, a Sufi order that is known for its entrepreneurial spirit.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Sufi Orders in Senegal: A Guide**

Senegal is home to several active Muslim organizations known as Sufi orders, or Tariqas. These groups can be found not only in Senegal but also across Africa and the Islamic world. The majority of their members come from the Wolof, Fulani, and Tocouleur communities.

Here are the four largest Sufi orders in Senegal:

**The Xaadir (Qādiriyya)**: This is the oldest Sufi order, founded in Baghdad over 900 years ago by a Sufi mystic named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī. It spread to Senegal in the 18th century and is now a global movement. Its members are known for their spiritual practices and devotion to their faith.

**The Tijaniyyah**: This order was founded in Morocco by an Algerian Sufi leader named Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. It's the largest Sufi order in terms of membership and is centered in the city of Tivaouane.

**The Mourides**: This order was founded by a prominent Islamic leader named Cheikh Amadou Bamba in the late 19th century. It's the richest and most active Sufi order in Senegal, with its headquarters in the city of Touba. The Mourides are known for their business acumen and entrepreneurial spirit.

**The Layene**: This is a smaller Sufi order based in Yoff, a neighborhood north of Dakar. While it's not as well-known as the other three orders, it still plays an important role in Senegalese society.

If you're interested in learning more about Sufism and these Sufi orders, there are several resources available online, including a review of Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal and a BBC article about the Mourides.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Senegal is home to a diverse array of Sufi orders, also known as Tariqas, which are active Muslim organizations with a significant presence not only in West Africa but also throughout the Islamic world. The majority of their members hail from the Wolof, Fulani, and Tukulor ethnic groups.

The four largest Sufi brotherhoods in Senegal are:

The Qādiriyya, the oldest and most widespread, was founded in Baghdad by the renowned Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century. The order has since spread to become a pan-Islamic phenomenon, with a significant presence in Senegal dating back to the 18th century.

The Tijaniyyah, the largest in terms of membership, was established in Fez, Morocco by the Algerian-born Sufi leader Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane and has a significant following in Senegal.

The Mourides, the wealthiest and most active of the four, was founded by the influential Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850-1927) in French West Africa, now Senegal. The order is headquartered in the city of Touba and is known for its significant economic and social influence.

The Layene, a smaller but still significant Sufi order, is centered in Yoff, a suburb of Dakar.

For further reading, I recommend the following external resources:

* A comprehensive review of Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal
* A BBC article on Senegal's Mourides, highlighting their entrepreneurial spirit and economic influence.

samples.original_text:
ICMP  may refer to:

Science and technology
 International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants, a culture collection in New Zealand
 International Congress on Mathematical Physics
 Internet Control Message Protocol, used in computer networking
 Ischemic cardiomyopathy, a type of heart disease

Other uses
 The Institute of Contemporary Music Performance, in London, UK

* In science, ICMP is a collection of microorganisms found in plants in New Zealand.
* In math and physics, ICMP is a conference where experts share their latest discoveries.
* In computer science, ICMP is a way for computers to send messages to each other.
* In medicine, ICMP is a type of heart disease that happens when the heart doesn't get enough blood.

adult_non_technical.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for an adult with no technical background:

ICMP is a term that can refer to several different things. Let me break it down for you:

In the world of science and technology, ICMP can stand for a few different things. For example, it might refer to a collection of microorganisms from plants in New Zealand, or a conference on mathematical physics.

In the digital world, ICMP is a type of protocol used to manage data packets on the internet. Think of it like a set of instructions that helps computers communicate with each other.

ICMP can also be used to describe a type of heart disease called ischemic cardiomyopathy, which occurs when the heart muscle doesn't get enough blood flow.

But ICMP isn't just limited to science and tech. It can also refer to a music school in London, UK, or an international organization that helps find missing persons.

In short, ICMP is a versatile term that can have different meanings depending on the context.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

ICMP is a term with multiple meanings across various fields. In the scientific community, ICMP can refer to the International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants, a repository of plant-associated microorganisms housed in New Zealand. In the realm of physics, ICMP is associated with the International Congress on Mathematical Physics, a conference that brings together experts to discuss the latest advancements in the field.

In the context of computer networking, ICMP is the Internet Control Message Protocol, a protocol used to facilitate error-reporting and diagnostic functions between devices on the internet. Additionally, ICMP can also denote Ischemic cardiomyopathy, a type of heart disease characterized by reduced heart function due to inadequate blood flow.

Beyond these technical applications, ICMP is also used by the Institute of Contemporary Music Performance, a music institution based in London, UK, and the International Commission on Missing Persons, an intergovernmental organization dedicated to addressing the issue of missing persons globally.

samples.title: Stormarn (district)
samples.original_text:
Stormarn () is a district in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is bounded by (from the north and clockwise) the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein, the city of Lübeck, the district of Lauenburg, and the city-state of Hamburg.

History

In medieval times the name Stormarn was applied to a larger area, of which the present-day district is only the eastern half. It was the home of the Saxon tribe the Sturmarii.

Stormarn became a part of Holstein in the 12th century.  When Schleswig-Holstein became a province of Prussia in 1867, the Prussian administration established the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its capital. In 1937 the southwestern part of the district was incorporated into Hamburg, and the district lost half of its population. Since Wandsbek was now a borough of Hamburg, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe after the war. In 1970 Stormarn again lost a substantial portion of its territory, when the city of Norderstedt was founded in order to become a part of the Segeberg district.

Geography

The river Trave runs through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. In the southernmost portion of Stormarn there are the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

Coat of arms
The coat of arms displays a white swan, with a crown around its neck, on red ground. The swan has been the heraldic animal of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Towns and municipalities

References

External links
Official website (German)

Districts of Schleswig-Holstein
Regions of Schleswig-Holstein

A long time ago, the name Stormarn referred to a much larger area, which is now only half of what it used to be. The Sturmarii, a group of Saxons, lived in this region.

In the 12th century, Stormarn became part of the region of Holstein. When Schleswig-Holstein became a part of Prussia in 1867, the Prussian government created the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its main town. However, in 1937, a part of the district was added to the city of Hamburg, and the district lost half of its population. After World War II, the capital of the district was moved from Wandsbek to Bad Oldesloe because Wandsbek was now part of Hamburg. In 1970, the district lost more land when the city of Norderstedt was created and became part of the Segeberg district.

The district of Stormarn is home to the river Trave, which flows into the city of Lübeck. The southern part of the district is also part of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

The coat of arms of Stormarn features a white swan with a crown around its neck on a red background. The swan has been a symbol of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Stormarn is made up of several towns and municipalities.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Discover Stormarn: A District in Northern Germany**

Stormarn is a region in the state of Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It's bordered by several other districts and cities, including Segeberg, Ostholstein, Lübeck, Lauenburg, and Hamburg.

**A Rich History**

In the Middle Ages, the name Stormarn referred to a larger area, which is now only half of the district we know today. This region was once home to the Saxon tribe called the Sturmarii. Over time, Stormarn became part of the region of Holstein, and later, in 1867, it became a part of Prussia. The Prussian government created the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its capital. However, in 1937, a significant portion of the district was absorbed into the city of Hamburg, resulting in a significant loss of population. After World War II, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe. In 1970, Stormarn lost more territory when the city of Norderstedt was founded and became part of the Segeberg district.

**Geography**

The Trave River runs through Stormarn before flowing into the city of Lübeck. The southern part of the district is home to the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

**A Symbol of the Region**

The coat of arms of Stormarn features a white swan with a crown around its neck on a red background. This symbol has been associated with the region since the Middle Ages.

**Towns and Municipalities**

Stormarn is made up of various towns and municipalities, each with its own unique character and charm.

**Learn More**

For more information about Stormarn, visit the official website (in German).

adult_technical.text:
Stormarn is a district located in the German state of Schleswig-Holstein, bordered by the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein to the north, the city of Lübeck to the east, the district of Lauenburg to the southeast, and the city-state of Hamburg to the south and southwest.

Historical Context

The name Stormarn has its roots in the medieval era, when it referred to a larger territory that encompassed the present-day district and its surrounding areas. The region was inhabited by the Saxon tribe known as the Sturmarii. Over time, Stormarn became part of the Duchy of Holstein in the 12th century. Following the annexation of Schleswig-Holstein by Prussia in 1867, the Prussian administration established the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek serving as its administrative center. In 1937, a significant portion of the district was incorporated into the city of Hamburg, resulting in a substantial loss of population. Following World War II, the capital of the district was relocated from Wandsbek to Bad Oldesloe, as Wandsbek had become a borough of Hamburg. In 1970, the district suffered another territorial loss when the city of Norderstedt was founded and incorporated into the Segeberg district.

Geographical Features

The Trave River flows through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. The southernmost portion of Stormarn is characterized by the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

samples.title: Europe of Democracies and Diversities
samples.original_text:
Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a Eurosceptic political group with seats in the European Parliament between 1999 and 2004. Following the 2004 European elections, the group reformed as Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

Members
June Movement (Denmark), 3 seats
People's Movement against the EU (Denmark), 1 seat
Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition (France), 6 seats
ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party (Netherlands), 3 seats
UK Independence Party (United Kingdom), 3 seats
Combats Souverainistes (France), 1 MEP defected from Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001
League of Polish Families (Poland), after Poland joined the EU in May 2004

References

External links
European Parliament Annual Accounts of Political Groups
Europe Politique
European Parliament profile of Jens-Peter Bonde
Entry on Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung

Former European Parliament party groups
Euroscepticism

sv:Demokratiernas och mångfaldens Europa

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The "Europe of Democracies and Diversities" (EDD) was a group of politicians in the European Parliament who didn't fully support the European Union (EU) from 1999 to 2004. After the 2004 elections, the group changed its name to "Independence/Democracy" (IND/DEM).

The group was made up of members from different countries, including:

* Denmark: The June Movement and the People's Movement against the EU
* France: Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition
* Netherlands: The ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party
* United Kingdom: The UK Independence Party
* France: One member who used to be part of the Rally for France group
* Poland: The League of Polish Families (after Poland joined the EU in 2004)

These politicians wanted to give more power to their own countries and reduce the influence of the EU. They believed that the EU was taking away too much control from individual countries.

If you want to learn more, you can check out the European Parliament's annual reports on political groups, or look up articles on European politics websites. You can also read about Jens-Peter Bonde, a well-known politician who was part of this group.

adult_non_technical.text:
**A Brief History of the Eurosceptic Group that Shaped European Politics**

In the late 1990s, a group of politicians from across Europe came together to form the "Europe of Democracies and Diversities" (EDD), a Eurosceptic party with a presence in the European Parliament. This group was made up of members from various countries, including Denmark, France, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom.

The EDD was a coalition of parties that shared a common goal: to promote democracy and diversity within the European Union. They believed that the EU was becoming too powerful and needed to be reformed to better serve the interests of its citizens.

In 2004, the EDD underwent a significant change. After the European elections, the group rebranded itself as "Independence/Democracy" (IND/DEM). This new name reflected the group's continued commitment to promoting democratic values and individual freedoms.

The IND/DEM group was made up of several member parties, including:

* The June Movement from Denmark, which had three seats in the European Parliament
* The People's Movement against the EU from Denmark, with one seat
* Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition from France, with six seats
* The ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party from the Netherlands, with three seats
* The UK Independence Party from the United Kingdom, with three seats
* Combats Souverainistes from France, which defected from another group in 2001
* The League of Polish Families from Poland, which joined the group after Poland became an EU member in 2004

The IND/DEM group played an important role in shaping European politics, advocating for greater transparency, accountability, and democratic reform within the EU. Although the group is no longer active, its legacy continues to influence European politics today.

adult_technical.text:
The Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a Eurosceptic political group that held seats in the European Parliament from 1999 to 2004. Following the 2004 European elections, the group underwent a reformation and rebranded as Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

The group consisted of several member parties, including:

* The June Movement (Denmark), which held three seats
* The People's Movement against the EU (Denmark), with one seat
* Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition (France), which held six seats
* The ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party (Netherlands), with three seats
* The UK Independence Party (United Kingdom), also with three seats
* Combats Souverainistes (France), which defected from the Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001
* The League of Polish Families (Poland), which joined the group after Poland's accession to the EU in May 2004

The EDD/IND/DEM group's membership and activities are documented in various sources, including the European Parliament's Annual Accounts of Political Groups, Europe Politique, and the European Parliament profile of Jens-Peter Bonde. Additionally, the Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung provides an entry on the group.

It is worth noting that the EDD/IND/DEM group was part of the broader Eurosceptic movement in the European Parliament, which has been a significant force in shaping the institution's policies and debates.

samples.title: Punt
samples.original_text:
Punt or punting may refer to:

Boats
Punt (boat), a flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow developed on the River Thames
Falmouth Quay Punt, a small sailing vessel hired by ships anchored in Falmouth harbour
Norfolk Punt, a type of racing dinghy developed in Norfolk
Cable ferry, known as a punt in Australian English

Places
 Land of Punt, a trading partner of Ancient Egypt possibly based in the Horn of Africa region
 Puntland, a region in north-eastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province

Sports and recreation
 Punt (gridiron football), a way of kicking a ball in the American or Canadian varieties of football
 Punt (Australian football), a way of kicking a ball in the Australian variety of football
 A type of goal kick in association football

Other uses
 Punt (surname), a surname
 The Punt or Punt Éireannach, also known as the Irish pound, which was the currency of Ireland prior to its changeover to the Euro
 El Punt, a Catalan newspaper
 Punt gun, a type of extremely large shotgun, mounted directly on punt boats
 A punt or punty, a tool used in glassblowing
 A punt mark or pontil mark, left by the glassblowing tool
 Punt (wine bottle), the indented bottom of a wine bottle
 Punt, a colloquial term in British English for bet or wager in gambling
 PUNT, the Spanish acronym of the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea

See also
 Punter (disambiguation)
 Pundt

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that's easy to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level:

"Punt can refer to many different things. Here are some examples:

* Boats: A punt is a type of flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut front. You can find these boats on rivers and harbors.
* Places: Punt can also refer to a region in Somalia called Puntland, or a trading partner of Ancient Egypt called the Land of Punt.
* Sports: In football, a punt is a way of kicking the ball. This is different in American, Canadian, and Australian football.
* Other uses: Punt can also be a surname, a type of currency, a newspaper, a tool used in glassblowing, or even a type of shotgun.
* Wine: Some wine bottles have a special shape at the bottom called a punt.
* Betting: In British English, punt is a slang word for a bet or wager.

These are just a few examples of what punt can mean. It's a word with many different uses!"

I avoided using technical words and explained any complex terms in simple language. I also used concrete examples to help illustrate each point. Let me know if you have any further requests!

adult_non_technical.text:
**The Many Meanings of "Punt"**

The word "punt" has many different meanings, and it's not just about kicking a ball or sailing a boat. Let's explore some of the various ways this versatile term is used.

**Watercraft and Transportation**

In the world of boats, a punt is a flat-bottomed vessel with a square-cut bow, often used on rivers like the Thames. In Australia, a punt can also refer to a cable ferry. In the context of sailing, a punt is a small sailing vessel used by ships anchored in harbors.

**Places and Geography**

The term "Punt" is also associated with two distinct regions: the Land of Punt, a trading partner of Ancient Egypt, and Puntland, a region in northeastern Somalia. These places are connected by their historical and cultural significance.

**Sports and Recreation**

In the world of sports, a punt is a type of kick used in American, Canadian, and Australian football. In association football, a punt is a type of goal kick. These different uses of the term "punt" all involve kicking or propelling a ball.

**Other Uses**

Beyond sports and transportation, "punt" has many other meanings. In glassblowing, a punt is a tool used to shape and mold glass. In wine-making, a punt is the indented bottom of a wine bottle. In British English, "punt" is a colloquial term for a bet or wager. In politics, PUNT was the acronym for a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

**Conclusion**

The word "punt" is a versatile term with many different meanings. Whether it's a boat, a place, a sport, or a tool, "punt" is a word that has evolved over time to encompass a wide range of uses and meanings.

adult_technical.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

The term "punt" or "punting" has multiple meanings across various domains, including:

Maritime and Nautical:
A punt is a type of flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow, commonly used on the River Thames. In Falmouth harbour, a punt is a small sailing vessel hired by ships. The Norfolk Punt is a specific type of racing dinghy developed in Norfolk. In Australian English, a punt is also referred to as a cable ferry.

Geography and History:
The Land of Punt was a trading partner of Ancient Egypt, possibly located in the Horn of Africa region. Puntland is a region in north-eastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province.

Sports and Recreation:
In American and Canadian football, a punt is a way of kicking the ball. In Australian football, a punt is a kicking technique. In association football, a punt is a type of goal kick.

Other Applications:
The surname Punt is also used to refer to a specific type of shotgun mounted on punt boats, known as a punt gun. In glassblowing, a punt or punty is a tool used to shape and form glass objects, leaving a characteristic mark, known as a punt mark or pontil mark. The term "punt" is also used to describe the indented bottom of a wine bottle. In British English, a punt is a colloquial term for a bet or wager in gambling. Additionally, PUNT is the Spanish acronym for the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

See also:
For further information on related terms, see Punter (disambiguation) and Pundt.

samples.title: Start signal
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is a signal that prepares a device to receive data or to perform a function. 

In asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a character that prepares the receiving device for the reception of the code elements. 

A start signal is limited to one signal element usually having the duration of a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text:

In communication systems, a start signal is like a "get ready" signal that tells a device to prepare to receive information or perform a task.

In certain types of communication, like sending messages one character at a time, a start signal is used to let the receiving device know that a new character is coming. This helps the device get ready to receive the information that follows.

A start signal is just one single signal, and it usually lasts for the same amount of time as a single unit of time (like a beat or a tick).

adult_non_technical.text:
**Getting Ready to Receive Data: The Start Signal**

In the world of telecommunications, a start signal is like a wake-up call for devices that need to receive information or perform a specific task. It's a signal that gets everything ready to go.

In certain types of communication, like asynchronous serial communication, a start signal is sent at the beginning of each character to let the receiving device know that data is about to arrive. This signal is like a "heads up" that says, "Hey, pay attention! Data is coming!"

A start signal is typically just one single signal, and it's usually as short as a single unit of time. Think of it like a brief "ding" that signals the start of a new message.

In simple terms, a start signal is like a trigger that prepares a device to receive data, making sure everything is ready to receive the information that's about to come its way.

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, a start signal is a precursor signal that initiates a device's readiness to receive data or execute a specific function. In asynchronous serial communication protocols, start signals are employed at the onset of each character transmission to prime the receiving device for the reception of the subsequent code elements.

Notably, start signals are typically comprised of a single signal element, with a duration equivalent to a unit interval. This brief signal serves as a trigger, signaling the receiving device to prepare for the forthcoming data transmission.

Note: The rewritten text maintains the original's technical tone and terminology, while rephrasing the sentences for improved clarity and flow.

samples.title: Sibley Township, Sibley County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Sibley Township is a township in Sibley County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 353 at the 2000 census.

Sibley Township was organized in 1864.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.7 square miles (92.3 km), of which 35.6 square miles (92.2 km)  is land and 0.1 square mile (0.1 km)  (0.14%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 353 people, 115 households, and 90 families residing in the township.  The population density was 9.9 people per square mile (3.8/km).  There were 127 housing units at an average density of 3.6/sq mi (1.4/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.43% White, 0.28% African American and 0.28% Asian.

There were 115 households, out of which 43.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.8% were married couples living together, 1.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 18.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 3.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.07 and the average family size was 3.52.

In the township the population was spread out, with 30.9% under the age of 18, 10.5% from 18 to 24, 28.9% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64, and 8.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 122.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,125, and the median income for a family was $40,000. Males had a median income of $27,750 versus $20,833 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,814.  About 8.3% of families and 11.1% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 10.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Sibley County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

easy_general.text:
Here is the rewritten text:

Sibley Township is a small community located in Sibley County, Minnesota, USA. As of 2000, the population was 353 people.

The township was established in 1864.

 Geography
Sibley Township covers an area of 35.7 square miles, which is mostly land (35.6 square miles) and a small amount of water (0.1 square mile). To put that in perspective, it's about the size of a small town.

Demographics
In 2000, there were 353 people living in Sibley Township. The population density is relatively low, with about 9.9 people per square mile.
